Auction: 1D pass 1NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1NT]
Do not be tempted to say 2!D, even with such good 3-card help. To support partner's minor suit opening you should have at least 4 cards in the suit. Remember he may have opened a 3-card suit.
Instead you bid 1NT showing a balanced 6-10 point hand with no 4-card Major suit. Partner passes.
South plays 1NT. West leads the !S4. East wins the !SA, then plays the !S9. West takes his !SK and leads another !S, East discarding a !H.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
To make a PLAN for a Notrump contract you should count your winners.
Winners: !S 1 : !H 1 : !D 2 : !C 3 : Total = 7
For this deal you see that you already have all the winners you need to make the contract. So you just want to be sure you don't do something stupid that would jeopardize those winners.
You win the !SQ, then lead to the !CA, !CK, !CQ. Everybody follows suit to these three tricks. Next you take the !HA. Then you play a small !D to your !DK, then play your !DA. You have now won your required 7 tricks, but you have a bonus. Since all the !Cs except the !C8 have been played your !C8 is now high and you make an overtrick.
Click NEXT to see the complete deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
But even with this type of hand you should make sure you take them in the right order. Here, if you had played the !DA and !DK BEFORE you played the !C A K Q you would have had no entry back to the fourth !C in your hand. In this case it was only an overtrick, in other deals it could make the difference between making and going down.

Auction: 1D pass 1H | pass 2H pass 4H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1!H]
A jump to 2NT would be descriptive, but your first goal is to seek a Major suit fit. When you have two 4-card Majors you should respond "up-the-line" so you bid 1!H. Partner says 2!H. What do you bid now? [BID 4!H]
Partner would not support your !H suit without 4 cards so you have an 8-card Major fit. There is no point in bidding !Ss.
Partner has at least 13 points and you have 13 so you bid the game.
South plays 4!H. West leads the !DT.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
To make a PLAN for a suit contract you should count your losers.
Losers: !S 0 : !H 1 : !D 0 : !C 3 : Total = 4
There is nothing you can do about losing the Ace of trumps. The three !C losers would only happen if West has the !CA and East wins a trick early, (say with the !HA), and leads a !C through your !CK.
You can take care of this possibility by discarding a !C from dummy BEFORE you play trumps. So win the !DK, and play !SA, !SK, !SQ, discarding dummy's !C3 on the last one. Then pull trumps. You will end up losing two !Cs and the !HA.
Click NEXT to see the Deal that could have set you. [NEXT]
East would win his !HA and would switch to a black suit to lead up to dummy's weakness. In this case he would surely lead the !CQ, and you would lose three !C tricks and be down before you started.
Making a PLAN is a necessary part of being a good Declarer and Visualizing what might happen is a necessary part of making a Plan.

Auction: pass 1NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1NT]
With 16 points and a balanced hand you should open 1NT. Do not worry about the lack of a !S stopper, a 1NT opening does not guarantee stoppers in all four suits.
Partner raises you to 3NT.
South plays 3NT. West leads the !S4.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Winners: !S 1 : !H 0 : !D 4 : !C 4 : Total = 9
It's nice to have a hand where the Winner count is 9. And guess what? West probably has the !SK, so you can finesse on the first trick for an overtrick.
HOLD IT! JUST STEP AWAY FROM THE QUEEN OF SPADES AND NOBODY WILL GET HURT.
What if you tried the finesse and East had the !SK? And what if he then switched to the !HQ? And what if your opponents then took the next 6 !H tricks? 
I think you get the idea. Win the !SA immediately and then take your other 8 tricks.
Click NEXT to see the complete Deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
This wasn't one of those times.

Auction: 1S | pass 2H pass 2S | pass 4S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1!S]
Don't think of passing. With 11 HCP and 2 length points you open 1!S. Partner responds 2!H. What is your next bid? [BID 2!S]
You must bid and you want to show that you have a bare minimum. You don't want to say 2NT because of that doubleton nothing !D. So you rebid your 6-card !S suit. Partner bids 4!S and everybody passes.
South plays 4!S. West leads the !D5 on which you play dummy's !D3. East wins !DJ, plays !DA, then !D2.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 1 : !H 0 : !D 2 : !C 1 : Total = 4
You have already lost the 2 !Ds and you sure can't escape losing the Ace of trumps. So you mustnot lose a !C trick. So your Plan will be to pull trumps, then finesse East for the !CQ. 
You ruff the third !D, play !Ss until the !SA appears. When you regain the lead you pull any outstanding trumps, play one high !C, (in case someone has a singleton !CQ), then enter dummy with the !HA and make the !C finesse. Half of the time you make the contract, the other half you don't.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
It's never great when the success of your contract depends on a finesse, but sometimes that's your only hope - a 50% chance.

Auction: pass 1NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1NT]
You have a very solid 17 points and a balanced hand. You open 1NT. Partner responds 3NT and you pass.
South plays 3NT. West leads the !HJ. You hopefully put on the !HQ, but East plays the !HK.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
You hopefully put on the !HQ, but East plays the !HK.
Winners: !S 0 : !H 1 : !D 1 : !C 4 : Total = 6
A hold-up won't help unless East had a doubleton !H, giving West a 7-card suit. So you win your !HA. The !S suit is solid after the !SA is played, but before you could enjoy those 3 tricks the defenders would have really enjoyed a bunch of !Hs.
Your only hope is to win 8 more tricks before you lose the lead. That means the !D finesse had better work. At trick 2 you lead your !DQ, playing low from dummy if West doesn't cover. Repeat the finesse as necessary. When West has the !DK you will make your contract, and when East has the !DK you will go down. That's a 50% chance, just like most finesses. But remember, if you had tried to establish the !S suit instead of taking the finesse your chance of making 3NT would be 0%.
Click for the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]

Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID pass]
You have 7 points so you know your side does not have a game. You also have no reason to think there is any better contract than 1NT. So you pass.
North would play 1NT. To make life more convenient the hands will be rotated so that South becomes declarer. 
Click NEXT. [ROTATE]

South plays 1NT. West leads the !HQ.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Winners: !S 1 : !H 2 : !D 1 : !C 1 : Total = 5
You need two more winners. Even if the !Ds split 3-2 you can get only one more from that suit. So clearly you must use the !S suit. Since you have only one entry to dummy you must save it until the right time.
Win the first trick with the !HK. Then play !SA followed by !S2. Continue playing !Ss until the !SK is forced out. Win whatever they play next and play your other winners. You cannot be stopped from taking 7 tricks.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
What would you try next? A !S finesse? Whether West took his !SK right then or later you would go down. You could never reach dummy again.

Auction: 1H | pass 2H pass 4H | pass pass pass |
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 4!H]
You have a nice hand, but 20 points is not strong enough to open 2!C. 
So you open 1!H. Partner raises to 2!H. What do you bid now? [BID pass]
Partner's raise to 2!H shows 6-10 points. You figure that should be enough for game but even if he has the full T you are not in slam range. So you bid the game. 
South plays 4!H. West leads !SA, then switches to !H2.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 2 : !H 0 : !D 1 : !C 1 : Total = 4
It's a good thing you stopped at game - partner's hand is about as bad as it could be.
The PLAN turns out simple. You can't avoid either of the three black losers so you must eliminate the !D loser. You can ruff it in dummy. Just to be safe you pull one more round of trumps, then play !DA, !DK and !D5, ruffing in dummy. You will eventually get to your hand (with a !S or a !C ruff) and pull the last trump.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
Only a real beginner would have pulled all the trumps and not been able to ruff that !D.

Auction: pass 1C | pass 1D pass 1NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID pass]
With 16 points as Responder you are not quite strong enough for a jump-shift to 2 !D. That requires at least 17 points. A jump to 3NT fits the point range (16-18) but promises a stopper in all unbid suits. So instead you bid 1!D, knowing partner is forced to keep the bidding alive. He now replies 1NT. What is your next bid? [BID pass]
Until now you were thinking the hand might end up in a slam. Now, with partner's minimum rebid, you happily say 3NT which partner passes.
North would play 3NT. 
Click [ROTATE]

South plays 3NT. West leads the !SQ. East puts on the !SK.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Winners: !S 1 : !H 2 : !D 5 : !C 0 : Total = 8
Let's say you hold up on the first !S, hoping they switch suits. HA! They aren't about to switch suits and they drive out your !SA at trick 2. That actually clears the situation up and makes this plan pretty simple to make.
You have taken 1 !S, and you will surely make 5 !Ds. Despite the solidity of those !Cs you dare not try to win a !C trick, because the defenders will pounce on that first !C and then win a bunch of !S tricks. 
So that makes it clear that you need 3 !H tricks, and there's only one way to get them. After taking your five !D tricks, play a !H to the !HK, then a !H back, finessing the !HJ. Half of the time you will make this contract, the other half of the time they will bury you with !Ss.

[PLAY N:ST,N:S6,N:S3,N:HA,N:HT,N:H7,N:H5,N:H4,N:DA,N:DJ,N:D2,N:CA,N:CK,S:S9,S:S5,S:S2,S:HK,S:HQ,S:H9,S:H2,S:DK,S:DQ,S:D8,S:D3,S:CJ,S:C7]
South plays 4!H. The defense takes the first three !S tricks, then switches to a !C.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 3 : !H ?? : !D 0 : !C 0 : Total = 3+??
With no more outside losers your task is very very simple:DO NOT LOSE A TRUMP TRICK.
There is no problem if trumps split 2-2 or 3-1, so you can put your mind to 4-0 splits only. If West holds !H J 8 6 3 then it won't matter whether your first trump play is !HA or !HK, you will still be able to finesse the !HJ. But if East holds !H J 8 6 3 it is vital that you first play either the !HK or !HQ. If you start with the !HA you will have lost your finesse position. The general rule is to first play a high trump from the hand that has two. That preserves a finesse through either defender's !H J x x x.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
Next visualize the situation if your first play was the !HK. West would show out and you would play the !HQ, then a small !H finessing your !HT. 
Finally visualize the situation if your first play was the !HK and it was East who showed out. You would play a small !H to your !HA, then lead a !H toward dummy finessing with the !H9.
Using the correct Plan guarantees the contract however !Hs split.

Auction: 1C pass 1S | pass 2S pass 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1!S]
Partner has opened and you have 14 points. You know you belong in game but there is no need to jump and use up bidding space. You respond 1!S.
Partner now bids 2!S. What do you bid next? [BID 4!S]
You know you should be in game and now you know the suit. You bid 4!S.
South plays 4!S. The defense quickly takes three !H tricks, then switches to a !D.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 0? : !H 3 : !D 0 : !C 0 : Total = 3?
This Deal is VERY similar to Deal 9 in that you are only worried about a 4-0 trump split. The reason that it shows up right here is to point out the difference between J 8 6 3 and J T 6 3.
If East holds !S J T 6 3 then there is nothing you can do about it - you will go down. If you lead a !S from dummy he will "split his honors" by playing the !ST. This will force your !SA and he can just sit back and wait for his !SJ to make a trick.
But if it is West with !S J T 6 3 you can keep him from winning a !S trick, IF YOUR FIRST !S PLAY IS THE !SA. East shows out and you play a small !S toward dummy's !S K Q 9. If West plays low you insert the !S9, if he plays one of his honors you win it, then return to your hand and finesse him out of the other honor.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
If your first !S was !SK or !SQ then it would be too late.
Click NEXT to see an alternate deal. [NEXT]
To summarize: If you are missing J x x x your first play should be from the hand with two honors. Then you will  be able to finesse in either direction. If you are missing J T x x your first play should be honor from the hand with only one. This will leave you with a double-finesse position in one direction. If the other defender has the trumps there is nothing you can do.

Auction: pass 1NT | pass 2NT pass 3NT | pass pass pass |
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1NT]
Aces and Spaces is the description you often hear about this hand. But the REAL description is 16 points, balanced. So you open 1NT. Partner replies 2NT. What do you bid now? [BID 3NT]
Partner is INVITING you to bid 3NT. If you have 17 points you should bid 3NT. If you have 15 points you should pass.
With 16 points you must make a judgement. This one is actually easy, despite the negative sound of "Aces and Spaces". In strength terms Aces are undervalued. Instead of being worth 4 points they are actually worth about 4.3 points. So you really do have a 17 point hand, and you bid 3NT.
South plays 3NT. West leads the !C2.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Winner count: !S 2 : !H 1 : !D 2 : !C 1 : Total = 6
Wow. Things do look a little Acey/Spacey. If the !Ds are 3-2, which is likely, you can establish 2 tricks there. You need one more and the best hope is the !CQ. There is a very good chance that West led from the !CK. So with a brief prayer to Brigidda (the Goddess of Bridge) you put up the !CQ. It wins the trick.
Now you are on cruise-control. Play a !D to the !DA. Play another !D back to dummy's !DK (both defenders follow). Now a third !D sets up the rest of the suit.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]

Auction: 1NT | pass 2C pass 2S | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 2!C]
Despite the great !C suit, you have a 4-card Major. It is your duty to first seek an 8-card Major fit, so you bid 2!C (Stayman). Partner replies 2!S. What do you bid? [BID 3NT]
Well, that wasn't the Major suit you were hoping for.
But with 11 points you have enough for game, so you bid 3NT.
North would play 3NT.
Click [ROTATE]
[PLAY N:SA,N:SK,N:S7,N:S2,N:HA,N:H8,N:H3,N:DA,N:DQ,N:D7,N:D2,N:C6,N:C2,S:S8,S:S5,S:HJ,S:H7,S:H6,S:H2,S:D8,S:D3,S:CA,S:CK,S:CQ,S:C4,S:C3]
South plays 3NT. West leads !DJ, East plays !DK.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Winners: !S 2 : !H 1 : !D 2 : !C 3 : Total = 8
Thanks to the opening lead you get an extra !D winner. Well, since the finesse would have worked it really isn't extra, it's just nice to know about it early. You need to find one more winner and the !C suit beckons. A 3-3 split would be very nice, but a 4-2 is more likely. Even with a 4-2 split you can still make your fifth !C good - but you must be careful with entries.
Since you have no immediate problem in any suit you can afford to give up the lead. So you play the !C2 from your hand and the !C3 from dummy. In other words, you duck a !C. Somebody will win this trick cheaply and no doubt play another !D. You don't mind at all - you win the !DQ, the !S A K, the !HA and dummy's !C A K Q 4, all of which are good.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
If you played a high !C first you would never have an entry back to dummy. You would have been forced to try to get there with the !HJ but as you can see, that wouldn't work.
If you had just played the !Cs from the top you would have made an overtrick when they split 3-3, but gone down when they split 4-2. Making an overtrick about 40% of the time is a high price to pay for going down the other 60%.

Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1NT]
This is awkward. With 8 points you must respond, but you cannot bid a new suit at the 2-level without 11 or more. Although you are far from balanced you must say 1NT.
You might as well not have worried. Partner jumps to 4!S and you pass.
North would play 4!S.
Click [ROTATE]
[PLAY N:SA,N:SJ,N:ST,N:S7,N:S5,N:S4,N:S2,N:D7,N:D5,N:CA,N:CK,N:CJ,N:CT,S:HT,S:H9,S:H6,S:H5,S:DA,S:DT,S:D9,S:D6,S:D4,S:D3,S:CQ,S:C7,S:C2]
South plays 4!S. West leads the !HK.

Losers: !S ? : !H 0 : !D 1 : !C 0 : Total = ?
That 1 !D loser is definite. So instead of guessing how many !S losers you have, just approach it from the viewpoint that you can afford 2 but not 3.
If the missing !Ss split 3-3 then your life is easy. You play !SA, then any !S. Win their return and play any !S. The defense can win two !Ss but no more.
It's when the !Ss are splitting 4-2 that you must be careful. If somebody has !S K Q 9 3 for example you will go down. The one important distribution to guard against is a doubleton honor in one hand. In this case your second !S play must be a LOW !S. When this drives out one honor your !S J T can insure that only one more trick is lost.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
But if your second !S play is a small !S East will win the !SK and you will be left with the !S J T to deal with West's !S Q 9, holding him to just one more trick.

Auction: 1NT | pass 3H pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis: You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. You and partner do NOT play Jacoby Transfer Bids. [BID 3!H] With 11 points you know you want to reach game since partner has at least 15. However, you aren't sure at this point just which game to reach. If you knew partner held 3!Hs you'd choose 4!H since you would have an 8-card Major fit. On the other hand, if you knew partner had only a doubleton !H you would choose 3NT, which would probably be better. So you jump to 3!H. This bid tells partner to "Pick a Game". He picks 3NT. North would play 3NT. Click [ROTATE] [PLAY N:SK,N:S6,N:S3,N:HQ,N:HJ,N:DA,N:DK,N:D4,N:D2,N:CA,N:CT,N:C6,N:C4,S:SA,S:S7,S:S4,S:HK,S:HT,S:H9,S:H5,S:H3,S:DJ,S:D5,S:D3,S:CQ,S:C3] South plays 3NT. West leads the !SJ. Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT] Winner count: !S 2 : !H 0 : !D 2 : !C 1 : Total = 5 Although the !D and !C suits offer the possibility for creating a winner it is evident that you really need to bring in the !Hs. By driving out the !HA you will establish the 4 winners that you need. The problem is that when you play !HQ then !HJ a good defender will hold up his !HA. You could get to dummy with the !SA and continue !Hs, but you would no longer have a sure entry to get back to those winners. There is an almost foolproof plan. Win the first trick with your !SK (saving dummy's !SA). Lead !HQ, then !HJ, OVERTAKING WITH DUMMY'S !HK. Now continue the !HT driving out the !HA. You will be able to reach the !H tricks with the !SA. Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT] [RESET]

Auction: 1H | 1S 2H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1!H]
You may not have had a problem with this opening bid, but be assured that many would. The hand meets all the requirements for an opening 1NT bid, balanced distribution and 16 points. So lots of good players would open 1NT. However, there is the question of the 5-card Major. Another group of good players don't open 1NT when their hand contains a 5-card Major.
So let us agree that either could be right and say that you chose 1!H. West overcalls 1!S, partner says 2!H and you pass.
South plays 2!H. West leads the !SK.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 2 : !H 2 : !D 0 : !C 2 : Total = 6
You might get lucky in the trump suit and only lose one trick, but you can't count on it. Dummy's !D suit has two extra winners, but there is the problem of transportation. By the time you get to enjoy those two winners you might have already lost six tricks.
One thing should be crystal clear. If you now lead a trump the defenders will win and cash 2 !Ss. You can avoid this by waiting on the trumps and playing !DK, then overtake the !DJ with dummy's !DQ. Then play !DA and discard a !S. Now from dummy you can lead a !H and perhaps play your !HK but even if it loses you will still make the contract.
Clickfor the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
Make sure you visualize how the play would have gone if you had played a trump to the second trick. When you see clearly the bad things that are likely to happen you will look harder for a remedy. When confronted with a hand such as this many beginning (or careless) players just automatically start trying to pull trumps. And many times they go down on hands that could have been made.

But you have trump control and can get in again and reach dummy with a ruff to continue !Cs. All West can do is get his one more trump.

This hand is much rarer - leaving TWO master trumps out. But you can see that it is the correct technique.

Auction: pass 1C | pass 1S pass 2NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1!C]
This sure looks like an opening 1NT hand, except for one little thing - it is too strong. Make sure you open 1NT ONLY with hands containing 15-17 points. For this one you open 1!C. Partner responds 1!S. What do you bid next? [BID 2NT]
Do not support partner's Major suit response with only 3 cards. It is good to raise partner's Major suit OPENING with 3 trumps because he guarantees a 5-card suit. As a RESPONSE he only promises a 4-card suit, so you should have 4 in the suit to give immediate support.
In fact you have a perfect bid. With a balanced hand and 18-19 points you open 1 of a suit, then jump in Notrump. Holding 18 points you bid 2NT and partner raises to 3NT.
South plays 3NT. West leads the !H5. East plays the !HQ.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Winner count: !S 2 : !H 1 : !D 0 : !C 4 : Total = 7
You need 2 more winners and they will come from the !D suit once you have forced out the !DA. There is a problem though. When the opponents get the lead with the !DA they might cash 4 !H tricks. Of course if it is East who wins the !DA and if he doesn't have a !H to play then all will be well. So you don't take your !HA on the first trick, nor do you take it on the second trick. At trick 3 you have no choice so you win your !HA. 
Now you can take your 4 !C tricks if you like. Then lead a !D honor. If they don't take their !DA on this trick you play another !D honor. One of the defenders will win this trick. If it is East you will make your contract, if it is West you will go down.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
Notice that if West was the one who had the !DA then you would go down despite your hold-up play. This PLAN is not a guarantee - but if you follow it you will make the contract 50% of the time. If you don't follow it you will make the contract 0% of the time.

You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1!H]

Partner raises to 4!H and everyone passes.
South plays 4!H. West leads the !DA and the defense wins two high !Ds then switches to a trump.

The two !D losers are already lost, so you must eliminate a !C loser. If West has the !CK then a simple finesse will win the day. That would be a 50% chance, right? WRONG! That would be a 0% chance. You and partner hold 23 HCP. West has already produced 4 HCP with the !DA, and if he had 3 more that would mean East opened with only 10 points. Very doubtful.
So face it, East has the !CK.
However, dummy has some nice !S cards. So you pull the last trump, play your !S3 to dummy's !SA, then lead the !SQ. If East puts on his !SK (which you know he must have) you ruff it. Then enter dummy with a !D ruff and discard the small !C on the good !SJ. If East doesn't play his !SK you discard your  !C loser immediately.
Clickfor the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
This was a perfect example. After the opening lead it was easy to deduce that all the rest of the high cards had to be in the East hand.

Win the !DA in dummy. Play the !HQ to the !HA and ruff the !HT with dummy's !S8. Play the !S5 to your !SA and ruff the !HJ with dummy's !S9.
Return to your hand with a !C and pull another round of trumps with your !SK. Leaving the master trump out start playing !C winners. Someone may ruff with their master trump but that's the only trick they will get.

With 13 points and 4 of partner's minor suit you may be tempted to say 2NT or 3!D. Both these temptations should be resisted - your first obligation is to show a 4-card Major if you have one. As poor as the suit is, you still respond 1!S. 
Partner comes back with 1NT. What do you bid now? (Hint: don't rebid the !Ss.) [BID pass]

You need two more winners and you can almost surely get them in !Ds. In fact, if the suit splits 2-2 you could actually get three more winners. But the danger here is that if they DON'T split 2-2 and if East happens to win the third !D he might lead a !S. And that might lead to disaster!
Instead, you allow for the possibility that !Ds may not split evenly and you make sure East (the Danger hand) doesn't get the lead. Win the !HK in dummy. Play the !DA, (which happens to draw the !DJ from West), then play a small !D and finesse with the !D9. If West can win the trick then the !Ds have split 2-2 and your other 3 !Ds are good. Most importantly though, West cannot lead a !S without giving you a trick with your !SK. If the finesse works, you make 5 !D tricks.

Here the bad thing would be for East to get the lead and play a !S. In this case you were able to avoid the bad situation by playing a suit differently than you might have done if there were no danger.

Auction: pass 2C | pass 2D pass 2S | pass 2NT pass 3S | pass 4S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 2!C]
With 22 points you are too strong to open with a 1-bid.
You start with a forcing 2!C, partner responds 2!D. This is a "waiting" bid, showing 0-7 points. What do you bid now? [BID 2!S]
No need to jump. If you say anything other than 2NT partner is forced to bid again.
You bid 2!S and it is partner who says 2NT. What do you bid now?
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Always keep in mind that you don't need to bid the same values twice. Partner knows that you have 22 or more points and knows that you have a good !S suit. So all you do at this point is rebid your !Ss to show that it is a 6-card suit.
You bid 3!S and partner raises you to game.
South plays 4!S. West leads the !HQ.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 1? : !H 1 : !D 2 : !C 0 : Total = 4?
That question mark means that if !Ss don't split 3-2 you will have 2 losers in which case the !D finesse will just have to work. However, the 3-2 split will probably occur, so you make your PLAN based on that.
Unless West is a complete moron dummy's !HK is a goner no matter what you do. So you duck, then ruff the !HJ continuation. Next you play !SA, !SK, both defenders following. At this point one defender still holds the master !SQ and you must decide whether to leave it outstanding or force them to play it. 
When dummy has a side suit you want to run but no outside entries it usually pays to drive out the master trump. So you play another !S and East wins the !SQ. He now plays a !D and you hopefully play the !DQ, but West takes the !DK and plays another !D. You are now in control. Win the !DA and play 4 rounds of !Cs, discarding your !D loser.

You would have played !CA, !C K, then a small !C to dummy's !CJ. East would ruff this with his !SQ and you would never be able to reach dummy's !CJ. You would be down 1, losing 1 !S, 1 !H and 2 !Ds.

Auction: 1C pass 1S | pass 2S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1!S]
There are three legitimate choices, 1!D, 1!S or 1NT.
You should always show a Major suit if you can, even a poor one like this.

Partner has a minimum opener. You pass in a flash.

If !Ss split 3-2 you can hold your losers in the suit to 3 as long as the defenders don't get a ruff. But if the defender with a doubleton trump happened to get a ruff then your trump losers would go to 4. You should lead trumps to try to prevent this.
So win the !DA and lead a !S. West will win and play 3 high !Ds. You ruff the third one in dummy. East may over-ruff, and if he does you can hope that he was the defender who started with 3 trumps. Suppose East now leads a !H. You win in your hand and play another trump, happily observing the !SK and !SA both fall. You win the rest of the tricks, discarding your !H loser on dummy's third !C.

What do you bid now? [BID 3NT]
You now need to make a jump bid. You MIGHT jump to 4!C but that would bypass what is probably your best game. Instead you just jump to 3NT. Partner doesn't HAVE to pass, but he does.

You have a LOT of points - but only 8 tricks. And you know that if you lose the lead there will be a deluge of !Hs on the table. !Cs is your best suit, and if the finesse works you will make 6. Of course if it fails you will go down. But there is one thing you should do before you stake everything on a 50% finesse. You should play 3 rounds of !Ds. If they split 3-3 you will have found your ninth trick and you won't risk the !C finesse.

[RESET]
The best thing about this plan is that when you test the !Ds, if it turns out they do not split 3-3 you can still try the !C finesse.

You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1!S]
Well, you're pretty sure you have a !C fit. But before you show partner your fine !C support you have an obligation to show a 4-card Major.
You respond 1!S, partner jumps to 3!S. What do you bid? [BID 4!S]
Your hand revalues to 11 or 12 points so you should bid game. 5!C requires 11 tricks and 4!S only T tricks. You bid 4!S.

Do you change your Plan? Click? [NEXT]
Well, East may be false-carding. He may also have the !SQ for example. But if you decide to play another trump and it turns out he was NOT false-carding you will be dead in the water. West will take his three trump tricks and some !Hs. Many !Hs.
So don't take the chance. Abandon trumps and start playing !C winners. Let West take the three trumps whenever he wants to. You will not lose control of the hand and will make your T tricks.

Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1!S]
You have an easy 1!S opening bid.
But West overcalls 2!D and partner bids 3!D.
What do you bid next? [BID 4!S]
You should be certain to have a partnership agreement on the meaning of a cue-bid after an overcall.
Most good players use it to show support for opener's suit and at least 11 points. In other words, a hand with which you would have made a limit-raise or better.
So you bid the !S game.
South plays 4!S. West leads the !DA, then !DK, then !DJ. East discards on the second !D and ruffs the third one with the !ST.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]

The loser count looks a little messy - that's because of the circumstances. If you could have just played three rounds of !Ss you would probably have had 0 losers, and if you ruff this !D you will have only 2 !D losers, but maybe create a !S loser.
But though the loser count is confused your plan should not be. You DO NOT over-ruff the !ST. Instead you discard your one !H loser (a loser-on-loser play). East can have this trick but whatever he returns you will win, pull trumps in THREE rounds if necessary, and take the rest of the tricks.

But did you notice that West made a bad play? He should have cashed his !HA before he led the third !D for his partner to ruff. Then when his partner ruffed with the !ST your goose would have been cooked.

Auction: 1C | pass 1H pass 1S | pass 3S pass 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1!H]
There is an excellent bidding guideline which tells you how to respond with two 4-card Majors. You bid them "up-the-line". That means you bid 1!H.
Partner's rebid is 1!S. What do you bid? [BID 3!S]
This hand shows why responder should bid "up-the-line". Partner can now show a 4-card !S suit at the 1-level. Imagine the suits reversed - you first respond with 1!S. If partner wanted to show a !H suit he would have to go to the 2-level, and he might not have the strength to do so.
Back to the actual situation. Over partner's 1!S bid you jump to 3!S. This jump shows about 11-12 points and good !S support (4 cards). In case you thought this showed 13 or more points that wouldn't be logical. If you had 13 points and 4 !Ss you would jump all the way to game. So 3!S is invitational. Partner accepts the invitation.
North would play 4!S.

Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1NT]
You have 15 points and you have a balanced distribution. You should open 1NT. It is true that you do not have !Cs stopped, but you are not required to have a stopper in all the suits to open 1NT. Partner jumps to 3NT and you pass.
South plays 3NT. West leads the !HQ.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Winner count: !S 1 : !H 2 : !D 1 : !C 2 : Total = 6
In many Notrump hands it is good to hold up to disrupt the defender's communications. In this hand you have a double-stopper in !Hs but only a single stop in !Ss and !Ds so win the first trick.
You need 3 more tricks from the !C suit. As long as the !Cs split 3-2, which is very likely, you can set up the tricks you need. BUT, if you just play !CA !CK and then a small one you'll be sorry. Those extra three !Cs will be established as winners but you will have no entry to them.
Instead, you play your !C4 to the second trick and also play a low card from dummy. This is called Ducking the trick. East/West will certainly win that trick, but you are in control. You can win whatever suit they play and you still have that !C7 to reach dummy's solid !Cs.

Auction: pass 1C | pass 3C pass 5C | pass pass pass

Is there any doubt? Although you only have 11 HCP your 6-card suit adds 2 more. And with 13 points you should always open. So you open 1!C. 
Partner responds 3!C. What do you bid? [BID 5!C]
With the !C fit your hand is now revalued to 15 points. But it's still a close thing. You may be able to make 5!C or you may not.

The two black Aces aren't going away so if you are to make this contract you must do something about your !D loser. And the only likely place to put it is on dummy's !SK. If West has the !SA, you can lead up to the !SK and make a winner out of it.
Suppose you win the !DQ in dummy and play a !C. Somebody will win the !CA and play another !D. You win this and lead toward the !SK. No good. West jumps up with his !SA and sets you with a !D winner.

Win the !D in your hand and immediately play the !S9. If West doesn't take his !SA he'll never get it, so assume he goes up. Now he leads !DJ but you win, get to dummy with the !HK and play the !SK, discarding the !D loser.

Auction: pass 1H | pass 3H pass 4NT | pass 5C pass 5H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1!H]
You have a very good hand. But not good enough to open 2!C, so you open 1!H.
Partner jumps to 3!H. What do you bid? [BID 4NT]
This is close. Partner has 11 or 12 points and good !H support. Your hand revalues to 21 points. You might have a slam. You decide to try for it and bid 4NT. Partner replies 5!C showing no Aces. So much for the slam. You bid 5!H.
South plays 5!H. West leads the !ST. You put on dummy's !SJ, East plays the !SK and you win the !SA.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 1 : !H 1 : !D 0 : !C 1 : Total = 3
You cannot avoid losing either of the two Aces. So therefore you must do something about the !S loser. And the only thing you can do with it is to discard it on one of dummy's !Cs.
Be careful. If you lead a trump now a defender will take the Ace and play another !S, exposing your loser while the !CA is still out. You must set up the !C first. So at trick 2 play your !C to dummy's !CQ. A defender may win this and play a !S, but you win the !SQ and play the !CK, discarding your !S loser. Now you switch to trumps.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
Imagine what the defense will do if you lead a round of trumps. Then imagine what they will do if you play a different suit instead.

Auction: 1D | pass 2D pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1!D]
With 19 points you are too strong to open 1NT so you open 1!D. Partner responds 2!D. What do you bid? [BID 3NT]
Perhaps you can make 5!D. But 9 tricks are easier than 11  so you bid 3NT. Notice that there was no reason to "show" your !S suit. If partner held 4 !Ss he would not have bid 2!D. 
South plays 3NT. West leads the !HQ.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Winners: !S 1 : !H 2 : !D 1 : !C 3 : Total = 7
You can create one winner in !Ds if they split 3-2, but too late, the defense would have set up their !Hs. So you must get 2 more !S tricks.
This is one of the most misplayed positions in bridge. The usual approach is to lead the !SQ, hoping that West holds the !SK. But this can't succeed. If West does hold the !SK he will cover, either this trick or the !SJ, and someone's !ST will become a winner. Of course if East has the !SK then the finesse will fail, along with your chance of 2 more winners.
The correct way to play for 2 more tricks is to hope EAST has the !SK and lead twice toward your !S Q J. So win the first trick, play !S4 to dummy's !SA. Lead the !S3 toward your hand, playing the !SJ if East plays low. (Of course if East ever plays the !SK he gives you two winners immediately.) When the !SJ wins, return to dummy with the !DA and lead the !S6 toward your !SQ.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]

Auction: 1NT pass 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 4!S]
HE WHO KNOWS, GOESYou KNOW your side has 26-28 points. You KNOW your side has 8 or more !Ss. You GO to 4!S.
South plays 4!S. West leads the !DJ.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 2/3 : !H 0 : !D 1 : !C 0 : Total = 3/4
You are definitely going to lose the !DA and the !S A K. Therefore you must plan to avoid losing a third !S.
You should lead UP TO your honor cards. Cover the !DJ and lose to East's !DA. Win his return (probably another !D) in dummy. Lead a small !S to your !SJ. West wins with an honor and probably plays the !DT. Ruff it, lead a !C to dummy and lead the last !S. If East plays the other high honor you play low. If East plays low you guess whether to play the !SK, or !ST. Your best play is to assume the two honors were split and play the !SQ.
Clickfor the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
Now click for an alternate possible. [BID ]
You might think that West is just as likely to have held an original doubleton !S A K as doubleton !S A T, and that playing the !S9 would be as good a play as !SQ.
This is untrue for a very classy-named reason - The Principle of Restricted Choice. You may not even believe it when you read it, but it's mathematically sound. If West were dealt an original !S A K, he would have been just as likely to win with the !SK as with the !SA. The fact that he actually won the !SA makes it less likely that he also holds the !SK.

Auction: 1D pass 1S | pass 2S pass 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1!S]
A jump to 2NT would not be a terrible bid. But it is more important to show your 4-card Major.
So you bid 1!S instead. Partner raises to 2!S.
What do you bid next? [BID 4!S]
It's another case of HE WHO KNOWS, GOES. You know you have at least 26 points and 8 !Ss. Of course you trust that partner would not raise a suit you bid as responder with only 3 trumps. So you bid 4!S.
South plays 4!S. West leads the !HK. The defense takes the first three !H tricks, then switch to a !C.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S ? : !H 3 : !D 0 : !C 0 : Total = 3?
It kinda makes you wish you'd bid 2NT after all doesn't it?
At least the picture is clear. Very clear. You have no wiggle room left so you must bring in the !Ss without losing a trick. So West MUST have the !SK. Therefore you assume West does hold the !SK. 
Suppose you lead the !SQ. West will play his !SK and force you to play dummy's !SA. Then one of the defenders will win the third !S with the !ST or !S9.
No, you only have one chance to make this contract - West must hold a doubleton !S K x. So you lead a SMALL !S from your hand and finesse dummy's !SJ. Then play the !SA, dropping West's !SK, then pull the last trump with the !SQ.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
Since you would only have one more honor you'd be bound to lose a trick.

Auction: 1NT | 2S 2NT pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1NT]
With 17 points and a balanced hand you naturally open 1NT. West overcalls 2!S. Your partner then bids 2NT. What do you bid now? [BID 3NT]
Your partner invited you to bid 3NT if you had 17 points, and you have 17 points. You trust your partner so you bid 3NT.
South plays 3NT. West leads the !SQ.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Winner count: !S 2 : !H 0 : !D 0 : !C 2 : Total = 4
This looks scary. Needing 5 more tricks means you are going to have to establish BOTH red suits. And with only two !S stoppers you have to hope West doesn't have both red Aces. If he does, you're down, so just assume that he only has one of them. Now if you can just figure out which Ace West has you can establish that suit first.
But you don't have to guess, there is a better way. West overcalled at the 2-level with a Queen-high suit and one outside Ace. THAT is bold. Surely he has at least a 6-card suit to justify that overcall. If so, then a simple hold-up will be worthwhile. So you let West hold the first trick, and when he leads another !S you win the !SK in your hand. If West has a 6-card suit East is now void of !Ss.
Play !Ds to drive out the !DA. If East has it he will not have another !S to force you with. If West has it he can force out your last !S, but then won't have the !HA for an entry. However the Aces are split - as long as West doesn't have both - you will establish 9 tricks.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
With the holdup it didn't matter which red suit you established first.

Auction: 2S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID pass]
Don't even think twice. Just pass and wonder why the opponents aren't bidding.
North would play 2!S.
Click [ROTATE]

South plays 2!S. West leads !HA, then !HK.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 1/2 : !H 1 : !D 0 : !C 3 : Total = 5/6
If West has both !CA and !CK you could save yourself 1 !C loser, but the odds are about 3 to 1 against that. Your best chance of making this contract is just to hold your !S losers to 1. With an expected 3-2 split there will not be a problem, but you might as well take extra pains if you can do so without risk.
So after you ruff the !HK you do NOT play the !SK. Instead you play a !D to dummy and lead a !S toward your honors. Your extra pains pay off when East plays the !SA, which was a singleton.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
It costs nothing to make a careful play. Most of the time it doesn't matter, but every now and again it pays off in a contract that couldn't be made without the careful play.

Auction: 3H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID pass]
You really really want to say 3!S. Here are three good reasons you shouldn't.
You have 9 !Hs between you. You may have only 7 !Ss. If you bid 3!S partner may bid again. You haven't been doubled.
North would play 3!H.
Click [ROTATE]
[PLAY N:S7,N:HA,N:HJ,N:H9,N:H8,N:H7,N:H5,N:H4,N:D8,N:CK,N:CT,N:C6,N:C3,S:SA,S:SK,S:S9,S:S8,S:S6,S:S5,S:S3,S:H6,S:H2,S:DQ,S:D4,S:C5,S:C2]
South plays 3!H. West leads the !SQ.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
It turns out there was a fourth reason not to bid 3!S - the opponents might lead the suit.
Losers: !S 0 : !H 1/2 : !D 1 : !C 4 : Total = 6/7
The !S lead is about the best thing that could have happened to you. You win with dummy's !SA and play !SK, discarding your !D. You then lead a small !C, covering anything East plays. You'd like to ruff a !C if you can, but if they play trumps to stop you then you'd like the trump play to come from West. West leads the !H3, East plays the !HK, and you win with the !HA. You play a small !C. If the defender who wins the !C doesn't play another trump then you can ruff your third !C in dummy. If the defender DOES play a trump, then you lose only one trump trick. You end up going down 1, which is pretty good.

Auction: 1D pass 2NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 2NT]
You have three reasonable choices. You could bid 2!C, you could jump to 3!D, or you could jump to 2NT. 
While all are reasonable, the jump to 2NT stands out as the most constructive by far. Partner bids 3NT and you pass.
South plays 3NT. West leads the !HJ.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Winner count: !S 1 : !H 3 : !D 0 : !C 3 : Total = 7
If West has the !SK then a finesse will gain you the two winners you need. However, if East has the !SK then the finesse will gain you just one winner and you will be hoping for a  3-3 !C split for the other. While this is a possible Plan, there is a far better one.
Rather than chance the !S finesse, you should immediately start establishing your !Ds. This has the advantage of not giving the defense any NEW winners - they were always going to get their two high !Ds. So win the !HA and play the !DT. Somebody will take this and probably continue with a !H. Take the !HQ and play the !DQ. Somebody will take this and probably continue with a !H. Take the !HK and then the rest of your winners. Maybe the !Cs will split 3-3 and give you an overtrick. And if you have assured the contract you MIGHT even try the !S finesse.
Clickfor the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
East would have won and played a !H, removing your second stopper. When !Cs did not split 3-3 you would have been forced to try a !D. East would win his !DK and drive out the last !H stopper. Then West would be able to take the !DA plus his established !Hs.

Auction: 1NT pass 2C | pass 2D pass 2H | pass 3H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 2!C]
Because you have an invitational hand with a 4-card Major (!Ss) you use Stayman.
After your 2!C bid partner says 2!D.
What do you bid next? [BID 2!H]
Partner does not have 4 (!Ss) so you have no 8-card fit there. However, he might have 3 !Hs, so you now bid 2!H. Partner will understand you are showing a 5-card suit.
Partner bids 3!H. What do you say? [BID pass]
This could go either way. You started out with 9 points, but perhaps you could revalue your hand upward after you find the fit. The problem with that is those two doubletons are in the long-trump hand, and taking ruffs in the long-trump hand doesn't usually add tricks. You take the conservative route and pass.
South plays 3!H. West leads the !CJ.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 2 : !H 2 : !D 1 : !C 1 : Total = 6
You may be able to ruff 1 !S in dummy, and discard another on a long !D. And you hope to keep your trump losers to 1.
Start by covering the !CJ to set up a sure !C trick. East wins the !CA and returns a !C, won by dummy's !CK. It looks better to start the trumps from your side, so play a !D toward your !DK. West wins and plays a !C, which you ruff. Now lead a !H, playing the !HK if West plays low. Assume this wins the trick. Lead a !H back, finessing the !H9 since you think West must hold the !HA. He does hold it, and takes it right now. West leads a !S. You win the !SA in dummy, play the !S7 to your !SK, and ruff a !S with dummy's last trump. Now lead dummy's !D Q J, discarding a !S on the last one. You have only good trumps left.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]

Auction: pass 1D | pass 1H pass 2NT | pass 3D pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1!D]
You have 19 points, too much for 1NT. With two 4-card minors you should open 1!D, regardless of strength. Partner responds 1!H. What do you bid next? [BID 2NT]
Partner's !H bid makes you very happy. It also makes your rebid a snap. With 19 points and a balanced hand you jump to 2NT.
Partner now surprises you a little by saying 3!D.
What is your next bid? [BID 3NT]
For partner to take you out of Notrump he must have a distributional hand, probably with a singleton or void in one of the black suits. You have to make the choice between passing, bidding 4!D or 5!D, or bidding 3NT.
While any of those choices might turn out best, the fact that most of your strength is in the black suits should help you decide on 3NT.
South plays 3NT. West leads the !S5. East plays the !S9.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Winner count: !S 2 : !H 0 : !D 2 : !C 4? : Total = 8?
Those 4 !C winners assume a 3-2 split. Since that is going to be the first suit you play you will find out soon enough.
You win the !SQ. Play the !CK, then the !CT (trying to tempt a cover). Go up with the !CQ and East follows with the !CJ so you do have 4 !C tricks. Take your other two !Cs right now.
You are now at the crossroads. For your ninth trick should you try the !D finesse or should you establish a !H. It's a no-brainer. If you finesse a !D and it loses to East's !DQ a !S will come back, knocking out your last stopper. Then, if the !Ds fail to split 3-2 you will be short one winner and it will be too late to set up the !H. So ignore the finesse and set up a !H for your guaranteed nine tricks.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
East would win and play a !S, and whether you ducked this one or not your last stopper would soon be removed. When !Ds failed to split 3-2 you would have been forced to try a !H. West would win his !HA and set you with !Ss.
Correctly played you would lead a !H honor to establish one trick in the suit and easily make the game with 2 !Ss, 1 !H, 2 !Ds and 4 !Cs.

Auction: 1S | pass 1NT pass 3S | pass 4S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1!S]
An easy one. You bid 1!S. Partner responds 1NT.
What is your next bid? [BID 3!S]
You're going to rebid your 6-card !S suit, but how high? The usual guideline is to bid 2!S with 13-15 points, but jump to 3!S with 16-18 points. You come in just over the line so you bid 3!S. Partner puts it in game.
South plays 4!S. West leads the !HQ, East playing !H9.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 0 : !H 1 : !D 1 : !C 2 : Total = 4
You must eliminate one loser and the easiest one will be the !H which you can ruff in dummy. However, East's !H9 looks a little ominous, particularly since West apparently has some length in the suit. Presumably you played the !HA on the first trick. Next lead the !H6 from dummy, hoping East can't (or doesn't) ruff. He plays the !H2. Win the !HK and play your !H 4, ruffing with dummy's !SQ. East is out of !Hs, but can't over-ruff. Now pull trumps and set up one !C trick. You lose 2 !Cs and a !D, just as expected.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]

Auction: 1D dbl pass 2D | pass 2H pass 2S | pass 4S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 2!D]
When responding to a takeout double use these guidelines:0-8 points: bid a suit cheaply9-11 points: bid a suit with a jump12 or more points: cue-bid the opponent's suit
With 13 points you cue-bid 2!D. Partner says 2!H.
What do you bid now? [BID 2!S]
You are forced to game, now you must find a suit. Partner suggested !Hs, you suggest !Ss. Partner agrees !Ss and bids the game.
South plays 4!S. West leads !DA, !DK, !DQ. East plays !D8 then !D2.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 0 : !H 0 : !D 3 : !C 1 : Total = 4
If you could ruff that !D then one of your !D losers would be eliminated - if East didn't over-ruff. But you know that East is going to over-ruff. So don't ruff it, discard dummy's !C6 instead. Later you can ruff your !C loser in dummy.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]

Auction: pass 1D | pass 2C pass 2NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1!D]
You have 13 points so you will definitely open the bidding. You don't open with a 4-card Major and you don't open with a 2-card !C suit. So this is the one distribution where you open a 3-card !D suit. Partner responds 2!C and it is your bid. [BID 2NT]
Be very careful! You are tempted to now bid 2!H or 2!S. Don't give in to the temptation. That would be a REVERSE - bidding a second, higher-ranking suit at the 2-level. You should have at least 16 points to reverse. Besides, if you trust partner you don't need to bid either of those suits anyway. If he had a 4-card Major he probably would have shown it on his first bid. No, your next bid is clearly 2NT. Partner raises to 3NT and you pass.
South plays 3NT. West leads the !H2, East wins the !HA and returns the !H5. West takes the !HK and plays the !H7.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
West leads the !H2, East wins the !HA and returns the !H5. West takes the !HK and plays the !H7.
Winner count: !S 2 : !H 2 : !D 2 : !C 2 : Total = 8
You are glad the defense started with !Hs, that was a suit you would have had to play yourself. You need one more winner and your first thought may be that the !Ss are going to have to split 3-3. However, that happens only about 40% of the time so you keep looking. There is one more card that might be valuable, the !CJ. If East holds the !CQ then you can make a trick out of the !CJ.
You are already in dummy with the !HJ so you lead a small !C. If East plays low you will play the !CJ which will hold the trick and become your 9th winner. If East plays his !CQ you will have the !CJ for your 9th winner later.
And if East doesn't have the !CQ at all? then you STILL have the possibility of a 3-3 !S split.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]

Auction: pass pass pass 1S | 2H 4S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1!S]
You open 1!S. West overcalls 2!H and partner bids 4!S.
South plays 4!S. West leads !HA, !HK, !HQ.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 1 : !H 2 : !D 1 : !C 0 : Total = 4
You have already lost the 2 !Hs and you will definitely lose the !D. So you cannot lose a !S as well. When you have 11 cards in a suit missing the King, the recommended play is to play for the drop. But the recommended play shouldn't be used on this hand because you know that East has the !SK. How do you know this? Because West has turned up with 10 points in !Hs, (the A K Q and a fifth one). If he held the !SK as well he would have had 13 points and a good suit and would have opened he bidding. But he didn't open, so he doesn't have the !SK.
Ruff the !H. Play the !D8 to dummy's !DT. If East takes the !DA win his return and enter dummy with the !DQ. When in dummy lead the !SQ and finesse East out of his !SK.
