Auction: 1H | pass 2H pass 3C | pass 4H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1!H]
Your first bid is easy, you say 1!H. But what do you say after partner's 2!H response? [BID 3!C]
You have 18 points and partner has 6-T. Doing the math, you total 24-28.
You want to make a bid that will tell partner to bid game if he has 9-T, but will stop at 3!H if he only has 6-7. Lots of players will bid 3!H with this hand to make just that invitation. There's nothing wrong with that bid.
But there is an improvement. Bid 3!C instead. Partner knows you aren't showing him a !C suit, why would you do that after agreeing on !Hs? What it means is "Partner I'm inviting you to bid the game if you have maximum, but if your decision is close decide based on !Cs, the suit I could use help in." It is called a HELP SUIT GAME TRY. Partner has 8 points and the !CA and decides that is enough to bid game.
South plays 4!H. West leads the !SK.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 1 : !H 0 : !D 1 : !C 2 : Total = 4
You win the !SA and pull trumps in three rounds. You need to manufacture one winner and you can see right off the bat that it cannot be manufactured in !Ds or !Cs. However, you CAN set up the !S8.
Lead the !ST. West must win with his !SJ. Let's say he plays a !C. Win with dummy's !CA and play the !S9, discarding a small !C. West will take his !SQ and cash a !C trick, but then must let you back in. You enter dummy with the !DA and discard your !D loser on the good !S8.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
You cannot make T tricks unless West's opening lead is a !S.

Auction: 1D pass 1S | pass 2S pass 3C | pass 3D pass 4NT | pass 5H pass 6S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1!S]
You don't quite have the strength for a jump-shift, and in any case sometimes it is better to proceed slowly. So you respond 1!S, knowing partner must bid again. 
He does bid again, surprising you when he says 2!S. What do you bid? [BID 3!C]
All of a sudden your hand has become gigantic. Never mind points, you have only 5 possible losers in your hand and partner has opened the bidding. Surely he can take care of a few of them.
You want to try for slam. DO NOT BID BLACKWOOD! With two quick losers in !Ds you would not know what to do if Partner showed only one Ace. You wouldn't know whether the defense could take the first two !D tricks or not. A better approach is to use a control bid. 
So you bid 3!C. Partner will absolutely know that you aren't bidding a !C suit, he knows you have already agreed on !Ss. He will take you to be showing first round control in !Cs, probably the !CA.
Partner bids 3!D. What do you bid next? [BID 4NT]
Partner's 3!D is a control bid showing the !DA. Do not even consider that he is trying to get back to !Ds, you both know that your suit is !Ss. 
NOW you use Blackwood, knowing you are not in danger of losing two quick !Ds.
Partner replies 5!H, showing two Aces. What do you bid? [BID 6!S]
Your side has all the Aces but don't get greedy. Remember that partner made a minimum bid at his second turn. He couldn't have two Aces and three Kings. 
So you bid the small slam.
South plays 6!S. West leads the !HQ.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 0 : !H 1 : !D 0 : !C 1 : Total = 2
Too bad partner didn't have either !HK or !CK. But since he didn't you will just have to establish the !D suit.
You pull trumps in one round with your !SK. Play !D A K, then ruff a !D. if both defenders follow then both dummy's !Ds are good and you will make 7. However, it is more likely that !Ds will split 4-2, in which case you return to dummy with the !SJ and ruff the fourth !D. Back to dummy with the !SA and play the now-established !D7, discarding either your !H or !C loser.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
In this hand you could not be defeated unless the !Ds split 5-1.

Auction: 2H | pass 4H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 4!H]
Wow! Partner opens with a 2-bid and you have all of this?
Don't get carried away, it was a WEAK 2-bid. So even though you have 19 points partner has only 6-11. But even though it is possible that the total only comes to 25 you bid the game anyway, figuring that it will probably be at least 26.
North would play 4!H.
Click [ROTATE]
[PLAY N:S9,N:S2,N:HK,N:HQ,N:HJ,N:HT,N:H6,N:H3,N:D8,N:D3,N:C9,N:C6,N:C2,S:SA,S:SK,S:S4,S:S3,S:HA,S:H5,S:H2,S:DA,S:D7,S:D6,S:D2,S:CK,S:C4]
South plays 4!H. West leads the !SQ. 
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 0 : !H 0 : !D 1 : !C 3 : Total = 4
There are two ways to get rid of one of those !C losers. You can lead up to the !CK, hoping that West holds !CA, or you can ruff it in dummy.
Suppose you try to combine both chances. Win the !SK, then play a small !H to your hand. Lead a !C and play dummy's !CK. East takes the !CA and plays another trump which you win in your hand. You play another !C but East wins this one also and leads another trump, removing dummy's last hope of ruffing a !C. Down 1.
Instead you could give up on the idea of leading toward the !CK and just lead a !C from dummy at trick 2. The defenders can win and lead a trump, but you play a second !C. They win this also but even if they lead a trump you can still ruff your third !C in dummy and make the game.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
You can also see that leading a !H back to your hand at trick 2 is a bad idea.
But did you see there is another way to reach your hand? You could play !SA then ruff a !S. This runs the small risk that East started with a singleton !S.

Auction: 1S | pass 2S pass 3D | pass 3S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 2!S]
With 6 points you must respond. And with 3 !Ss you can support partner's suit.
You respond 2!S and partner bids 3!D. What do you bid? [BID 3!S]
Partner's 3!D bid is a Help Suit Game Try. He is inviting you to bid game if you have a good 2!S response, particularly if you can help him in !Ds.
Although have the !D help you have a bare minimum response. So you return to 3 !S which partner passes.
North would play 3!S.
Click [ROTATE]
[PLAY N:SK,N:SJ,N:ST,N:S8,N:S4,N:HA,N:HK,N:H3,N:H2,N:D9,N:D5,N:CA,N:C6,S:SQ,S:S9,S:S2,S:H8,S:H5,S:H4,S:DA,S:D6,S:D3,S:C7,S:C5,S:C4,S:C2]
South plays 3!S. West leads the !DK. 
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 1 : !H 2 : !D 1 : !C 1 : Total = 5
The !D loser, the !C loser and the Ace of trumps are unavoidable. One !H loser is also unavoidable, but the second one can be ruffed in dummy. You cannot afford to play a single trump.
Win the !DA and play !HA, !HK, !H2. The defenders will win this. If your !H3 happened to set up then you won't have to ruff it, but more than likely the !Hs split 4-2. The defenders may now take a !D winner, or they may lead !SA and another !S. But they cannot stop you from ruffing your fourth !H with dummy's !SQ or !S9.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
In that case you must be sure to ruff the fourth !H with the !SQ or the !S9. If East wants to over-ruff it will be with the !SA which you must lose anyway.
Look at what would have happened if you had led a trump at trick 2. East could have won the !SA and played another !S. Then, when West took the third !H he could lead his last !S and dummy would have no trump to ruff the final !H with.

Auction: 1C | pass 1D pass 1NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1!C]
When you are dealt 13 points and only one biddable suit things are simple. After you open 1!C partner responds 1!D. What now? [BID 1NT]
You can't support responder's suit with only 3 cards so you show your minimum by bidding 1NT. Partner bids 3NT and you naturally pass.
South plays 3NT. West leads !S6. East plays !SK.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Winners: !S 1 : !H 2 : !D 1 : !C 2 : Total = 6
You need 3 more winners and clearly they must come from the !D suit. If West happens to hold the !DK all will be well, but what about the times when East holds it?
The immediate, burning question is whether to win the first trick or not. By winning you will create a second !S stopper - as long as East never gets into the lead. But the problem is that your main finesse is going into East. So you hold up on the first trick, sacrificing the chance of a second stopper. When East returns a !S you hold up again, playing the !SJ which West wins with the !SQ. Your !SA is finally driven out on the third trick.
Now you take the !D finesse, losing to East's !DK (as expected). But it doesn't matter because East has no more !Ss. Whatever he plays you win and take all your winners, which happen to add up to 9.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
If you did not have the !SJ you would never consider doing anything except hold up. But with it you start wondering if you can get a trick with it. Of course, as you see, the hold-up would be correct with !S A 3 2, and it is also correct with !S A J 2.

Auction: 1H | pass 2H pass 4H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1!H]
With 20 points and 5-3-3-2 distribution you could correctly open 2NT.
However, many think it more important to bid a 5-card Major. In this case you decide to open 1!H. Partner responds 2!H.
What do you bid next? [BID 4!H]
Partner promised 6-10 points. With your 19 you decide to bid game.
South plays 4!H. West leads the !DQ.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 2 : !H 1 : !D 1 : !C 1 : Total = 5
One of the !S losers will be ruffed in dummy so you really just have to eliminate one loser.
It is very tempting to win the first trick in dummy and immediately finesse East for the !HK. If the finesse works then all will be well, but if it fails another !D will knock out your !DA. Then, when the defense gets into the lead with a !S or !C they will cash their !D winner.
Here is a better idea. Win the first trick in your hand with the !DA, and immediately lead a low !S toward the !SQ. If West holds the !SK he is caught in the middle. If he ducks you play the !SQ and don't lose any !Ss. If he goes up you can win a later trick with the !SQ and dump dummy's !D loser on your !SA.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
But there are many situations when that is NOT the best plan. Perhaps because you need to ruff something in dummy, or perhaps (like this hand) because playing trumps would give the timing to the defense. 
In this deal pulling trumps is secondary to finding a place for that slow !D loser.

Auction: 1H | pass 4H pass pass | pass pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1!H]
You open 1!H and partner jumps to 4!H. You pass.
South plays 4!H. West leads the !CQ.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 2 : !H 0 : !D 2 : !C 1 : Total = 5
The !C losers are shown as 1 since you will always be able to ruff a !C in dummy.
North's precipitous leap to 4!H was made partly in hopes of making the contract, and partly as a preemptive bid to shut the opponents up. So it wouldn't be a surprise to land in an unmakeable contract. However, this one has a slim chance. The only suit you might make something of is !Ss. If West holds the !SA then leading up to the !SK would eliminate one of the !S losers - that would at least get you to down only 1. 
Or, if West holds the !SQ and East the !SA then leading up to the !SJ would also eliminate one !S loser. But this play has another advantage - if West should happen to hold BOTH the !SA and !SQ then leading up to the !SJ will actually let you make the contract. So you win the !CA, pull two trumps, then play a !S to the !SJ. If that wins, back to your hand with a trump and play your other !S to the !SK.
Click NEXT to see a miracle. [NEXT]
But you should still ask yourself if there is some distribution that will allow you to be successful. And if there is, just assume that distribution and boldly play the cards out.

Auction: 1NT | pass 2C pass 2D | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1NT]
Balanced, 17 points. You open 1NT. Partner's response is 2!C. What do you bid? [BID 2!D]
Partner's 2!C is Stayman. You have no 4-card Major to show so you bid 2!D. Partner now says 3NT and you pass.
South plays 3NT. West leads !SQ.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Winners: !S 2 : !H 0 : !D 4 : !C 2 : Total = 8
The only thing better than being good is being lucky! You are very lucky that you didn't get a !H lead - now you must take advantage of your good luck.
You only need one more winner, and the !C suit is your best bet. You can finesse either defender for the !CQ so naturally you will finesse West. You dare not let West get into the lead since he can lead through dummy's !HK. If East gets the lead with the !CQ, he cannot hurt you.
Win the first trick with the !SA. (DO NOT HOLD UP, WEST MAY SWITCH). Play the !CK then !CJ, letting it ride if not covered. East can win the !CQ but cannot lead a !H without giving you a trick. You win whatever else he returns and make your 9 tricks. Of course you must be careful to unblock the !D A K Q while you still have a dummy entry to the !DJ.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
Be on the lookout for this type of situation because many times you have a finesse that can be made either way. So you finesse into the Safe hand.

Auction: 3H | 3S 4H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 3!H]
You estimate your hand has 6 playing tricks. That is reasonable for a preemptive 3!H bid. West overcalls 3!S and partner bids 4!H. Everybody passes.
South plays 4!H. West leads the !SK.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 1 : !H 1 : !D 0 : !C 1 : Total = 3
This looks way too easy. If the !H finesse works and the !C finesse works you could make 6. It is when things look too easy that you should look for danger! What if you play the !SA and East ruffs. What if East also gets a trick with the !HK and West gets a trick with the !CQ. What with your !S loser you would be down 1.
West probably has a 7-card suit to overcall at the 3-level, so if you play the !SA East will ruff and one of your winners will disappear. So don't play the !SA. Duck and let West win the trick while East shows out as expected. West will lead the !SQ and you duck again. So West will lead the !SJ and you duck one more time, but now you can ruff in your hand.
Lead your !HQ and finesse, East winning the !HK. East will probably return a !D which you win in dummy. Play the !HA. Then ruff a !D to get back to your hand and pull any trumps left out. Play a !C to dummy's !CA and at long last play dummy's !SA and discard your !C loser.
Clickfor the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
To make sure the !SA didn't disappear you had to hold it until East no longer had a trump.

Auction: 2C pass 2NT | pass 4C pass 4D | pass 6NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 2NT]
With 9 points opposite an opening 2!C bid you are too strong for a negative response.
A suit response would promise a 5-card suit so you bid 2NT. Partner says 4!C.
What do you bid? [BID 4!D]
Partner's jump to 4!C over your 2NT is Gerber convention.
You have no Aces so you respond 4!D. Partner bids 6NT.
South to play 6NT. West leads the !SJ.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Winners: !S 3 : !H 2 : !D 3 : !C 0 : Total = 8
You need 4 more winners. The !C suit will provide 3 of them once the !CA is gone. A 3-2 split in !Ds will assure 2 more !D tricks. There are lots of possibilities but you must be careful of entries and unblocking. In particular, you only have one entry to your hand (if you don't waste the !SQ) and that is the !C K Q. So you need to be sure to unblock the !S A Q before you try to get to your hand in !Cs.
But there is something you MUST do first - test the !Ds. You win the !SA and play !DA, !DK. East shows out on the second !D! Now you unblock your !SQ, then lead a !C to your !CQ. Assume a defender takes the !CA and plays a !S. You win the !SK, then the !CK. Next a !D toward dummy, finessing West out of the !DJ. Dummy is now high.
Clickfor the full Deal - and an auxiliary plan. [NEXT]
[RESET]
You must abandon !Cs temporarily and take the !D finesse. You take your good !Ds and then go back to !Cs.

Auction: 1NT | pass 6NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 6NT]
Partner has a balanced hand with 15-17 points. You have a balanced hand with 18 points. Together that makes two balanced hands with 33-35 points.
So you bid 6NT.
North would play 6NT.  
Click [ROTATE]
[PLAY N:SA,N:SQ,N:S8,N:HA,N:H7,N:H6,N:H2,N:D8,N:D5,N:D4,N:CA,N:CQ,N:C9,S:SK,S:S7,S:S3,S:HK,S:H8,S:H4,S:DA,S:DK,S:DJ,S:CK,S:CJ,S:CT,S:C6]
South plays 6NT. West leads the !SJ. 
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Winners: !S 3 : !H 2 : !D 2 : !C 4 : Total = 11
It's nice to make Plans for slams because there are so few losers to worry about.
This one is definitely straightforward. You need to get one more winner. You can hope for a 3-3 !H split which would mean your fourth !H would become a winner, or you can hope that West has the !DQ in which case a simple finesse will give you the winner. But instead of making it an either/or situation you can combine your chances.
Win the first trick in either hand and duck a !H. Win the return and play your 4 !C winners (discarding a !D from your hand) followed by your other 2 !S winners. Then play !DA, !HK and !HA. You will be in your hand with two cards - the !H7 and the !D8. If the !H7 is good, cash it and win the last trick with dummy's !DK. If the !H7 is not a winner then finesse the !DJ.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
Here the !D finesse was one possibility, but by ducking a !H you could test the !H suit and still keep the !D finesse in reserve.

Auction: 1S | pass 2H pass 2S | pass 3S pass 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1!S]
You open 1!S and partner responds 2!H.
What do you bid? [BID 2!S]
With only 14 points and a 6-card suit you rebid a minimum 2!S. Partner raises to 3!S.
What do you say now? [BID 4!S]
Your bids show 13-15 points. Partner has decided to invite you to bid game with a maximum. Since you have 14 points it's not really clear whether you should accept the invitation. You decide to add a little for your singleton Ace and bid 4!S.
South plays 4!S. West leads the !DK.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 0 : !H 2 : !D 2 : !C 0 : Total = 4
The two fast losers in !Hs can't be helped, but maybe you can get rid of one of the !D losers.
Win the !DA and play the !C6 to your !CA. Play !SA, then a small !S to dummy's !SJ. Lead the !CQ. If East covers, ruff and re-enter dummy with a trump so you can discard a !D loser on the !CJ. If East doesn't cover the !CQ when you lead it, discard a !D immediately. As long as East holds the !CK you can make the contract. This is called a Ruffing Finesse.
Click NEXT to see all four hands. [NEXT]
But in this deal the ruffing finesse is the only Plan that works.

Auction: 2C | pass 2D pass 2NT | pass 3C pass 3H | pass 4H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 2!C]
You certainly have a Notrump type hand, but you are too strong to open 2NT.
With 23 points you open 2!C. Partner says 2!D.
What is your next bid? [BID 2NT]
Now you show your 23 point, balanced hand by bidding 2NT. This is not forcing on partner, he might pass.
However, he doesn't pass, he says 3!C.
What is your next bid? [BID 3!H]
This is no different than a 3!C bid after an opening 2NT. It is Stayman.
So you bid your 4-card !H suit and partner bids the game.
South plays 4!H. West leads the !C2. The defense takes three !C tricks, then plays a small !D.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
The defense takes three !C tricks, then plays a small !D.
Losers: !S 0 : !H 1 : !D 0 : !C 3 : Total = 4
Since you've already lost the 3 !C tricks the Goal of your Plan is simple - Don't Lose the !H.
That makes the card assumptions simple also - East Must Have the !HK.
You only have one dummy entry so once you use it you must remain in dummy until you have finished finessing. If East has the !H K x you can't go wrong. If he has !H K x x you will have to play with care. And if he has !H K x x x you must play perfectly.
Enter dummy with the !SK. Lead the !H9 and let it ride. Assuming it wins, lead the !HJ and play your !HT under it. Now lead a small !H and finesse the !HQ. This way you get all four !H tricks. No other way will work.
Click NEXT to see why. [NEXT]
VISUALIZE:
(1) That your first play from dummy was  !HJ, and you played !H3 from your hand. The next !H would have to be taken in your hand and you no longer have a finesse.
(2) That your first play from dummy was the !HJ and you played !HT under it. To stay in dummy one more trick you would have to play the !H9 and put the !H3 under it. But when you play the !H9 East will cover with his !HK. You can win with the !HA but are left with !H Q 3 and the lead will be in your hand. You will lose a trick to East's !H 8 5.

Auction: 1C pass 2NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 2NT]
With 13 points and good 4-card support you are strong enough to jump to 3!C.
However an 11 trick minor game is not as attractive as a 9 trick Notrump game, so you should also consider a jump to 2NT.
Looking at all those Kings should sway you to 2NT. You prefer to be declarer on this hand so the opening lead comes up to one those Kings. Partner bids 3NT.
South plays 3NT. West leads !H7, East plays !HT and you win !HJ.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Winners: !S 2 : !H 1 : !D 2 : !C 2 : Total = 7
The opening lead gave you 1 !H trick. If !Cs split 2-2 you can make T tricks! But wait, you only need 9 tricks. What if you play 2 top !Cs and it turns out East has !C Q x x ? He could win the next !C and lead a !H through your !H K 9. That would not be good.
So East is the Danger hand and he must be kept out of the lead. At trick two cross to dummy with the !CA. Then play the !CJ, letting it ride if East doesn't cover. If West has the !CQ you will lose the trick but he cannot play !Hs without setting up your !HK. You will win 4 !C tricks and the game. If East actually does have the !CQ you will make an overtrick.
Clickfor the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
That old guideline says you should finesse for a missing Queen when you and partner have eight cards in the suit, but play for the drop when you have nine.
All else being equal, it's a good guideline. But sometimes all else ISN'T equal, like in this hand where you absolutely must not let East get the lead.

Auction: 1D | pass 1H pass 3D | pass 4D pass 5D | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1!D]
You open 1!D and partner responds 1!H.
What is your next bid? [BID 3!D]
With 18 points you are too strong to rebid 2!D but just right to jump to 3!D. Now partner raises to 4!D.
What is your next bid? [BID 5!D]
Your jump showed 16 - 18 points and partner invited you based on that range. He wants  you to bid game if you are at the top. With 18 points you bid 5!D.
South plays 5!D. West leads the !CJ and East plays the !CK.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 1 : !H 1 : !D 0 : !C 1 : Total = 3
The !C lead was pleasant, it gave you a free finesse. But it didn't really give you a winner since you would have ended up taking the finesse yourself even without the lead. Still, it clears the position somewhat.
You can't get rid of the !S loser, nor can you get rid of the !H loser. By process of elimination then, you must get rid of the !C loser. You could ruff it in dummy, but the play to the first trick makes you a little worried about an over-ruff by East. You could ruff with the !DA, but then if someone started with !D J T 8 you'd lose a natural !D trick.
First test the !Ds by playing the !DK. West shows out and there goes your hope of ruffing the !C with the !DA. You have one more possibility to try. Play the !HA, then a small !H toward the !HQ. If West holds the !HK dummy's !HQ will be promoted to a winner that you can dump your !C loser on. 
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
If you ruffed the third !C with the !DA East would win a trump trick.
So you couldn't ruff the third !C at all, you had to discard it on something. And the only "something" that dummy had was the !HQ.

Auction: 2C | pass 2D pass 2S | pass 3S pass 4NT | pass 5D pass 6S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 2!C]
This is definitely a 2!C opening bid.
Partner responds 2!D, 7 points or less.
What do you bid next? [BID 2!S]
The formalities are over. Partner knows you have 22 or more points and you know he has 7 or fewer. Time to find a suit.
You bid 2!S which partner raises to 3!S.
What do you bid next? [BID 4NT]
Partner's 3!S bid is forward-going. With a complete bust he would have said 3!C as a "second negative". So you use Blackwood. Partner shows one Ace and you bid the slam.
South plays 6!S. West leads the !CJ.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 0 : !H 1 : !D 0 : !C 1 : Total = 2
Between the !H loser and the !C loser which one can you eliminate? Easy question, fast losers like the !HA are tough to eliminate. Usually you work on those slow losers.
The logical way to remove that !C loser is to ruff it in dummy. But do it carefully. It would be silly to play !CA, !CK, !CQ and then try to ruff the !C4. That is just begging for an over-ruff. It would be better to just take two rounds of !Cs, then ruff the !C4. But even that isn't the best.
First take two rounds of trumps with the !SA and !SK. Then play two top !Cs. Only then do you ruff the !C4.
Clickfor proof that this elaborate Plan was the best. [NEXT]
It made no difference in tricks whether you ruffed the third or fourth !C so that made it right to ruff the third one.

Auction: 2NT | pass 3C pass 3S | pass 4S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 3!C]
Partner has 20-21 points, so with your 6 you belong in game. But which game?
You use Stayman convention to try to find out. Partner responds 3!S.
What do you bid now? [BID 4!S]
You have at least 26 combined points and 8 !Ss. So you bid 4!S.
North would play 4!S.
Click [ROTATE]
[PLAY N:SA,N:SJ,N:S8,N:S6,N:HA,N:HK,N:DJ,N:D9,N:D5,N:CA,N:CQ,N:CJ,N:CT,S:SK,S:SQ,S:S7,S:S2,S:HJ,S:H4,S:D7,S:D6,S:D2,S:C6,S:C5,S:C3,S:C2]
South plays 4!S. West leads !DA, !DK, !D4. East wins the third trick with !DQ and plays a !H.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 0 : !H 0 : !D 3 : !C 1 : Total = 4
Since you've already lost the three !Ds you'd better not lose the !C.
You must find East with the !CK and you must be able to finesse three times. That means three dummy entries and they all must come from the trump suit.
Play the !SA, then lead the !S8 to dummy's !SQ. Notice that you must save your !S6. Pay attention to whether both defenders follow to both tricks. They do, and that means there is only one !S left out. Play a !C and finesse the !CT. Now lead the !SJ to dummy's !SK. Finesse the !CJ. Finally, lead the !S6 to dummy's !S7. Finesse the !CQ. Claim the rest.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
The first part is realizing that you need to have three entries to dummy.
The second part is figuring out that the !S suit could provide them.

Auction: 1C pass 1H | pass 2H pass 4H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1!H]
Don't even think of jumping to 2!H. That would show 17+ points. Instead you just bid 1!H, knowing partner is forced to bid again.
Partner does bid again, saying 2!H. What do you bid now? [BID 4!H]
Partner's rebid promises a minimum opening bid (13-15) and four !Hs. That makes your total about 28 points and ten !Hs. So you bid game. 
South plays 4!H. West leads the !S2, East playing the !SQ.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 1 : !H 0 : !D 2 : !C 1 : Total = 4
If the !C finesse works you have no !C loser, and as a bonus you will be able to discard one of your other losers. Even if the finesse fails you still have an extra winner for the discard.
Is there a danger here? Yes. Suppose you win the first trick, pull trumps, then finesse the !C. East might win and play a !S back to West's hand. And West might then lead a !D through dummy's !DK.
West is the Danger Hand. You want to keep him off the lead. His only possible entry is the !S suit, so all you have to do is hold up on the first trick. Win the second !S, pull trumps as before, and finesse the !C. East wins but cannot get to his partner's hand for the killing !D lead. You will discard one of your !D losers on dummy's fourth !C.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
For this deal the hold-up serves a different purpose. It keeps one defender from ever gaining the lead.
You had to lose one !S in any case, so you just choose to lose it to the defender who cannot hurt you.
Notice that the Danger Hand WAS on lead at one point - the opening lead. If West had been clairvoyant enough to lead a !D the contract could have been beaten. Opening leads are important to the defense.

Auction: 2H pass 2NT | pass 3D pass 6NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 2NT]
You were probably stunned when you picked up this hand and even more stunned when partner bid.
Your biggest problem is that partner has opened with a weak bid and won't credit you with such a huge hand. So you must make sure you don't make a bid he might pass until you're ready.
For example, suppose you made a jump shift to 4!C. Would partner know what that meant? Do you know what it meant?
The best(?) bid at this point is probably 2NT. Everybody knows what that means. Partner is forced to reply, and will either rebid his suit with a minimum hand or show a "feature" if his hand is better than minimum.
Partner replies 3!D. What do you bid now? [BID 6NT]
Trust your partner. He has shown a better-than-minimum Weak-2 bid, probably 9-11 points, and a high card in !Ds, either the !DA or !DK.
With your hand you don't need anything else to make a slam. You have to decide between 6!H and 6NT. Based on your reluctance to have an opening !C lead go through your !C A Q you choose 6NT.
South plays 6NT. West leads the !SQ.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Winners: !S 2 : !H 6? : !D 0 : !C 1 : Total = 9
The winner list isn't as bad as it looks, once you drive out the !DA you'll have your three extra winners in !Ds. 
In fact, your only real problem is making sure you get all 6 !H winners. If the !Hs split 3-2 it's easy, but if they are 4-1 you cannot afford to overtake the !HJ at the second trick. Fortunately dummy has both the !DK and the !D9.
Win the !SA. Play !HA and !HJ. West shows out on the second one. Lead your !D2 to dummy's !D9. Either you are in dummy now to run the !Hs, or East wins the trick with the !DA. In this case you can win his return (don't finesse if he leads a !C), and get to dummy with the !DK to run the !Hs.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
But when you can make a plan that caters for the possibility you should certainly do so.
In this case dummy had a certain entry in the !D suit so you take advantage of that entry.

Auction: 1H | 2D 2H 2S pass | pass 3H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 2!H]
With 11 points you would probably have bid 3!H, a limit raise, if East hadn't overcalled.
But you now doubt your !DQ is worth 2 points so you just say 2!H.
Now West comes in with 2!S and it is passed around to you. [BID 3!H]
With a known 9-card fit this hand is worth a 3!H bid.
Everybody passes.
North would play 3!H.
Click [ROTATE]

Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 2 : !H 1 : !D 3 : !C 0 : Total = 6
Although there are two !S losers in your hand, one can either be ruffed in dummy or discarded on a high !C. So you really only have one loser too many.
You should realize that if you ruff this !D with one of dummy's teensy !Hs it will be over-ruffed. East did signal a doubleton. The loss of the teensy !H doesn't worry you, you have plenty of them. But the loss of the opportunity to dump a loser should worry you a lot. 
So don't ruff at all. Discard a !S. Now you can ruff your other !S loser in dummy.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
Often, like in this deal, you can discard a loser instead.

Auction: 2C | pass 3C pass 4NT | pass 5D pass 5NT | pass 6D pass 6NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 3!C]
With 9 points you have enough strength to make a positive response. And with a good 5-card suit you respond 3!C.
Partner says 4NT. What do you bid now? [BID 5!D]
Partner's 4NT bid is clearly Blackwood. With one Ace you answer 5!D.
Partner says 5NT. What do you bid now? [BID 6!D]
Partner's 5NT bid guarantees that your side has all the Aces, and asks for your Kings. With one King you answer 6!D.
Partner says 6NT and you pass.
North would play 6NT.
Click [ROTATE]
[PLAY N:SA,N:SQ,N:S4,N:HA,N:HJ,N:HT,N:DA,N:DQ,N:DJ,N:D8,N:CK,N:CQ,N:C6,S:S9,S:S2,S:H8,S:H5,S:DK,S:D6,S:D5,S:D2,S:CA,S:CJ,S:CT,S:C3,S:C2]
South plays 6NT. West leads the !DT.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Winner count: !S 1 : !H 1 : !D 4 : !C 5 : Total = 11
You need just one more winner. If the !SK is with East then a simple finesse will provide it. This would not be a terrible plan - you can expect it to succeed 50% of the time. Of course that means you will go down the other 50% of the time.
The double finesse in !Hs is better. If East holds EITHER the !HK OR the !HQ you will succeed. This raises your chances to 75%.
So win the opening lead with dummy's !DK. Play the !H5, finessing your !HT. West will probably win this with either !HK or !HQ. No matter. Win West's probable !D return and take 5 !C tricks, discarding your 2 !S losers. Lead dummy's !H7 and finesse the !HJ. When this wins the rest of the tricks are yours.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
The choice between a single finesse and a double finesse is one that you will face many times. So remember that the double finesse works 75% of the time.

Auction: 1C | pass 5C pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 5!C]
This is NOT a simple choice.
Partner may have a hand where 3NT is a laydown. Or he may have a hand where 3NT is a godown.
Science isn't going to help you so you guess that 5!C probably has a good chance.
North would play 5!C.
Click [ROTATE]

South plays 5!C. West leads !DA, then !D2.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 2 : !H 1 : !D 1 : !C 0 : Total = 4
MAYBE East will have the !SA and the !HK. But maybe not. You do have an extra !D trick so you need to determine the best use you can make of that.
First pull trumps. It takes one round. Play your other !D winner and discard one of dummy's !Ss. This protects you from losing more than one !S. Enter dummy with a trump and lead the last !S. Assume East has the !SA. If he goes up with it you will be able to dump dummy's !H loser on your !SK. If he plays low you put on your !SK and you no longer have a !S loser.
If it turns out West has the !SA then your !S play didn't work. In that case you would enter dummy again and try the !H finesse. This plan is a winner if East holds EITHER the !HK or the !SA.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
With correct play you succeed when East holds the !SA, but also if he holds the !HK.
The key play was dumping the !S on your !DK rather than a !H.

Auction: 1H | pass 2H pass 3D | pass 4H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1!H]
You have a straightforward 1!H opening bid.
Partner responds 2!H. What do you bid now? [BID 3!D]
With 17 points and two doubletons you are on the borderline between passing and bidding game. If partner has the top of his 6-10 points you want to be in game, if he is at the bottom you don't.
A reasonable bid would be 3!H, inviting partner to bid game with a maximum.
A better bid is 3!D, a Help Suit Game Try. This says the same thing, bid game with a maximum, but also says "Use your !D holding to help you decide."
That was just what North needed. He only had 7 points but decided the !D help was worth an extra point or two.
South plays 4!H. West leads the !CA, !CK, !CQ.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 0 : !H 0 : !D 2 : !C 2 : Total = 4
You must eliminate one !D loser, that means ruffing it in dummy. You would like to pull trumps first but you cannot chance pulling two rounds because if they don't split 2-2 you would have to leave one out until after you had ruffed the !D. The problem would then be that the defender who took the !DA might lead the third trump, preventing your ruff.
So first you must drive out the !DA. After you ruff the !C you play a !D to dummy's !DK. East takes the !DA and leads a trump. You win in your hand, pull one more trump, then play !DQ, !D7, ruffing in dummy. Back to your hand with the !SA, pull the last trump and claim.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
And you couldn't get the !D ruff until after you had forced out the !DA.

Auction: 1H dbl pass 2S | pass 4S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 2!S]
When responding to partner's Takeout Double:- with 0-8 points you bid cheaply- with 9-11 points you jump in a suit- with 12 or more points you cue-bid their suit
You have 11 so you jump to 2!S. Partner bids 4!S and you pass.
South plays 4!S. West leads the !HK.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 1 : !H 3? : !D 0 : !C 1 : Total = 5?
The loser count is somewhat misleading because obviously you can ruff some !Hs in dummy.
Sometimes it is better to count winners, even though it is a suit contract. Winners: !S 2 : !H 1 : !D 2 : !C 2 : Total = 7
Thinking like this makes it clear that you must win 3 of your 4 small trumps. The best way to do this is to win the !HA and pull 2 rounds of trumps with !SA and !SK, spurning the finesse. Trumps split 3-2, so leave the master trump out and cash your other high card winners. Then start cross-ruffing, !Hs in dummy and !Ds in your hand. The defender with the master trump is welcome to ruff with it whenever he wants - it won't stop you from coming to T tricks.
Clickfor the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
If you tried that East would have won his !SQ, then played another !S. That would leave both you and dummy with only one trump each and you would have come up a trick short. You can afford to pull just two rounds of trumps, then must cross-ruff with your remaining four.

Auction: 1H | pass 3H pass 4H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1!H]
You open 1!H, partner responds 3!H.
What is your next bid? [BID 4!H]
Partner's 3!H response shows 11-12 points with good trumps.
With your 14 points you decide to bid the game.
South plays 4!H. West leads the !C4, East plays the !CK.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 3 : !H 0 : !D 2 : !C 1 : Total = 6
There is no hope of extra winners except the !D suit. You are wide open in !Ss, so you have to hope that West holds the !DK. But that won't be enough by itself, in case he has !D K x x x you also have to have three entries to your hand. Two of them will be the !HA and !HQ and the third entry must be the !CA.
So you win the first trick with the !CA and immediately take your first !D finesse. It wins, so you return to your hand with a !H to the !HQ and take another !D finesse. Back to your hand with the !HA (pulling the last trumps) and take a third !D finesse. Finally on the !DA you can discard either your !C loser or a !S. You will have to give up three tricks at the end.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
Any other plan that was based on West holding the !DK would work ALMOST 50% of the time but would fail when West had three protectors for the !DK.

Auction: 1H | pass 3H pass 4H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 3!H]
You have 11 (perhaps 12) points and four trumps. Just right for a limit raise.
So you bid 3!H and partner goes to game.
North would play 4!H.

[PLAY N:SA,N:S4,N:S2,N:HQ,N:HJ,N:HT,N:H5,N:H3,N:DK,N:DJ,N:D7,N:CA,N:C3,S:SK,S:S7,S:S3,S:HA,S:H8,S:H6,S:H2,S:DQ,S:D4,S:CQ,S:C7,S:C5,S:C4]
South plays 4!H. West leads the !SQ. 
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 1 : !H 1 : !D 1 : !C 1 : Total = 4
You know you can't get rid of the !D loser, and it's hard to imagine a way that would let you get rid of the !C loser. The !H loser depends on the finesse. So you should try to find somewhere to put the !S loser.
First you win the !SA. You know that you will eventually take the !H finesse, so should you take it now? Visualize the likely defense actions if you do. Say East wins the !HK. He will surely play another !S, knocking out dummy's !SK. Whenever you try to set up !Ds the defense will take their !S trick and you will eventually go down.
What happened is that you gave the defense a tempo and let them control the timing of the play. You should not have rushed into the !H finesse. Instead suppose that you win the first trick with dummy's !SK and immediately play the !DQ. The defense can take their !DA when they want to and push another !S, but now the timing is on your side. You can discard a !S from dummy on your good !D in time.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
Set up the !D winner before you take the !H finesse and you will always be able to dump the !S loser no matter who has the !HK.

Auction: 1NT | pass 2C pass 2S | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1NT]
With 15 points and a balanced hand of course you open 1NT.
Partner's response is 2!C. What do you bid? [BID 2!S]
Partner's 2!C bid is Stayman asking you to name a 4-card Major.
You bid 2!S, but that must not have been the Major he wanted so he bids 3NT.
South plays 3NT. West leads the !D2. East plays !DQ. You hold up on this trick and East returns the !D3.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
You hold up on this trick and East returns the !D3.
Winners: !S 1 : !H 4 : !D 1 : !C 0 : Total = 6
You need to get three more winners and you have two very clear possibilities.
If East holds the !SK you can finesse him out of it and win an additional 3 tricks in the suit. The problem with this approach is that half the time West will hold the !SK and you will go down.
Or you can drive out the !CA and definitely set up an additional 3 tricks in that suit. The problem with this approach is that if the defender's !Ds split 5-3 they will be able to win 4 !Ds and the !CA.
If you pay attention to the opening lead this becomes a simple decision. West led the !D2. Assuming that was fourth down then he must have led from a 4-card suit. So it looks like the !Ds must be splitting 4-4 and it is safe for you to establish !Cs. So you drive out the !CA. The defenders take their other 2 !Ds but you make the game losing only 3 !Ds and the !CA.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
West's lead of the !D2 should have made you pretty sure that he had led from a 4-card suit. If the !D2 is fourth down, there cannot be a fifth down. Additionally, East's return of the !D3 confirmed that conclusion. If East had started with only 3 !Ds, (say !D Q 6 3) his correct return at trick 2 would have been his next highest, the !D6. With 4 cards in the suit his correct return is his original fourth down.

You have a good hand, a very good hand. But not good enough to open 2!C.
Instead you open 1!S, partner raises to 2!S and East doubles.
What do you bid now? [BID 4!S]
Some would think it clever to now redouble - to put the pressure on East maybe.
But why bother? East would just bid 3!H or 3!D and then you would bid 4!S. So save all the in-between and just bid it now.
South plays 4!S. West leads the !DJ.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 0 : !H 1 : !D 1 : !C 2 : Total = 4
One loser to get rid of. Perhaps you could lead toward the !HQ? Nope, that wouldn't work because East surely has the !HK for his Takeout Double.
Play East for the !CK and finesse him out of it? That probably would work since he likely has that card for his Takeout Double.
So you take the !DA, pull trumps and then . . . . and then you apologize to your partner. You had to be in dummy to finesse the !C and you were only going to be there once. You must finesse the !C immediately, then pull trumps.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
If you decided to play for trumps to split 2-2 so you could use the !S8 as an entry back to dummy for the !C finesse then you need to start thinking more clearly!

Auction: 1S | pass 2S pass 3H | pass 4S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1!S]
You open 1!S and partner responds 2!S.
What do you bid now? [BID 3!H]
With 18 points you want to invite partner to bid game if he has 9 or 10 points. While you could do this with a 3!S bid it is more informative to use a Help Suit Game try - bidding 3 of the suit you'd most like help in. You bid 3!H.
Partner has magnificent help in the !H suit so he bids 4!S.
South to play 4!S. West leads the !CQ.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 1 : !H 0 : !D 2 : !C 1 : Total = 4
You know you are going to get to dummy with a !H and then try the !S finesse. Your big worry should be that if the !S finesse loses East will be able to get the lead and play a !D through your !D K 8.
So ask yourself: "How is East going to get the lead?" The only trick he could win would be the !CK which he almost surely has. But you can keep this from happening by simply holding up on the first !C trick. Win the next one with your !CA, enter dummy with a !H and take the !S finesse. It loses, but to West who can't hurt you with a !D play.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
Then think about how to keep East from getting the lead - in this case holding up on the first trick.

With four trumps and 11-12 points you have a pretty standard limit raise.
So you bid 3!S and partner raises to game.

South plays 4!S. West leads the !HQ.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 1 : !H 1 : !D 1 : !C 1 : Total = 4
You have a loser in each suit and must eliminate one of them. Since the defense can take their Aces whenever they want to you need to find a place to put your "slow" !H loser. There are two possibilites, but each must be tried immediately because once you lose the lead the defenders will set up their !H.
You could win the !H in your hand and lead toward the !CK. If West holds !CA you can establish the !CK for a !H discard.
You could win in dummy and set up a !D no matter which defender holds !DA. You could then discard a !H from dummy on your good !D. This is obviously the better choice since it works with any distribution.
Win the first trick with dummy's !HK and play !DJ. Continue !Ds until they take the !DA. Win their return with your !HA and discard dummy's !H7 on your good !D. Only then do you start on trumps.

[RESET]
A very important part of this Plan was where you chose to win the first trick. Since entries are a problem with either hand you had to save the high !H as entry to the hand that would have the eventual winner.

Auction: 1C pass 1H | pass 3H pass 4H | pass pass pass |
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1!H]
You certainly want to show a Major suit so you respond 1!H.
Partner jumps to 3!H. What do you say? [BID 4!H]
Your response showed 6-10 points and at least four !Hs.
Partner is inviting you to game if you are in the top of that range. With 9 points you certainly are so you bid the game.
South plays 4!H. West leads the !CQ.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 1 : !H 0 : !D 1 : !C 2 : Total = 4
The defense will take their two !C tricks as soon as they get the lead. But you can discard your "slow" !S loser on one of dummy's !D honors IF West has the !DA and IF you act quickly.
Win the first trick with your !CA. Immediately play a !D, putting up dummy's !DQ if West plays low. Pull a round of trumps with !HA, then another, getting back to your hand with !HK. Play your other !D. If West doesn't take his !DA now then you no longer have a !D loser, so assume he takes it. The defense can now take their two !C winners, but when you get the lead again you can discard your !S loser on dummy's good !DK.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
This wasn't a guaranteed Plan like some. If East held the !DA then you would go down.

Auction: pass 1NT | pass 2NT pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1NT]
With a balanced hand and 16 points you open 1NT. In the Bridge dictionary under "Opening 1NT Bid" they probably have a picture of this hand. Partner responds 2NT. What do you bid? [BID 3NT]
Partner's 2NT bid is invitational. Specifically it tells you to pass with 15 points or bid 3NT with 17 points. But it doesn't tell you what to do when you have 16 points. So you have to make a judgement about your hand. Is it closer to 15 or closer to 17? The answer is definitely "closer to 17". Aces are actually worth a little more than 4 points and you have three of them. Also, most of your spot cards are higher than average, with only one card below a 7. So you bid 3NT.
South plays 3NT. West leads the !S6, East plays !S2.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Winner count: !S 2 : !H 2 : !D 0 : !C 1 : Total = 5
You are bound to get 2 winners in !Ss. You need to create 4 winners and the !D suit offers the perfect opportunity. Drive out the !DA and the other four !Ds are winners. But there is a very critical problem. If the defenders hold up their !DA until the third round of the suit you may be locked out of dummy.
Suppose you win the first !S with your !S8. Then you start on !Ds and the defense wins the third one and leads a !H. You win the !H but your only hope of reaching dummy is with a !S. If you take your !SA, then lead a low one West will take his !SK and two more. Suppose you try to sneak over to dummy by playing your !ST. West will jump up with !SK, then lead another which you must win with your !SA. No entry.
In hindsight the answer is simple. Win the very first !S trick with your !SA. That leaves dummy with the !S Q J and a sure entry. It seems strange to win a trick with a higher card than necessary but it is the only way to make this contract.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
Click NEXT to see the effect of your play to the first trick. [NEXT]

Auction: 1D 1H | 1S 2H 2S 4H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1!H]
You surely want to compete and must choose between a Takeout Double and an overcall.
To make a Takeout Double followed by a bid of your own suit you should have 17 points or more. Since you don't quite measure up you overcall 1!H. The opponents find a !S fit and partner raises your !Hs. 
What do you bid now? [BID 4!H]
If you bid 3!H now partner would not take it as invitational, he would just assume you were competing for the partscore.
The truth is that you don't know if you can make game or not. If you are feeling very conservative then perhaps a 3!H bid is ok. But the bold will bid 4!H. 
South plays 4!H. West leads the !SA then the !S8.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 1 : !H 0 : !D 2 : !C 2 : Total = 5
You cannot avoid losing the two !Ds and since you have already lost a !S you must not lose any !Cs. So you have to find East with the !CK. But that isn't all - you also need to get to dummy twice to make two finesses. The !HA is one entry and the other one will have to be the !H7.
Be very careful. Ruff the second !S with the !H8 saving your !H5. Pull one round of trumps with !HK, then lead !HT to dummy (still saving the !H5). Play a !C and finesse the !CJ. Lead your !H5 to dummy's !H7, then another !C, finessing the !CQ. Now play !CA and ruff your last !C with dummy's last !H.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
If you hadn't been able to find that extra entry you would have had no choice but to play East for the doubleton !C K x.

Auction: 1S | pass 2S pass 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1!S]
Make a choice. With 20 points you are strong enough to open 2NT. But, with two doubletons you can't really call this a balanced hand. So you should open 1!S.
Partner responds 2!S. What do you bid? [BID 4!S]
There should be no doubt about this bid. Partner has at least 6 points so you know there is enough for game. You bid 4!S.
South plays 4!S. West leads !HA, !HK, !H3 and East follows to all three.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 0 : !H 2 : !D 2 : !C 1 : Total = 5
The 5 loser count isn't actually right because at this point you can dump one of those losers on dummy's !HQ. The question is: Which one?
You have two chances to set up an extra winner - if the !Ds split 3-2 or if the !CK is with East. If you discard the !CQ right now you will be pinning all your hopes on the !D split. By discarding a !D instead you keep both possibilities alive.
So discard the !D. Pull trumps with !S A J (it takes two rounds) then play !DA and !DK. Bad news, East shows out. So now you take your second chance. Enter dummy with a trump and play a !C, finessing East for the !CK. Good news, this works. Two chances are better than one.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
The percentages are right but the logic is wrong. If you are going to benefit from a 3-2 !D split it is only necessary for you to keep 4 !Ds in one of the hands, not both. So the fourth !D in your hand was unimportant while the !CQ gave you an extra shot.

Auction: 1H | pass 2D pass 2H | pass 4H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1!H]
You have an easy 1!H opening bid.
Partner responds 2!D. What is your next bid? [BID 2!H]
No matter how much you learn about bidding you will always come across hands which defy you to find anything reasonable to say. This is one of them.
You can't pass. Partner's 2-level response forces you to bid again. You can't raise his bid to 3!D with only 3-card support. You shouldn't rebid your !H suit without 6 of them. And you hate to bid 2NT with your black suit holding. Whenever you get into a situation like this you should admit to yourself that whatever you say is going to be a lie, then try to find the bid that is likely to get you into the least amount of trouble.
In this case that bid is 2!H. Although you only have 5 of them, at least you have the top 3.
After all that worrying partner bids 4!H and you pass.
South plays 4!H. West leads the !SQ and the defense plays three high !Ss.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 2 : !H 0/1 : !D 0 : !C 1 : Total = 3/4
If the trumps split 3-2 you are going to make 11 easy tricks.
So you ruff the third !S and play !HA, !HK. East shows out.
Decide whether to revise the Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Don't change plans, the old one was doing fine. Pull one more trump with the !HQ. That leaves West with !HJ and you with !H7. Don't panic, just don't lead any more !Hs. Start playing !D winners, then !C winners. Let West ruff with his !HJ any time he wants to, your !H7 will then be able to take care of a !S return and let you get back to minor suit winners.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
This deal is a good example of that principle.

Auction: 1S | pass 1NT pass 3S | pass 4S pass pass | pass

With 10 points you aren't strong enough to respond at the 2-level, particularly with that weak !D suit.
So you bid 1NT. Partner jumps to 3!S.
What do you bid? [BID 4!S]
Your 10 points are looking better now that you know partner has at least 16. That puts you at game-going strength.
And your !S Q 7 looks better too, knowing that partner has 6 !Ss.
So you bid 4!S.
North would play 4!S.

You have one loser to get rid of. Your best approach is to establish a !C in dummy to take care of your !D loser. You can't pull trumps yet because you need  the !SQ as an entry.
Win the !HA. Play a !C to the !CK, then another !C. A defender will probably win this one and they will take two !Hs. But then they must give you the lead. You enter dummy with the !SQ and dump your !D6 on the good !C. Then you pull trumps and claim.

If the opening lead had been a !D you would first take the !DA, then pull trumps, then establish a !C to discard a !H loser, using the !HA as an entry.
If the opening lead had been a !S you would pull trumps, then establish a !C to discard a red loser on, using the !HA as an entry.
The same general plan, but with slightly different details, applies with all opening leads.

Auction: 2D pass 2NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 2!D]
With 11 points and a beautiful 6-card suit this is the perfect hand for a Weak-2 opener. So you open 2!D. Partner responds 2NT. [BID 3NT]
Partner's 2NT bid is a standard response to a Weak 2-bid. You are expected to rebid your suit if you have a minimum (6-8 point) hand. Otherwise you are to bid an outside suit in which you hold a high card - this is called "showing a feature". And the final possibility is this one, where you have a solid suit,  either A K Q x x x or A K J T x x. In this case you bid 3NT.
North would play 3NT.

The !S lead assures you of two tricks in the suit. So you only need to create two more. If the !Ds split 3-2 (likely) you could get 3 extra tricks there. But there's a danger - if they split 4-1 you wouldn't have an entry to them. Well, you wouldn't have an entry unless you DUCKED the first !D. Then a 4-1 split wouldn't prevent you from making 5 !D winners.

West shows out.

West shows out.
That's tough. No matter how you play them you can only get 3 !D winners. So you must turn elsewhere - elsewhere being the !C suit.
Win the !DQ but don't play another !D yet, you need an entry back to dummy later. Instead, lead the !C2 and finesse your !CT. West will win with one of the high !Cs and probably return a !S. You may as well take the !SQ now. Play your !D8 to dummy's !DK, cash the !DA, then play the !C4, finessing your !CJ. Fortunately this wins and when you cash your !CA both defenders follow. The rest of your clubs are good and you make an overtrick.

When the !Ds turned out to be 5-0 you had to get lucky. Your back-up Plan wasn't likely to work - it required the missing !C honors to be split, but also required a 3-3 !C split, not a likely outcome.
But there was no other choice so you have to try it.

Auction: 1NT | pass 4NT pass 6NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 4NT]
You have 16 points - a pretty solid 16 in fact. Partner has 15, 16 or 17, so together you have 31, 32 or 33. You want to invite partner to bid 6NT if he has 17, but to decline if he has 15. The correct bid for this invitation is 4NT. It is called a "quantitative" 4NT since it is just an invitational raise. It is NOT Blackwood - if you wanted to ask for Aces you would use Gerber.
Partner bids the slam.
North would play 6NT.

[PLAY N:SJ,N:ST,N:S5,N:HK,N:HQ,N:H6,N:DK,N:DJ,N:DT,N:D3,N:CA,N:CK,N:C9,S:SK,S:S8,S:S6,S:HA,S:H8,S:H4,S:DA,S:DQ,S:D8,S:CQ,S:CJ,S:CT,S:C7]
South plays 6NT. West leads the !S3.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Winner count: !S 0 : !H 3 : !D 4 : !C 4 : Total = 11
It's pretty clear which suit you have to worry about! Your goal is simple, you must win one !S trick before you lose two. So the crux of your problem is: Who holds the !SA and !SQ?
If West has both of them you are guaranteed to win the first trick no matter what you play.
If East has both of them you are going to lose the first two tricks no matter what you play.
The problem is to decide what to do if they are split. The answer relies on psychology, not on probability. West has made an attacking lead. But if you were West would you start out leading a low !S from a suit like !S A 9 7 3? That would be incredibly foolhardy, you would probably lead a different suit and save your !SA for catching something high from declarer. On the other hand you would be quite likely to lead a small card from !S Q 9 7 3. 
Your PLAN should be to play low in dummy and win your !ST if East withholds the !SA.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
Since West is unlikely to underlead an Ace against 6NT you play East for the !SA.

So all you have to do is turn the !S Q J into the equivalent of the !SK. It's easy. 
Win the !CA. Take two rounds of trumps with the !HA Q. East shows out on the second trump lead. Play the !SA, then the !S4. West will win the !SK and the defense will take their !C trick. Then they must give you the lead and you play a !H to dummy's !HK, pulling West's final trump. Play the good !SQ, discarding one of your !D losers.

Auction: 1S | pass 2C pass 2D | pass 4S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1!S]
You have a real bare-bones 13 points. No matter, you don't pass with 13. So you open 1!S.
Partner responds 2!C. What do you bid next? [BID 2!D]
You have two choices - bid 2NT or bid 2!D. Neither is showing any extra strength so partner shouldn't go crazy. Not liking that singleton you say 2!D.
Partner goes crazy and bids 4!S.
South plays 4!S. West leads the !CJ.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]

You may think you're lucky they didn't take their !H tricks, but the truth is that they will probably get them anyway. If trumps split 2-2 then you can easily ruff both !D losers in dummy. Or, you could ruff three !C losers in your hand, it would work out the same.
The first key is to go up with the !CA. you cannot afford to lose a !C now with those three !H losers staring you in the face.
Next play the !SK and !SA, but West shows out on the second one. Don't pull a third one. You need to make those last five trumps separately. Take your two high !Ds, then start cross-ruffing !Cs and !Ds. You will lose the final three !Hs.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
And with any cross-ruff it is best to pull as many trumps as you can spare before you start ruffing. Leave yourself just the number of trumps you need.

Auction: 1H | pass 2H pass 3C | pass 4H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1!H]
You have a valid opening 1NT bid. You also have a valid opening 1!H bid. It is up to you and your partner to agree on whether you will open 1NT when you hold a 5-card Major.
For the purpose of this Deal, and not choosing sides, you open 1!H. Partner responds 2!H. [BID 3!C]
You agree on Where, now you must figure out How High. Add partner's 6-T to your 17 and you get 23-27. In other words you might have enough for game if partner has a maximum. 
You want to make an invitational bid and it is ok to now bid 3!H. Partner will understand what you mean and will either pass or bid 4!H, depending on his hand.
But you can also bid any other suit and it will have the same invitational quality to it, but it will give partner the information about where you could use some help. This is called a Help Suit Game Try. In this case you bid 3!C.
Partner, with 9 points and help for !Cs, bids 4!H.
South plays 4!H. West leads the !CJ.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 2 : !H 1 : !D 1 : !C 0 : Total = 4
The !SA and the !HA definitely won't go away. And the !D loser is pretty sure also. However, the second !S loser can be eliminated either by leading up to the !S K Q 5 or by ruffing it in dummy.
Suppose you win the !C and play one round of trumps. Oops, it is now too late to make the contract. Someone can win the !HA and play another !H. Then, whoever takes the !SA can lead a third !H and you can no longer ruff your !S.
Try this instead. Win the !C in dummy and play a small !S to your !SQ. Assume West wins the !SA and leads !HA and another !H. You win this in your hand, play !SK and ruff your last !S with dummy's last trump. Now get to your hand, pull trumps and give up a !D at the end.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
Suppose when you led toward your !SQ it held the trick. Would you be convinced that East musthold the !SA and change your plan? Would you then pull trumps and let your contract depend on that assumption? I hope not.

Auction: pass 1C | pass 1S pass 1NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1!C]
With 14 points and only one biddable suit this was a snap. You open 1!C. Partner responds with 1!S. What do you bid? [BID 1NT]
This one isn't such a snap. You sure cannot support !Ss with only 2 of them, even good ones. You aren't supposed to rebid your !Cs without a 6-card suit. You hate to bid Notrump with neither of the two red suits stopped, and you cannot pass. So you bite the bullet and say 1NT. Partner jumps it to 3NT and you pass, hoping he can stop the red suits.

You need 2 more tricks and you expect to get them from !Cs. This should have been evident while they were leading all those !H winners so you would not have discarded one of the !Cs from your hand. But you also had to be careful not to discard even one of dummy's !Cs, you need all three of them.
If the !Cs split 3-2 it wouldn't matter, but if East happens to have !C J x x x then you will need dummy's third !C to make a finesse. You first play your !CA, then lead a small !C to dummy's !CK. West shows out on this !C so you know that East has !C J 9 left. You lead dummy's !C7, finessing East out of the !CJ.
