Auction: 2C | pass 2D pass 2S | pass 4S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 2!C]
You have 23 points. You must open 2!C.
Partner responds 2!D showing 7 or fewer points.
What do you bid? [BID 2!S]
Following partner's negative response you merely bid your suit at the cheapest level.
You bid 2!S and partner jumps to 4!S.
Now what do you say? [BID pass]
Partner's first response told you he has a weak hand. It didn't suddenly turn into T or 11 points. Partner is merely pulling a "He Who Knows, Goes" bid. He thinks you belong in 4!S.
South plays 4!S. West leads the !DQ.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 0 : !H 3 : !D 0 : !C 1 : Total = 4
It is possible (but not probable) that !Cs will split 3-3. 
It is possible (one chance out of two) that East holds the !HA. You could pull trumps, ending in dummy, then lead toward your !HK.
It is almost certain that you could ruff your !H loser in dummy, but only if you play a !H at trick two, leading away from your !HK. The defenders will win the !H cheaply and probably play a trump. You win dummy's !SA and play another !H which they also win. They lead a second trump which you win in your hand. You now ruff the last !H with dummy's !SJ, return to your hand, pull trumps and claim.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
If instead you decide to lead a !S to dummy's !SJ and lead a !H toward your !HK you might go down. West could win the !HA and play a second trump. When you played the next !H West would win again and play a third round of trumps. You would no longer be able to ruff the !H loser.

Auction: 4H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 4!H]
One school of thought says to open 2!C with a hand that is within one trick of game, even though the point count is below 22.
Another school of thought says to go ahead and bid the game, hoping to keep the opponents away from any competition.
Today you take the second and bid 4!H.
South plays 4!H. West leads the !DQ.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 3 : !H 0 : !D 0 : !C 1 : Total = 4
You are going to lose the !C for sure, so you need to find a way to hold the !S losers to 2. The obvious possibility is for West to hold the !SA and you lead through him to make the !SK a winner. That's a 50% possibility.
But you can improve on that a little bit. If West holds both the !S Q J you could make a deep finesse of dummy's !ST and East would have to play his !SA to win the trick. And if it didn't work and East won with a lesser !S you would still have time to play toward the !SK.
Win the !D, pull trumps, lead the !S3 to dummy's !ST. 
Clickfor the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
You must modify the Plan a little bit. Now your only hope is that West still holds the !SJ. So you win the next trick in your hand and lead a !S toward dummy's !ST. This time West is caught. He plays the !SJ hoping you had a doubleton, but you still have a !S to get to the now high !ST.

Auction: 3H | pass 4H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 3!H]
You are very weak. But you are also not vulnerable.
So with 5 playing tricks you leap to 3!H. Partner raises to 4!H and you pass.
South plays 4!H. West leads !SA, then !H8.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 2 : !H 1 : !D 0 : !C 1 : Total = 4
You've already lost 1 !S, you can't escape the !C and it looks like the !H is unavoidable also. So that means you can't afford to lose that second !S.
If you play dummy's !H4 East will win the !HK and play another !H. You will lose that second !S and go down 1.
Instead you should rise with dummy's !HA, play !DA, !DK and then a small !D which you ruff. Now play your !S9 and ruff with dummy's last trump.
Clickfor the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
But you don't want to get into the habit of doing what is USUALLY good without thinking through the consequences.

Auction: 1NT | pass 2NT pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1NT]
With a balanced, 17 point hand you open 1NT. Partner responds 2NT. What do you bid? [BID 3NT]
You were invited to bid 3NT if you have a maximum opener. With 17 points you accept the invitation.
South plays 3NT. West leads !S5. You put on dummy's !S6 and East plays the !S8.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Winner count: !S 2 : !H 0 : !D 1 : !C 5 : Total = 8
The good news is that they didn't lead a !H. The bad news is that if you give up the lead they probably will. 
Assuming the !Cs behave you need to get one more winner. It's possible you could lead toward dummy's !DQ but even if it works they would probably attack !Hs. Your best chance of getting an extra trick lies in the !S suit.
It is almost certain that West holds the !SQ. Of course defenders sometimes don't lead according to the guidelines, but if East had the !SQ he would likely have played it at the first trick. In addition, the Rule of 11 tells you there were 6 cards in the North, East and South hands higher than the !S5. You can account for all of them, so West must have the !SQ. In that case you can assure the contract by winning the first trick with the !SK rather than the !ST. In this way you will be able to gain a trick by finessing West for the !SQ. It's true that if you won with the !ST you would still have both the !SK and !SA remaining, but you wouldn't have the dummy entry you needed.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
Notice how strange this game can be. If your holding was !S K 2 rather than !S K T you would have had no difficulty coming up with the correct play. But the fact that you can win a cheap trick with the !ST tries to lure you into making an inferior play.

Auction: 1S | pass 2S pass 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You are South and it is your bid. Decide what you would say, then click on BID. [BID 1!S]
You have a nice hand, but can only open 1!S.
Partner raises to 2!S. What do you bid? [BID 4!S]
Partner has 6-10 points, you have 20 points.
The math works so you bid 4!S.
South plays 4!S. West leads the !DT, you cover and East plays the three high !Ds.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers: !S 0 : !H 1 : !D 2 : !C 1 : Total = 4
To start with, you ruff the third !D. You cannot avoid the !C loser, so you might think that !Hs must break evenly to give you a fourth !H trick. In fact, there is a chance that you might ruff the fourth !H.
Play exactly two rounds of trumps with the !SA and !SK. Then play !HK, !HA and !HQ. If both defenders follow to three leads your fourth !H is good so you pull the last trump. If somebody shows out on the third lead and does not ruff then play your last !H and ruff in dummy. Return to your hand with the !CA and pull trumps.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
By pulling exactly 2 rounds of trumps first you can also succeed in the case where !Hs split 4-2 and the defender with the doubleton !H also has a doubleton trump.

Auction: 1NT | pass 2NT pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 3NT]
Partner's 2NT bid invites you to bid game if you have a maximum hand. Your 17 points is certainly a maximum so you bid 3NT.
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
Will you take your !SA immediately? or at trick 2? or trick 3?
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
You need 3 more tricks, and they must come from !Cs. So you must drive out the !CA. The problem is that when the defenders win the !CA they may also take 4 !S tricks.
While you cannot guarantee the contract you can at least give yourself a better chance by holding up your !SA on the first trick, and also on East's !S continuation. You win the third !S with your !SA. [NEXT]
Now you drive out the !CA. There are four possibilities:West may win the !CA and cash two more !Ss, down 1. West may win the !CA and cash just one !Ss, you make it. East may win the !CA and have a fourth !S to lead, you make it. East may win the !CA and be out of !Ss, you make it.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
If you win the first or second !S trick you will fail. When you attack !Cs, East will win the !CA and play a !S.
Holding up twice can never hurt, and in this case it is the only way to make the contract.

Auction: 1NT | pass 2H pass 2S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 2!H]
In the pre-transfer days you would have bid 2!S with this hand and partner would have passed. Now you make partner bid the !Ss first by saying 2!H. Partner dutifully replies 2!S. What do you say? [BID pass]
In the pre-transfer days you would have bid 2!S with this hand and partner would have passed. Now you make partner bid the !Ss first by saying 2!H. Partner dutifully replies 2!S. What do you say?
You say pass.
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
The contract would be 2!S played by North.
To make South the declarer click ROTATE. [ROTATE]
[PLAY N:ST,N:S5,N:HA,N:HQ,N:H6,N:H2,N:DA,N:DQ,N:D4,N:CA,N:CJ,N:C7,N:C4,S:SJ,S:S9,S:S8,S:S6,S:S4,S:S2,S:H4,S:DK,S:D6,S:D5,S:D3,S:C8,S:C3]
South plays 2!S. West leads the !C2. East plays the !CQ which you take with your !CA.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Count losers in the long-trump hand, (dummy this time).
You can make the contract if you just force out their big trumps. But there is another tempting possibility. You could enter dummy with the !DK and play the !H4, finessing East for the !HK. If the finesse is successful you could then discard dummy's !C loser on the !HA.
Should you or shouldn't you? [NEXT]
The reward for this play would be an overtrick. The price of failure would be going down in a cold contract. So obviously, at rubber bridge, you would be foolish to take such a risk. Playing Duplicate though, you might consider it. But let's say you decide to play safe. [NEXT]
Win the !CA and play a trump. As soon as you get in play another trump. The defenders will no doubt take their !C winner when they get in. East will no doubt win one of those high trump tricks, and he MAY lead a !H when he gets in. There you will be, trying to decide again whether to finesse . . .
Click for the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
As you see, the !HK is in the wrong place this time, but might be right the next time.
Usually you should not risk your contract for the sake of an overtrick.

Auction: 1NT | pass 2C pass 2D | pass 2NT pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 2!D]
Partner's 2!C is Stayman convention. With no 4-card Major suit your response is 2!D. Partner now bids 2NT. What do you say? [BID 3NT]
Partner's 2!C is Stayman convention. With no 4-card Major suit your response is 2!D. Partner now bids 2NT. What do you say?
The 2NT bid is invitational, asking you to bid game with a maximum, pass with a minimum. You have 17 points so you bid 3NT.
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
You put on dummy's !SJ, but East wins the !SA then continues with the !S9. Do you play your !SK now?
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
You need 3 more tricks, and they must come from !Ds. So you must drive out the !DA. The problem is that when the defenders win the !DA they may also take 4 !S tricks.
This is another case where you should hold up. Allow EW to win the second trick and take your  !SK only at trick #3. [NEXT]
Now you drive out the !DA. If West has it and also started with 5 !Ss you will go down. But if East has the !DA you will make the contract no matter how !Ss split.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
If you win the second !S East will still have a !S when he wins the !DA.
But if you hold up your !SK East will have no !S to put his partner in with.

Auction: 2NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 3NT]
Even if you wanted to show your !D suit how would you do it? If you bid 3!D it would be a transfer and if you bid 4!D you would have bypassed 3NT, your probable best contract.
But you didn't want to bid them anyway, you just wanted to bid 3NT, right?
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
The contract would be 3NT played by North.
To make South the declarer click ROTATE. [ROTATE]
[PLAY N:SK,N:S8,N:S5,N:HA,N:H2,N:DA,N:D7,N:D3,N:CA,N:CK,N:CQ,N:C7,N:C2,S:SQ,S:S9,S:H8,S:H4,S:H3,S:DK,S:DJ,S:DT,S:D8,S:D2,S:CJ,S:CT,S:C4]
West leads !H5, East plays the !HQ.
The first thing you need to decide is whether to hold up on the !H.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
First decide the holdup question. West led the !H5 and you can see the !H4, !H3 and !H2. Assuming West led fourth down he must have only a 4-card suit since there are no cards he could have lower than the !H5. With !Hs splitting 4-4 a holdup would do no good, and isn't necessary anyway.
So take the !HA. Then what? [NEXT]
You COULD try the !D finesse. Even if it loses it would establish several !D winners. However, if the defenders win just 1 !D trick they will quickly grab their 3 !H tricks and their !SA and put you down 1. [NEXT]
This is why it is important to make a Plan which includes a Winner count. You need just one additional winner and all you have to do to get it is play a !S honor.
Clickfor the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
When you can see all four hands, including the location of the !DQ, it kind of makes you wished you had finessed and gotten all those overtricks.
Good Bridge players like to take tricks, but they are not greedy.

Auction: 1NT | pass 2H pass 3S | pass 4NT pass 5D | pass 6S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 3!S]
Partner's 2!H bid is a transfer; he expects you to bid 2!S. However, with such great !S support and an outside doubleton your hand now revalues to 18 points - more than an opening 1NT. You indicate this with a jump to 3!S. This is called a "Super-Accept".  Partner now bids 4NT. What do you answer? [BID 5!D]
Partner's 2!H bid is a transfer; he expects you to bid 2!S. However, with such great !S support and an outside doubleton your hand now revalues to 18 points - more than an opening 1NT. You indicate this with a jump to 3!S. This is called a "Super-Accept".  Partner now bids 4NT. What do you answer?
Blackwood, and with one Ace you answer 5!D. Partner bids 6!S and everybody passes.
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
It won't matter where you take it, but assume you win in your hand.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Since the !D loser is a sure thing you will need to find somewhere to discard a !C. There are three possibilities:Finesse West for the !HQ. (50% chance)Try to drop the !HQ by ruffing the third round. (also about 50%)Establish a !D honor. (T0% certain) [NEXT]
First pull trumps, ending in dummy. It takes two rounds. Next play the !D5 toward your !DQ. West wins this and plays another !C. Win the !C, come to your hand with the !HK, then play your good !DQ, discarding dummy's losing !C.
You will need to ruff two !Hs in your hand, but the rest of the tricks are yours.
Click NEXT to see all four hands. [NEXT]
If they had been 3-1 you would have had to leave the last trump undrawn until after you had ruffed two !Hs in your hand.

Auction: 1NT | pass 2D pass 2H | pass 4H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 2!D]
With 10 points and a 6-card !H suit you want to transfer. You say 2!D and partner bids 2!H. What do you bid now? [BID 4!H]
With 10 points and a 6-card !H suit you want to transfer. You say 2!D and partner bids 2!H. What do you bid now?
You know you want to play in !Hs since partner will have at least 2 of them. Your problem is whether to merely invite with 3!H or go ahead and bid the game. Since partner has either 15, 16 or 17 points you should probably just bid 4!H. The worst thing that could happen is that partner would be playing game with only 25 points.
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
The contract would be 4!H played by North.
To make South the declarer click ROTATE. [ROTATE]
[PLAY N:SK,N:S4,N:HK,N:HT,N:H4,N:H3,N:DA,N:D7,N:D5,N:CK,N:CQ,N:CJ,N:C2,S:SA,S:SJ,S:S6,S:HQ,S:HJ,S:H9,S:H7,S:H5,S:H2,S:D6,S:D4,S:D2,S:C8]
South plays 4!H. West leads the !DK. Do you hold up or not?
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
There is no reason to hold up. Besides, you have bigger problems to deal with.
After you take the !DA at trick one you have four fast losers staring you in the face the instant you lose the lead. So do you pull trumps now? [NEXT]
No, you dare not touch trumps yet - remember those 4 fast losers. 
You cannot avoid the !HA and !CA, so you must get rid of one of the !D losers before you play trumps. [NEXT]
Win the !DA, play the !SK, then finesse the !SJ. If the finesse works discard a !D on the !SA, then pull trumps. If the finesse fails you will go down 2 instead of 1.
Click NEXT to see whether you made it or went down 2. [NEXT]
When the cards MUST lie in a particular way for the contract to be makeable, just assume that's the way they lie and go for it.

Auction: 1NT | pass 2C pass 2S | pass 2NT pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 2!S]
In response to partner's Stayman bid you show your 4-card !S suit. Partner now bids 2NT. What do you say? [BID 3NT]
In response to partners Stayman bid you show your 4-card !S suit. Partner now bids 2NT. What do you say?
You may disagree with the Stayman bid on 3-4-3-3 distribution. In any case, 2NT is invitational, so with 17 points you say 3NT.
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
West's !HJ lead probably means !Hs won't be 3-3, so you will need to get 2 !S tricks.
Suppose you win the first trick and plunk down the !SQ. If East wins with a doubleton !S honor you will only be able to win 1 !S since West will sit there with !S A 9 or !S K 9 behind your !S J T. [NEXT]
Instead, win the first trick in dummy and play a small !S toward the !S Q J T. East will play low and West must take his !S honor. But you can win his return, enter dummy and play another !S toward your hand. If you are lucky, East will be forced to play an honor and you can toss your !S5.
to see if you were lucky. [NEXT]
It only fails if West holds 4 or more !Ss headed by A K.

Auction: 1NT | pass 2NT pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 2NT]
A square hand, no 4-card Major, and 9 points. This is the very hand that the book said to bid 2NT with. And when you do, partner says 3NT which you pass.
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
The contract would be 3NT played by North.
To make South the declarer click ROTATE. [ROTATE]
[PLAY N:SA,N:S7,N:S4,N:HA,N:H9,N:H4,N:D8,N:D6,N:D3,N:CA,N:CK,N:CQ,N:C9,S:S8,S:S6,S:S5,S:HK,S:H7,S:H2,S:DA,S:DQ,S:D9,S:CT,S:C6,S:C4,S:C3]
South plays 3NT. West leads the !C2. You must be living right, West gives you a trick with the opening lead.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
You got a good break on the opening lead, now you need only one more winner. There is NO CHANCE of creating another winner in !Ss, !Hs or !Cs, so your second good break is that you know it will have to be !Ds. [NEXT]
You COULD lead toward dummy's !DQ, finessing West for the !DK. That would be a perfectly good 50% chance. But there is an even better play if you look carefully. [NEXT]
Play a !D from your hand and if West plays low insert the !D9. Much of the time East will win with the !DJ or !DT. If so you are no worse off, you play West for the !DK. But if it happens that West was dealt both the !DJ and !DT then East will have to win that trick with the !DK, or perhaps not even win it at all!
Click for the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
But what if West has played the !DT, splitting his honors?
You would put on dummy's !DQ and East would win the !DK. But you aren't down yet! Later you lead another !D toward dummy's !D A 9 and finesse West for the !DJ.

Auction: 2NT | pass 3C pass 3D | pass 4D pass 5D | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 3!D]
Partner's 3!C bid is Stayman; with no 4-card Major you respond 3!D. Partner now bids 4!D. What do you bid? [BID 5!D]
Partner's 3!C bid is Stayman; with no 4-card Major you respond 3!D. Partner now bids 4!D. What do you bid? 
Partner wouldn't bypass 3NT unless he was pretty distributional. His bid is invitational and you have excellent !D help so you try 5!D. 
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
You may be wishing partner had said 3NT. But at 3NT West might have led a !H, then you'd be wishing you were in 5!D.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
This looks so easy let's check it by trying a winner count as well. Five !Ds (after !DA is gone), the !S A K, the !HA and the !C A K Q. Yes that adds up to 11 winners.
Is there ANY danger here at all? [NEXT]
Whenever a hand looks easy you should ask yourself what could go wrong. And here the only thing that could go wrong is if one of your !S winners gets ruffed. So how can you prevent that possibility? [NEXT]
If East has a singleton !S, and West has the !DA you might go down if you win the first trick in your hand. West will take his !DA and play the !SJ. If you go up with dummy's !SK East will ruff and you will still have a !S loser.
The simple solution is to win the first trick with dummy's !SK. Now when West wins the !DA and leads another !S it's a different situation. East may well ruff, but if he does you will just play a low card - East will have ruffed your !S LOSER.
Click for the complete Deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
But you are very lucky that you took the time to read this hand so you know how to play safely!

Auction: 1NT | pass 2C pass 2H | pass 3NT pass pass | pass

You have 12 points and a 4-card !S suit. To find a possible 4-4 fit you bid 2!C, the Stayman convention. Partner bids 2!H. What do you bid now? [BID 3NT]
You have 12 points and a 4-card !S suit. To find a possible 4-4 fit you bid 2!C, the Stayman convention. Partner bids 2!H. What do you bid now?
You were hoping for a !S response, but so be it. You now bid 3NT, knowing partner will correct to 4!S if he was 4-4 in the Majors, or pass if he doesn't have 4 !Ss. He passes.
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
The contract would be 3NT played by North.
To make South the declarer click ROTATE. [ROTATE]
[PLAY N:SA,N:SJ,N:S6,N:HA,N:HQ,N:H5,N:H4,N:DK,N:DQ,N:D8,N:D2,N:C7,N:C3,S:SK,S:S8,S:S3,S:S2,S:H7,S:H6,S:H3,S:DA,S:DJ,S:DT,S:D4,S:CA,S:C4]
South plays 3NT.
West leads the !CK, East follows with the !CT. Do you hold up or not?
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
It makes no difference whether you hold up or not, (unless their !Cs are 7-2), so go ahead and take the first trick.
Either the !HQ or the !SJ MIGHT become your ninth trick. [NEXT]
If you try either finesse and it wins you will make your contract. If you try either finesse and it loses you will be set immediately with !Cs. Each finesse is a 50% shot.
Is there anything you can do to improve your chances? [NEXT]
Of course - otherwise the question wouldn't have been asked!You can combine two chances. Obviously you cannot take both finesses, but you can try to drop the !SQ in two pulls, and if she doesn't drop you still have the !H finesse to fall back on. So win the !CA, play 4 !D winners and the !S A K, then see whether you have to try the !H finesse. [NEXT]
But if she hadn't, you'd still have a 50% chance in !Hs.

Auction: 1NT pass 3C | pass 4C pass 6C | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 3!C]
You are thinking slam; your first step is a jump to 3!C.
Partner says 4!C; what do you bid? [BID 6!C]
You are thinking slam; your first step is a jump to 3!C.
Partner says 4!C; what do you bid?
With partner agreeing !Cs, one possibility would be for you to cue-bid your !HA. Another would be just to bid 6!C. You choose the second approach.
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
East plays low and you win the !HQ.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Your best chance at another winner is the !D suit. West MAY have both the !D K Q, if not you will have to establish the suit. [NEXT]
At trick 2 pull just one round of trumps with the !CK. Then play a small !D, finessing the !DJ when West plays low. East takes the !DQ and returns the !SJ. [NEXT]
Go up with your !SK, you may need the entry to dummy later. Pull one more trump with the !CQ, then play a small !D to dummy's !DA. Ruff a !D with a high trump, West discarding.  [NEXT]
Enter dummy with the !CA, pulling West's last trump as you do, and ruff one more !D, establishing the fifth !D. Enter dummy with the !SA and discard your losing !S on the good !D.
Click NEXT to see the full Deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
If the suit splits evenly perhaps you can be a little sloppy and still get by.
But in cases like this one, with a 4-2 split, you cannot afford to waste an entry too early.

Auction: 1NT | pass 2D pass 2H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 2!D]
This situation comes up a lot. You don't have enough points to advance partner's 1NT opening, but you have a "long suit" that might play better than notrump. If "long suit" is 6 !Hs or 6 !Ss then pretty clearly you should transfer partner to that suit and then pass. But with only 5 of the Major it is tougher to say that 1NT would be an inferior contract. Here's a suggestion - with fewer than 9 points and a 5-card Major, transfer to that suit when you have a singleton or void, otherwise pass 1NT. So here you bid 2!D and partner says 2!H. What do you bid now? [BID pass]
This situation comes up a lot. You don't have enough points to advance partner's 1NT opening, but you have a "long suit" that might play better than notrump. If "long suit" is 6 !Hs or 6 !Ss then pretty clearly you should transfer partner to that suit and then pass. But with only 5 of the Major it is tougher to say that 1NT would be an inferior contract. Here's a suggestion - with fewer than 9 points and a 5-card Major transfer to that suit when you have a singleton, pass with no singleton. So here you bid 2!D and partner says 2!H. What do you bid now?
Of course you pass, that was the whole point of the transfer.
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
The contract would be 2!H played by North.
To make South the declarer click ROTATE. [ROTATE]
[PLAY N:SA,N:ST,N:S5,N:S2,N:H8,N:H6,N:DA,N:DK,N:D3,N:CA,N:C9,N:C6,N:C2,S:S6,S:HA,S:H7,S:H5,S:H3,S:H2,S:D7,S:D6,S:D4,S:D2,S:C8,S:C5,S:C4]
South plays 2!H. West leads the !SQ, East playing the !S7.
 We will all agree that you win the first trick with your !SA.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
In suit contracts it is usual to count losers. Sometimes in low level suit contracts it makes things clearer if you count winners. Here you have 4 high card winners in your hand plus the Ace of trumps in dummy.
Your plan will therefore be to make as many of dummy's small trumps as you can. [NEXT]
At trick 2 ruff a !S in dummy. Pull one trump with the !HA. Play a !C back to your !CA and ruff another !S. [NEXT]
Got the idea? Play a !D to your !DK and ruff your last !S in dummy. Then play the !DA. If you've been counting you have taken the first 8 tricks. A good thing, too, because you aren't going to take any more.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
Here is an example of when that principle is NOT correct; when you need to get several ruffs with small trumps.

Auction: 2NT | pass 3C pass 3H | pass 3NT pass 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 3!H]
Partner's 3!C bid is Stayman; with 4 cards in both Majors you respond 3!H. Partner now bids 3NT.  What do you bid? [BID 4!S]
Partner's 3!C bid is Stayman; with 4 cards in both Majors you respond 3!H. Partner now bids 3NT.  What do you bid? 
Partner would not use Stayman unless he held a 4-card Major suit himself. Since he didn't like your !Hs it follows that he must have 4 !Ss.
So you correct the 3NT contract to 4!S. 
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
If you had left it in 3NT you'd have 8 top tricks and a !S finesse for 9.
But you're in 4!S. Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
If you can guess the !SQ your problems are over. But just in case you dislike those 50% guesses, try to find a better Plan. [NEXT]
Another possibility is that a defender holds either a singleton or doubleton !SQ so you can pick up the suit by leading !S A K. This is smaller than a 50% chance. [NEXT]
But there is more to the odds than that. Suppose you try the second possibility and play off both the !SA and !SK but the !SQ does NOT drop. You are still not dead! You just leave the !SQ out there and start on !Hs. As long as the defender who holds the !SQ has at least 3 !Hs he will be unable to ruff until after you have discarded dummy's !D loser.
The extra chance makes this Plan your best hope.
Click NEXT to see which plan works. [NEXT]
You could have gone down easily by playing West for the !SQ.
Or you could have made it whoever held the !SQ by using the "improved" plan.

Auction: 1NT 2H X | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID double]
Sometimes the opponents make overcalls which disrupt the smooth flow of your side's bidding. You and your partner need to have ways of dealing with these disruptions. One possibility is the lebensohl convention which is used a few times in these T0 Deals. There are lots of other methods out there, and you may not care for lebensohl. One of the big reasons we use it is that it includes a penalty double - some other methods use the double for other reasons.
So, in lebensohl an immediate double of their overcall of partner's 1NT opener is for penalties. Just like this one - punish them if they dare try to disrupt your bidding!
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
To see all the hands click NEXT. [NEXT]
This is the only Deal like this out of the T0.
No Declarer Plan for you to make, no tricks to look for.
Just play through the deal as you think it might go and see how many tricks you can set East. Enjoy.

Auction: 1NT | pass 4NT pass 6NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 6NT]
Partner's 4NT bid is not Blackwood, it is the Quantitative 4NT. He is unsure whether to bid 6NT or not, so is inviting you to do so.
With 15 points you are supposed to pass. With 17 points you are supposed to bid 6NT. Wouldn't you know it, 16 points. Today you feel bold, so you say 6NT.
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
East plays the !HA and returns the !H3.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Winner List: !S = 4 : !H = 1 : !D = 2 : !C = 4 :: Total = 11
One trick is already lost and at first glance it looks like your only slim chance will be for the !D Q J to fall doubleton.
But a dummy has a very important card, the !H9. You know from the opening lead that West holds the !HT, so if he happens to hold the only guard in !Ds you will be able to squeeze him in the red suits.  [NEXT]
You don't even have to do anything special. Play your 4 !C winners, then 3 !S winners. [NEXT]
Now play the !SJ and watch West's discard. If he throws the !HT dummy's !H9 will become a winner. If he doesn't throw the !HT then you know dummy's !H9 is worthless so discard it and hope the !Ds are good.
Click NEXT to see. [NEXT]
But not always. Sometimes they just happen, like this one. You were really hoping for the !DQ and !DJ to fall and you fell into the squeeze instead.

Auction: 1NT 2S 3H | pass 4H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 3!H]
When partner opens 1NT, interference can easily gum up your smooth bidding sequences. Playing the lebensohl convention, your 3!H bid shows a 5-card suit and is forcing to game.
It doesn't always work out so well, but here partner had an easy 4!H bid.
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
Whatever you play, East takes the !S A K J and then plays a small !C. West started with just one !S.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Don't let that Question Mark by the !H losers mislead you - if you are going to make this contract you cannot lose a !H trick at all!Is there any hope? [NEXT]
The odds aren't good, but you actually have TWO possibilities for success. If West holds the singleton !HK, you can play a small !H to dummy's !HA, dropping the !HK, then finesse East out of his !HJ. Or, if East holds the singleton !HJ you can play your !HQ, finessing West for the !HK and at the same time smothering East's !HJ.
Which basket will you put your eggs into? [NEXT]
The answer is simple Bridge math!East started with 6 !Ss leaving him 7 cards outside the !S suit. West started with just 1 !S, leaving him with 12 cards outside the !S suit. Obviously East is much more likely to have a singleton !H than West.
So you win the !CA in your hand, play the !HQ and let it ride if West does not cover.
Then you click NEXT to see how things turned out. [NEXT]
But to tell the truth, the Bridge math wasn't really complete. Distribution-wise it was just fine, but there is also the question of strength.
The fact that East overcalled makes it more likely that he holds more high cards than West, and this skews the odds toward East holding the !HK.
But think about it. If East does in fact hold the singleton !HK, and if you cleverly drop it by playing dummy's !HA it won't help you. You will then have to lose a trick to West's !HJ.

East is the Danger hand because if he wins a !C he might lead through your precarious !HK. West wins the !CJ, but you win the game. West cannot profitably play !Hs, so he will probably continue with another !D. But since the !CQ will now drop under the !C A K you have your ninth trick.
 for the complete deal. [NEXT]

[PLAY N:SA,N:S4,N:S3,N:HK,N:H7,N:H3,N:DK,N:DQ,N:D2,N:CA,N:CT,N:C7,N:C2,S:SK,S:S8,S:S6,S:S2,S:HQ,S:H8,S:DA,S:D8,S:D3,S:CK,S:C5,S:C4,S:C3]
South plays 3NT. West leads the !H6.
First big decision. Which !H do you play from dummy?
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
The Rule of Eleven tells you there are 5 !Hs in North, East and South which are higher than the !H6. You and dummy hold 4 of them so you can place East with just 1. The missing high cards are !H A J T 9. Elementary, Watson; East must hold the !HT because from !H A J T 6, !H A T 9 6 or !H J T 9 6 West would NOT have led the !H6. So your first smart move is to play dummy's !HQ, which holds the trick. What next? [NEXT]
You need to find one more winner and your best chance is the !C suit. You will need a 3-2 split in the suit, but you must establish the !C winner without letting East get the lead. East is the Danger Hand because he can play a !H throughyour !H K 7. Therefore it would be unwise to play !CA, !CK, then another !C because East is very likely to be the one with 3 !Cs. [NEXT]
Did you get it? Play a small !C toward your hand and put on the !CT if East plays low. You don't expect the !CT to win the trick, it is more of a duck than a finesse. West takes this with his !CJ but he can do you no harm. If he continues with !Hs your !HK will be a second stopper. If he plays any other suit you will scamper home with your 9 tricks, which of course now include those 3 !Cs.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
But what if East had figured out what you were going to try and played his !CQ when you led from dummy?
He would have been very, very sorry. You would have had no choice but to win the trick, and when West's !CJ fell on the next trick you would have all 4 !C tricks!

Then, the next time they get the lead they will take their !H winner. You need to get rid of that !H loser BEFORE you start on trumps. [NEXT]
Play a small !D to the !DK. East will take this and play another !H to your !HK. Play your !DQ and discard dummy's !H loser. Now you might just as well ruff that !H in dummy, (with the !S7 to be safe), and play trumps from that side. [PLAY N:SK,N:SQ,N:S9,N:HK,N:H7,N:H5,N:H4,N:DK,N:DT,N:CA,N:C8,N:C4,N:C2,S:S7,S:S5,S:S2,S:HA,S:HQ,S:H6,S:DA,S:DQ,S:D6,S:D5,S:D3,S:C7,S:C3]
South plays 3NT. West leads the !S6; East plays the !SJ.
Your immediate problem is whether or not to hold up. ? ? ?
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
There is some merit in a holdup. East is likely to have just 2 !Ss, so a holdup would exhaust his cards in the suit. If he later got the lead he would have no !Ss. On the other hand, East might well switch to !Cs, and that would certainly be unwelcome. Finally, if you do win the first !S you have another stopper if you can prevent East from getting the lead. So win the first trick with the !SK. Notice that by winning with the !SK you keep West in the dark as to whether you or East has the !SQ.
You need just one more trick, and either red suit might split 3-3. So is that your plan? Lead out red winners and hope? [NEXT]
Truthfully, that wouldn't be a terrible plan. The chance of a 3-3 split in a suit is about 36%. But since you need either of two 36% chances that comes to almost 60% (if you aren't Math oriented don't worry about it, you can trust me).
There's a safer approach though; remember you only need 4 !D tricks, not 5. [NEXT]
There is a wonderful "safety play" that will practically guarantee your contract. Enter dummy with a !H, then play a small !D toward your hand and finesse with your !DT! West may win with the !DJ, but even if he does he is the Safe Hand and cannot play a !S without giving you a trick. And whatever else he could play you would win and make 4 !D tricks. In the actual Deal the !D finesse actually works and you make all 5 tricks in the suit.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]

Your contract just became a sure thing!Play the !CK to strip both your hands of !Cs. Lead dummy's last !D,  and when East plays low, finesse the !D9. If the finesse wins, discard a !H from dummy on your good !D. But if the finesse loses to West's !DJ, he will be endplayed and have to lead a !H into your !H A Q or give you a ruff/sluff with a !C. And on top of that your fourth !D will be good.

Auction: 1NT | pass 2H pass 2S | pass 4S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 2!S]

Auction: pass 1NT | pass 2S pass 3C | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 3!C]
Many people play Jacoby Transfer convention. Not all of them play that an initial response of 2!S asks partner to bid  3!C. You use that here and reply 3!C. Everybody passes.
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
South plays 3!C. West leads the !HQ. East takes the !H A K, then switches to the !SQ.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Instead of trying to estimate how many !C losers you may have, just tell yourself that you can only afford to lose one! Then you base your plan on that requirement. [NEXT]
You might as well win the !SA. You need to play the trumps from dummy and the easiest way to get there is to play !D A K, then ruff a !D. Now play a !C from dummy and play what from your hand?  [NEXT]
You may think it is a guess whether to play the !CK or !CJ, but there is no guessing involved here. You must play the !CJ because East cannot possibly hold the !CA. Just go back and look at the bidding again. The East hand failed to open the bidding in first seat. And since then you have seen the !H A K and the !SQ come out of the hand. That's 9 points and the !CA would bring that total to 13. Since he passed it follows that he doesn't have the !CA. Of course he might or might not have the !CQ, you just have to hope for that card.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
But good players don't forget, they use every bit of information they can get to help them make their contracts. That's why they make more contracts.

Auction: 2NT | pass 4NT pass 6NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 6NT]
Partner's 4NT bid is not Blackwood, it is the Quantitative 4NT. He is unsure whether to bid 6NT or not, so is inviting you to do so.
With 20 points you are supposed to pass. With 21 points you are supposed to bid 6NT. The evaluations probably aren't that accurate, but at least you have an excuse to bid 6NT.
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
East plays the !CJ which you take with your !CK.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
There are two places you might find your twelfth winner. You can finesse East for the !SQ; this is a 50% chance. Or, the !Ds might split 3-3; this is about a 40% chance. [NEXT]
If you try the !S finesse and it fails you will go down even if the !Ds are splitting 3-3.
If you play !DA, !DK then another !D, a 4-2 !D split will defeat you even if the !SQ was with East. [NEXT]
Two chances are always better than one. The way to take both chances is to duck a !D at trick 2. Win whatever the defenders play next and then test the !Ds. If they do split your last !D will be trick #12. But if they don't split you can still try the !S finesse.
Click NEXT to see. [NEXT]

Auction: 1NT | pass 2C pass 2S | pass 2NT pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis: The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 2!C] With 9 points you have just enough to respond. And with a 4-card Major suit you should use Stayman so you bid 2!C. Partner duly replies 2!S. What do you say now? [BID 2NT] With 9 points you have just enough to respond. And with a 4-card Major suit you should use Stayman so you bid 2!C. Partner duly replies 2!S. What do you say now? You don't have a 4-4 !H fit, so you invite the notrump game by bidding 2NT. Partner raises to 3NT. Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT] The contract would be 3NT played by North. To make South the declarer click ROTATE. [ROTATE] [PLAY N:SK,N:S8,N:S6,N:S2,N:H7,N:H5,N:DA,N:DK,N:D7,N:CA,N:CK,N:C6,N:C3,S:SA,S:S9,S:HQ,S:HT,S:H6,S:H3,S:D8,S:D5,S:D2,S:CQ,S:CJ,S:C9,S:C4] South plays 3NT and West leads the !DQ. Should you win or hold up? A pretty good argument against holding up could be that they might switch to !Ss. However, say you do in fact hold up and that West does in fact continue !Ds with East following suit. Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT] Don't worry any more about the !Ds since there is nothing more you can do. Instead, worry about where that one more winner is going to come from. The answer will have to be: from the !H suit. [NEXT] You might be tempted to take your 4 !C tricks right away, but avoid the temptation. The !C suit is your convenient transportation back and forth between hands. You will have to lose at least 2 !H tricks in order to set up 1 winner, and by the time you do that the defenders will have established at least 1 more !D trick. What that means is that you cannot afford 3 !H losers. So how will you play the !Hs? [NEXT] You should play West for the !HJ plus one of the big ones. This is a better chance than playing him for both the !H A K. So play a !H toward dummy and insert the !HT when West plays low. East wins with the !HA and clears the !Ds. Play another !H toward dummy's !HQ. West can take his !HK and cash his !D winner but dummy's !HQ will be your ninth trick. Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT] [RESET] West could hold both the !HA and !HK, in which case leading toward dummy's !HQ would be the winning play. West could hold EITHER !H A J x OR!H K J x in which case finessing dummy's !HJ would be the winning play. This is the more likely distribution of the two.

Auction: 1NT | 2H 3D pass 3NT | pass pass pass |
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 3NT]
Partner's 3!D bid shows a 5-card suit and is forcing to game. While 5!D is possibly the best contract your double !H stopper should sway you to 3NT instead. This is the old "9 tricks are easier than 11" principle.
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
As expected, West attacks in his !H suit.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Even if East holds both black Queens, (not likely), you can only finesse your way to 8 tricks. Since you need 9 tricks you must establish the !D suit.
If West holds both the !DA and !DK then you are going down, because they will win the race to establish !Hs before you can establish !Ds. [NEXT]
But when the !DA and !DK are in different hands you have a good chance for success; it depends on East having no !H at the time he takes his !D winner. [NEXT]
So you should hold up on the first !H trick and win the second. If West started with 6 !Hs then East will be out. So whether he wins his !D trick first or second he still won't be able to continue !Hs.
to see all four hands. [NEXT]
On the other hand, if West takes the first !D trick he can certainly drive out your last !H stopper. But then, when East takes HIS !D winner he will have no !H.
Finally, if West had only a 5-card !H suit, good defense would beat you. But they have to be sure East wins the first !D trick, and they might slip up.

Auction: 2NT | pass 3C pass 3D | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis: The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 3!C] Partner's 2NT opening shows 20-21 points so you know you want to be in game. To find out which game you bid a Stayman 3!C. Partner replies 3!D. What do you say now? [BID 3NT] Partner's 2NT opening shows 20-21 points so you know you want to be in game. To find out which game you bid a Stayman 3!C. Partner replies 3!D. What do you say now? You don't have a 4-4 !H fit, so you bid 3NT. Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT] The contract would be 3NT played by North. To make South the declarer click ROTATE. [ROTATE] [PLAY N:SJ,N:S9,N:S6,N:HA,N:H8,N:DA,N:DK,N:DT,N:D5,N:D3,N:CA,N:CK,N:C6,S:SK,S:S5,S:HJ,S:H7,S:H5,S:H3,S:DQ,S:D6,S:D2,S:C8,S:C5,S:C4,S:C2] South plays 3NT. West leads the !S3. Your first problem is which !S to play from dummy. That is an easy problem. If you play the !SK you might lose the first five or six tricks. If you play low you guarantee a !S stopper. East plays the !SA and returns the !S7 to dummy's !SK. West plays the !S2 on this trick. Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT] You need 2 more winners, and you need to get them before you lose the lead because it appears that West can cash 3 more !S tricks. That means you need all 5 !D tricks. The good news is that the 5 missing !Ds will split 3-2 about two-thirds of the time. The bad news is that they will be 4-1 about one-third of the time. Can you protect yourself against a 4-1 break? [NEXT] Maybe and maybe not. If West has !D J x x x there won't be anything you can do about it. But if East has this holding then you can succeed if you play your cards right. [NEXT] Did you like that "play your cards right" quip?First play a !D to your !DK; both defenders follow. Next play a !D to dummy's !DQ. West discards a !C. You are conveniently in dummy so you play dummy's last !D and East's !D J 9 are caught in a pincer movement by your !D A T 5. Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT] [RESET] Suppose your first !D play had been dummy's !DQ. You could make your contract if you play a small !D and finesse the !DT. But at that point you wouldn't know whether the !Ds were splitting evenly or not. You'd be risking defeat on a hand where everybody who played for the 3-2 split was making the contract. By taking the SECOND !D trick with dummy's !DQ the 4-1 split is exposed at the right time.

Analysis:

Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Only one more winner is needed. You should play a low !S from dummy in the hope that West will lead the suit again, giving you a trick with your !SJ (you know West holds !SQ). In fact, you should even give him some incentive to play another !S by dropping your !S9, pretending to hold just the !S J 9. But West noticed his partner's discouraging !S2 and switched to the !C8. [NEXT]
You try the !CJ but East plays the !CQ and you have to win with your !CK. [NEXT]
Your chances for success are slipping away and you are down to your last hope. Your !SJ is a threat that only West can guard against. If West also is the defender with long !Hs then he would also have to guard dummy's fourth !H. In that case you could squeeze him. But there is one important play you must make for the squeeze to function. [NEXT]
You must play dummy's !SA to unblock so your !SJ can be the threat you need. Then play the !HA, !CA and 5 !D winners. [NEXT]
If West has thrown the !SQ you win your !SJ and dummy's two high !Hs. But since he probably held onto the !SQ you just play a !H to dummy and hope all three !Hs are winners.
Click NEXT to see if they are. [NEXT]
You were lucky it wasn't East with the 4 !Hs.

Auction: 1NT | pass 2H pass 3S | pass 4S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 3!S]
Partner expects you to bid 2!S.
But your hand has suddenly increased in value - with the known !S fit you add another point for your doubleton and you have 18 points. So you jump to 3!S; this is called a Super-Accept. But so what. Partner just bids the game anyway.
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
East plays the !HK, then !HA, then !H5.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
You need to eliminate two losers. If West has the !DK a finesse will save one loser. If !Cs split 3-2 that will eliminate one loser. And of course your !HJ is ready to provide an immediate discard. [NEXT]
So what are you going to discard right now on that !HJ? It looks obvious to discard the !DQ; then if the !Cs do split 3-2 (68% chance) you will be home free, losing only two !Hs and one!C. [NEXT]
Throwing the !DQ is a bad idea. And basically unnecessary. If the !Cs are splitting 3-2 you don't need to keep a fourth !C in both hands. So discard a small !C from dummy and keep the !DQ just in case the !Cs turn out 4-1 and you have to fall back on the !D finesse. 
Click NEXT to see why. [NEXT]
After you pull trumps you play the top two !Cs and discover (too late) that you cannot set up a !C winner.
But what if the !DK was actually with East, and the !Cs were splitting 3-2 all the time?
Click for an alternate possibility. [NEXT]
You pull trumps first, then play two top !Cs. When both defenders follow you give up a !C. West wins and plays a !D, but you go up with dummy's !DA, enter your hand with a trump and NOW discard that !DQ on your good !C.

Auction: 2H 2NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass |
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 2NT]
You should be sure you and partner are on the same page with this bid. A 2NT overcall over a Weak-2 opener shows the same hand as a 1NT overcall over a 1 of a suit opener. In other words, 15-18 points, and at least 1 (preferably 2), stoppers in their suit.
Partner, who is on the same page, bids 3NT.
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
As expected, West leads his partner's !H suit.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
You need 5 more winners. This is important to keep in mind.
You can establish at most 1 winner in !Ds, 2 in !Ss, and 3 in !Cs. Since you must work on both !Ss and !Cs, you don't need to try for anything extra in !Ds. [NEXT]
If East has both black Aces you will go down, but you know that he cannot have two outside Aces with a 6-card !H suit headed by the Q J and still open with a weak 2-bid. So West must have at least one of the black Aces. [NEXT]
If you could guess which Ace East holds you could work on that suit first. He would win it, then get his !Hs established, but wouldn't be able to get back in to cash them.
But better than guessing, you should just holdup on the first !H trick and win the next one. Then it won't matter which Ace you knock out first because West will not have a !H to play in either case.
Click NEXT to see. [NEXT]
If you win the first trick and then play !Cs, you will be unlucky. West will  take his !CA and play his last !H. Then when East takes the !SA he will set you with !H tricks.
If you hold up on first trick luck won't come into it. It will no longer matter which black suit you establish first.

Auction: 1NT | 2H 3C pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 3!C]
After the overcall of your partner's opening 1NT you must make a quick decision with this type of hand:Force to game or settle for partscore. Using lebensohl, a suit bid at the 3-level shows a 5-card or longer suit and is game forcing. You go for it by bidding 3!C (not Stayman) and partner says 3NT.
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
The contract would be 3NT played by North.
To make South the declarer click ROTATE. [ROTATE]
[PLAY N:SA,N:S7,N:S4,N:HA,N:HK,N:H5,N:DA,N:D6,N:D3,N:CJ,N:C8,N:C5,N:C2,S:SQ,S:S6,S:S3,S:H8,S:H4,S:H2,S:DQ,S:D8,S:CK,S:CQ,S:CT,S:C9,S:C6]
South plays 3NT. West leads the !HQ. You must make an immediate decision whether to hold up or not.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Of course the !C suit will produce 4 winners so you need just one more in !Ss or !Ds.
First the question of holding up or not. The reason for a hold-up play is to be sure that when East gains the lead he has no !Hs remaining. But in this Deal you can place most of the strength with West so you don't need to hold up. And, in fact, there is a good reason why you shouldn't. [NEXT]
Win the first trick with your !HK and immediately play a !C, taken by West's !CA. He plays the !HJ which you win with your !HA. East followed suit to the second !H! [NEXT]
West has 3 !H winners in his hand. There is a good chance that he has the !SK and !DK as well. So if you play either of those suits, leading toward the Queen, West will jump up with his King and put you down 1. So instead, play a !C winner, and when West shows out, play your last !H! West will smile as he takes his three !H winners but then he will frown when he realizes he must lead away from one of his Kings! You, of course, will jump up with dummy's Queen of that suit for your ninth trick.
Click for the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
Always keep in the back of your mind the possibility of an elimination play. In this Deal that meant you needed to refuse the hold-up because you would need the third !H to throw West in with.

Auction: 1NT | pass 2H pass 2S | pass 3S pass 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 2!S]
Partner's 2!H bid is a transfer; you respond 2!S. Partner now bids 3!S.  What do you bid? [BID 4!S]
Partner's 2!H bid is a transfer; you respond 2!S. Partner now bids 3!S.  What do you bid? 
You wouldn't have chosen !Ss for a trump suit.
But you aren't doing the choosing, partner is. He has set the trump suit as !Ss and asks that you bid game if you have a maximum 1NT opening. So you bid 4!S, as instructed.
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
West leads !HK, East plays !HJ. You have no reason to hold up so you win the !HA.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Things look simple. You can afford one !S loser so as long as they split 3-2 you will succeed. So you play !SA, !SK; West follows to the first and discards a !D on the second. [NEXT]
OK, East has two trump tricks, but don't give up. Maybe, just maybe, there is a way out. Check your winners:You have won 3 tricks - !HA and !S A K. You have 4 more top winners - !DA and !C A K Q. If you can somehow add 3 more small trumps that will be the T you need. [NEXT]
Play dummy's !D7 to your !DA, then ruff a !D. Play a !C to your hand and ruff another !D. Play another !C to your hand and ruff your last !D. While you are ruffing these three !Ds East is helplessly following suit.
Now play to your good !C while East again has to follow suit.
You have taken the first T tricks. Poor East is going to end up ruffing his partner's !D winner with one of his master trumps.
Click NEXT to see all four hands. [NEXT]
When they split badly, sometimes you can recover by ruffing with small trumps while the trump-heavy defender has to follow suit.
This is called "trump elopement".

Auction: 2NT | pass 6NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 6NT]
Sometimes bidding is easy. Partner has 20 or 21 points, balanced. You have 13 points, balanced. Total = 33 or 34 points, balanced. So you close your eyes and bid 6NT.
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
The contract would be 6NT played by North.
To make South the declarer click ROTATE. [ROTATE]
[PLAY N:SA,N:SK,N:SJ,N:HA,N:H7,N:H2,N:DK,N:DQ,N:D7,N:D6,N:CA,N:C9,N:C4,S:S8,S:S7,S:S6,S:HQ,S:H8,S:H5,S:DA,S:DJ,S:D2,S:CK,S:CQ,S:CJ,S:C3]
South plays 6NT. West leads the !DT. Too bad West didn't lead a !S. Oh, well.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
There is no way to get more than 4 winners in each minor suit, so you need to win either the !SJ or !HQ.
Which one should you try? [NEXT]
Why not try both? If you make sure you try them in the right order you can have both chances. [NEXT]
Suppose you lead a small !S from dummy and play your !SJ, and it loses to West's !SQ. If you then try leading a small !H toward dummy's !HQ, obviously the defender with the !HK will grab it to set the contract.
Instead, try the effect of leading toward the !HQ first. If West has the !HK then you will succeed in creating the extra winner you need. But what if you play the !HQ and East takes it with his !HK? Too bad, but at least you are not dead yet. You still have a chance to finesse  East for the !SQ.
Click for the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
There are two critical cards, the !SQ and the !HK. However they are not the same degree of criticality.
If the !SQ is in a favorable position, (with East), you are always going to make your contract no matter which you try first.
But if only the !HK is in a favorable position, (with West), you can make the contract only if you try !Hs first.

Auction: 1NT | pass 2D pass 2H | pass 3NT pass 4H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 2!H]
Partner's 2!D bid is a transfer; you respond 2!H. Partner now bids 3NT.  What do you bid? [BID 4!H]
Partner's 2!D bid is a transfer; you respond 2!H. Partner now bids 3NT.  What do you bid? 
Partner tells you that he has enough points to be in game, and that he holds exactly 5 !Hs. With your 3 !Hs you know of an 8-card Major fit so you correct the contract to 4!H.
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
You win the opening lead with your !CQ.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
The 2 !D losers are unavoidable, and even you will have to give up a trick to the Ace of trumps. So you have to make sure not to lose a second !H. [NEXT]
Win the !CQ and play a small !H to dummy's !HJ, which holds the trick. [NEXT]
I hope you didn't continue drawing trumps by playing the !HK. If you did then you are going down in an ice-cold contract.
The way to lose only one !H trick is to keep leading toward dummy's honors. So come to your hand with a black card and play another !H in that direction, leading through West's !HA. When you win that trick repeat the maneuver.
Click NEXT to see why this was necessary (but you've already figured it out, right?). [NEXT]
In fact it would only occur perhaps one time in seven.
But there is no reason to go down once every seven times when you don't need to.

Auction: 1NT | pass 2C pass 2H | pass 6H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 2!H]
The 2!C bid was Stayman, so you bid your !Hs.
Partner takes the direct approach and puts you in slam.
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
West finds their best lead, exposing your !C loser right off the bat.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
If you can guess the !H finesse correctly you will make 7, discarding dummy's !C loser on the fourth !D. But if you guess wrong they will immediately set you with a !C trick. [NEXT]
There is a better way - one that combines two chances. Win the !CA. Then play your !HA and !HK. If the !HQ happens to fall, pull the last trump and run your winners.
If the !HQ DOESN'T fall, (she won't of course), switch to !Ds. On the fourth round of !Ds discard dummy's !C, whether it is ruffed with the !HQ or not.
Click NEXT to see the complete deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
But playing the deal as described will win whenever the !HQ is doubleton, OR when the player with the protected !HQ holds at least 3 !Ds.
Pretty good odds, better than the going rate for finesses, which is 50% off.
There was an alternate plan, just as good. After taking the two top trumps, run the !Ss, discarding two !Cs from your hand. As you see, either would have worked.

Auction: 1NT | pass 2NT pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 3NT]
Partner's 2NT bid invites you to bid game if you have a maximum hand. You aren't thrilled by all the Quacks in your hand but with 17 points you bid 3NT.
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
East wins the first trick with the !SK and returns the !S9. West plays the !S3 under your !SJ.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
You need 2 more tricks, and the !D suit will provide them after you drive out the !DA.
Is that what you should do? [NEXT]
That is definitely NOT what you should do. West led the !S5, then played the !S3 to the second trick. You have seen the !S4 and !S2 so it is clear that West started with a 5-card suit. That means East still has a !S. The instant you play a !D one of the defenders will grab the !DA and West will take his three more !S tricks.
As much as you hate to put your contract in the hands of a 50% finesse chance, that is what you must do. Forget the !D suit and finesse West for the !HK, trying for two extra tricks in !Hs.
to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
So you have to play well and stay away from !Ds.

Auction: 1NT pass 4C | pass 4S pass 6H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 4!C]
There would be nothing wrong with a transfer bid here, but probably no advantage either. What you really want to know is how many Aces partner has. So you ask him with a Gerber 4!C bid.
Partner says 4!S (2 Aces), what do you bid? [BID 6!H]
There would be nothing wrong with a transfer bid here, but probably no advantage either. What you really want to know is how many Aces partner has. So you ask him with a Gerber 4!C bid.
Partner says 4!S (2 Aces), what do you bid?
Looking at three possible !C losers you bid 6!H.
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
The first trick is easy; you win with dummy's !SA.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
It can't do any good to ruff your fourth !C in dummy because you would have to lose two before that could happen. Of course one of your !Cs can be discarded on dummy's !SK but what about the other two? [NEXT]
Suppose you win the !S and unblock the !DA. Play !HK, then to dummy's !HA. Take one !C discard on the !SK, then play the !DQ and discard a second !C.
It won't work. You would establish the !D for your last discard but you have no entry to it. [NEXT]
This will work. At trick 2 discard the !DA on dummy's !SK. Play the !DQ and discard a !C when East doesn't cover. West will take the !DK and attack !Cs but you are in control now. You win your !CA, pull trumps, ending in dummy, and discard the remaining 2 !C losers on dummy's !D J T.
Click for the full layout. [NEXT]
If East held the !DK the play would be slightly different; you would have to ruff when he covered. But the result would be the same.
Did you notice that you started with 3 !C losers and no !D loser, but you ended up losing 1 !D and no !Cs?

Auction: 1NT | 2D 2NT pass 3C | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 3!C]
Partner's 2NT is the lebensohl convention. He requests that you bid 3!C as a relay, which you do. Partner now bids 3NT. What do you say? [BID pass]
Partner's 2NT is the lebensohl convention. He requests that you bid 3!C as a relay, which you do. Partner now bids 3NT. What do you say?
When partner bids 3NT AFTER the lebensohl 2NT, he is suggesting you play there, and he guarantees a stopper in their suit. You are happy to pass.
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
West attacks in !Ds and you must make an immediate choice. Hold up, win in dummy, or win in your hand.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
First decide about what to do at trick #1. If you hold up and West plays another !D, no harm will be done. But probably no good will be done either because West is likely to have 6 !Ds, leaving East with just a singleton anyway. But what if West pockets the one !D trick and switches to !Hs, a suit where you only have one stopper? Since that might turn out badly, you should NOT hold up.
As to which hand to win it in, that's easy. You need to preserve any dummy entries that you can so you win the first trick with your !DK. [NEXT]
Now you establish some !C winners. You play the !CJ and both defenders play low. [NEXT]
You have to assume that defenders good enough to hold up their !CA at the first opportunity will be good enough to do it on the second play also. But you can thwart them by next playing your !CT and overtaking with dummy's !CQ. Even if they do hold up again you can continue with another !C from dummy to establish the suit while you still have the !DA for an entry.
Click for the complete Deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
Then you will lose all those !C tricks in dummy.

Auction: 1D 1NT | pass 2D pass 2H | pass 3NT pass 4H | pass pass pass
Analysis: The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 2!D] The question is: Do you use Transfers after a 1NT OVERCALL? And in particular, can you bid the opponent's suit and have it mean a transfer instead of a cue-bid? This is something you and your partner need to agree on - as for me and my partner, we think 2!D is a transfer. Partner replies 2!H. What do you say now? [BID 3NT] The question is: Do you use Transfers after a 1NT OVERCALL? And in particular, can you bid the opponent's suit and have it mean a transfer instead of a cue-bid? This is something you and your partner need to agree on - as for me and my partner, we think 2!D is a transfer. Partner replies 2!H. What do you say now? With 10 points you are between Invitational and Game-forcing. Which means you bid either 2NT or 3NT, whichever suits your fancy. Today let's say it is 3NT which partner converts to 4!H. Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT] The contract would be 4!H played by North. To make South the declarer click ROTATE. [ROTATE] [PLAY N:SA,N:SQ,N:S8,N:S2,N:HQ,N:HT,N:H9,N:DK,N:DT,N:D4,N:CA,N:CT,N:C6,S:S5,S:S3,S:HA,S:HJ,S:H8,S:H6,S:H2,S:D7,S:D5,S:D2,S:CK,S:CJ,S:C9] South plays 4!H. West leads the !D9. East wins the first trick with the !DA, then plays !DQ. You take your !DK now, fearing that the next one could be ruffed by West. Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT] You hope East, who opened the bidding, (as West before the hands were rotated), will have the !SK, which would reduce your losers to 4. You win the second !D and play your !HQ, taken by East with the !HK. He cashes the !DJ, West following, then exits with a small !H. [ROTATE] Win this trump and play one more, pulling East's last trump and ending in dummy. Play a !S to your !SQ (which wins) then play !SA and ruff a !S in dummy. East follows with the !S7, !SJ and !SK. Now you must try the !C finesse, but through whom? Is it a 50-50 guess? Or is East more likely to have the !CQ since he had the opening hand? [NEXT] No, it is not a 50-50 guess. No, East doesn't have the !CQ, West does. If you watched the cards that East has played you will realize he started with 3-3-4-3 distribution. You will also know that he started with 14 points outside the !C suit. If he had the !CQ he would have a balanced 16 point hand and would have opened 1NT, not 1!D. So West has the !CQ. Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT] [RESET] But if you don't pay attention on all T0 of them you will miss the one time where your attention was needed.

Auction: 1NT pass 2S | pass 3C pass 3D | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 2!S]
In the old days (before transfer bids) you could have just bid a "drop-dead" 2!D. But those days are gone so you must improvise. You bid 2!S, transferring partner to !Cs.
Partner says 3!C; what do you bid? [BID 3!D]
In the old days (before transfer bids) you could have just bid a "drop-dead" 2!D. But those days are gone so you must improvise. You bid 2!S, transferring partner to !Cs.
Partner says 3!C; what do you bid?
You now bid 3!D and partner knows to pass.
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
East overtakes and plays !S A K 9.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Rather than trying to figure out how many losers this !D holding may produce, approach it from the other direction; you can only afford ONE loser, so you assume the cards lie in a way that will give you that result. [NEXT]
That means that the !Ds must be splitting 3-2, and it also means that you must knock out the !DA without using either the !DK or !DQ. Can you do it? [NEXT]
Your only hope is for West to hold a doubleton !D A x. You ruff the third !S, then play a small !D toward dummy's !DQ. When this wins the trick, play another !D, and duck in your hand. If West's !DA falls you will be golden. 
Click for the full layout. [NEXT]
When this happens you should play as if they actually DO lie in that way, even though it may be against the percentages.

Auction: 1NT | pass 2H pass 2S | pass 2NT pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 2!H]
With 9 points and a 5-card Major suit you should definitely transfer, so you bid 2!H. Partner replies 2!S. What do you say now? [BID 2NT]
With 9 points and a 5-card Major suit you should definitely transfer, so you bid 2!H. Partner replies 2!S. What do you say now?
Now you complete the sequence by bidding 2NT, trusting partner to put it in the right place. He has maximum points and a doubleton !S so he puts it in 3NT.
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
The contract would be 3NT played by North.
To make South the declarer click ROTATE. [ROTATE]
[PLAY N:SJ,N:S4,N:HA,N:HT,N:H2,N:DA,N:DJ,N:D6,N:D2,N:CA,N:CK,N:C7,N:C3,S:SK,S:SQ,S:ST,S:S9,S:S3,S:HQ,S:HJ,S:H4,S:D8,S:D5,S:C6,S:C5,S:C2]
South plays 3NT. West leads the !H6, East follows with the !H5. What will you play from dummy? And what will you play from your hand.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
It's not as bad as that Winner List looks; you can establish 4 !S winners very easily.
In fact, it looks so good you might wonder what could possibly go wrong. Here's something that can go wrong. The defenders take the SECOND !S trick with their !SA. Can you get back to dummy for those other three winners? [NEXT]
Maybe you can and maybe you can't. It depends on what you played from your hand at the first trick. If you won that trick in your hand with the !HA, then YES, you can get to dummy by leading twice toward the !H Q J.
But if you won the first trick more cheaply with your !HT, (or perhaps dummy's !HJ), and you still have that !HA in your hand then West will prevent you from ever getting to dummy.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
Suppose you win the first trick with your !HT. If you later play your !HA then West's !HK will stop you from getting to dummy. But if instead you play a small !H toward the !H Q J West will grab his !HK and your own !HA will block your entry.
But if you take the first trick with a "spendthrift" !HA then dummy's !H Q J will become a guaranteed entry to the !Ss.
And notice - no matter which way you play it you still end up with exactly 2 !H tricks. So the play doesn't cost a trick, it just gains an entry.

Auction: 2NT | pass 3H pass 4S | pass 6S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 4!S]
With a maximum 2NT opener, 4 of partner's !Ss and a doubleton you jump to 4!S, the Super-Accept.
Partner wastes no time bidding the slam.
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
West finds their best lead, exposing your !H loser. With a different lead you could have led toward dummy's !DJ, but not now.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
A very simple Plan would be for you to pull trumps and then guess who holds the !CQ. Simple, but putting your slam on a 50% chance isn't very satisfying. [NEXT]
How about an elimination play instead? Win the !HA. Then play to dummy's !SK. West shows out and you must temporarily stop drawing trumps. [NEXT]
For the elimination play to work you must strip !Ds from both hands. So play both the !D A K, then ruff a !D with the !SQ. Pull trumps with your !S A J, then ruff the last !D in dummy.
The work is done. Just play a !H. Whichever defender wins must either play a !C into your split tenaces, or play a red card and give you a ruff/sluff.
Clickfor the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
If you knew who held the !CQ then you wouldn't have to learn Elimination plays.
Click NEXT to see the hands just before the throw-in. [NEXT]
[PLAY N:SK,N:SQ,N:S6,N:S5,N:S3,N:H2,N:DJ,N:D5,S:SA,S:SJ,S:S2,S:HA,S:DA,S:DK,S:D6,S:D4]
You now play the !H, eliminating that suit from both hands. Whichever defender wins the trick must either play another !H and give you a ruff/sluff, or play a !C and give you a free finesse. Either way you will make the slam.

Analysis:

Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]

Question 1: Do you hold up?
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
The lead of the !C2 tells you that West has only a 4-card suit, so there is no need to hold up. In fact if you did hold up East might play an unwelcome !H back.
Your best bet is going to be the !D suit, but dummy isn't exactly loaded with entries. How will you manage it? [NEXT]
When entries are really scarce the best approach is ducking. Win the !CK and play a low !D from both hands. A defender will win this and probably continue with a !C. [NEXT]
Stick to the plan. Win the !CA and again play small !Ds from both hands, relaxing when both defenders follow suit to the second !D.
They can now cash their 2 !Cs, and you had to give them 2 !Ds. But that's the only tricks they will get. Dummy's 3 !Ds are good and you still have a !D in your hand to get there.

In this case it was a double-duck.

South plays 6!S. West leads the !HK. Of course you take your !HA.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
The Losers are counted from dummy's long-trump hand for simplicity.
The !C suit must be established to take one of the !D losers. But there may be an entry problem since the opening lead has taken out one of your entries already.
Pull trumps in two rounds, (you got a break there), leaving the !SK in your hand as an entry. [NEXT]
If you now play !CA, !CK, and then ruff a !C you will succeed when the !Cs split 3-3. But if they are 4-2, then you will fail because you only have the one entry to your hand. [NEXT]
A better plan is to play a small !C from each hand. This gives the defense a !C trick but you can win their return, play a !C to the !C A, take the !CK, then ruff the FOURTH !C. This will establish the FIFTH !C and you still have the !SK for an entry.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
If you can afford to lose a trick in the suit you can make do with one fewer entry just by ducking the first round. Basically it gives you three plays in the suit before you take your ruff. 
But what if the contract had been 7!S?
Obviously you couldn't afford to lose a trick so you would have to bang down the two top !Cs, then ruff one and hope the suit was splitting 3-3.

[PLAY N:SK,N:SJ,N:ST,N:S5,N:HA,N:HK,N:HQ,N:DT,N:D3,N:CQ,N:CJ,N:CT,N:C2,S:SQ,S:S9,S:S4,S:HJ,S:H8,S:H4,S:DA,S:DJ,S:D6,S:CK,S:C9,S:C5,S:C3]
South plays 3NT. West leads the !DK. What will you play from dummy? (East follows with the !D2.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Since West has apparently led from !D K Q it seems you will get a second !D winner when they pursue the suit. You can also establish 3 more winners in !Cs. You can also establish 3 more winners in !Ss.
But as you can figure, you are going to have to establish BOTH black suits to get enough winners, and therein lies the problem. If West has a 5-card !D suit they will be able to establish 3 !D winners by the time you have knocked out both black Aces. In that case you cannot make the contract. Of course, if the !Ds are split 4-4 you will only lose 2 !Ds and the two black Aces. However West would probably not have overcalled a 4-card suit. [NEXT]
But West might have a 6-card !D suit, leaving East with just 2. Assume the two black Aces are split, one with West and one with East. If you win the first trick with dummy's !DA you will be OK if you first play the black suit where West holds the Ace. He will take it and then establish his !Ds. No problem, because when you knock out East's black Ace he won't have a !D left. BUT, if you guess the wrong black suit first you will go down.
You can protect your interests fully just by letting West hold the first !D, then winning the second as cheaply as you can. At that point East will be out of !Ds so it won't matter which black suit you go for.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
If you take dummy's !DA at the first trick you will succeed if you next attack !Ss, but you will fail if you next attack !Cs. 
But if you hold up on the first trick and win the continuation, you will succeed whichever black suit you attack next.
The holdup would of course fail if West held both black Aces, but in this case no Plan would succeed.

Auction: 1NT | pass 2NT pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 3NT]
Partner's 2NT bid invites you to bid game if you have a maximum hand. With 17 points you bid the game.

You play the !C4 from dummy, East plays the !CT and you take your !CQ.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
You are pretty sure West has the !CA so dummy's !CK can become a winner. If so, you only need 3 more winners.
All 3 can come from the !D suit if the finesse works, only 2 if it fails. Assume the worst, so that means you will also need a !S winner. [NEXT]
When you give up the lead the opponents are going to continue !Cs if they can. If West has a 5-card !C suit you could lose 3 !Cs, the !SA and the !DK. Either defender might win the !SA, but only East can win with the !DK.  [NEXT]
Since West, the Danger hand, can only get in with the !SA you should establish a !S winner first, even though the !Ds are better. Whoever wins the !SA will probably knock out dummy's !CK. Hopefully this will not cause you a problem because when your finesse for the !DK loses to East he won't have another !C. At least that's the Plan!
Click NEXT to see if the Plan was a good one. [NEXT]
Play !Ss first and even though West can win and establish !Cs East will not have a !C to return when he wins his !DK.
It goes without saying that if your !SK holds the trick you immediately switch to !Ds.
