[PLAY N:SK,N:SJ,N:ST,N:HA,N:HQ,N:H7,N:DA,N:D7,N:D5,N:CA,N:CQ,N:C7,N:C4,S:SA,S:SQ,S:S5,S:HK,S:HJ,S:H4,S:DK,S:DQ,S:D6,S:D3,S:CK,S:C3,S:C2]
South plays 7NT. West leads the !HT and East follows with the !H2.
DO NOT HOLD UP.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
There are two chances for your thirteenth winner, your fourth !C or dummy's fourth !D.
Some players will assume that means one of those two suits will have to split 3-3, so they will immediately test one, then the other. [NEXT]
In fact there is another possibility for success - even if neither suit is 3-3 it may be that the same defender holds 4 cards in both suits. In this case that defender can be squeezed. BUT, you don't play the !Cs and !Ds first, you play the other two suits.
Win the first !H, then play two more !Hs and all three !S winners. That will be 6 tricks played, and each defender will be down to 7 cards left in their hand. If one of them happened to start with 4 !Cs and 4 !Ds he will have to discard from one of the holdings and you will be able to win your fourth card in that suit. 
Click for the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
When you play your sixth Major suit winner East is squeezed and must discard from one of his 4-card holdings.
This is an Automatic Squeeze, which just means you don't have to do any preparatory work. All you have to do is play off all your non-threat winners before you play the squeezing suits.

[PLAY N:SQ,N:S3,N:HA,N:H8,N:H6,N:DQ,N:D7,N:D5,N:D2,N:CA,N:CK,N:C9,N:C4,S:SK,S:S9,S:S8,S:S7,S:S5,S:S4,S:H7,S:H5,S:H4,S:D9,S:D8,S:D6,S:CQ]
South plays 2!S. West leads the !HQ and East plays the !H9.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Suppose you win the !HA, play over to the !CQ, then try to get back to your hand with a trump to discard 2 losers on !C A K. If it worked that way it would be fine, but it is very likely that a defender would win their trump Ace, then take their 2 !Hs and 3 !Ds. You could be down one before you even got started.
A better approach is to trade one of your !C winners for a quick discard. Take the !HA, then play  !C A K, discarding a !H from dummy. That will eliminate one !H loser. [NEXT]
You probably cannot avoid your 3 !D losers, but you may be able to get out with losing a single trump. IF !Ss split 3-2, and IF you can win tricks with both the !SK and !SQ then you will make it. The only way it can happen is if East holds a doubleton !S A x. You must play the first !S from dummy, so ruff a !C to get there, then lead a small !S, putting on your !SQ when East follows low. This wins the trick, (hip-hip), so you now play your !S3, ducking in dummy. When East has to take his !SA, (hooray), you are home-free.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
But, if you need East to hold the !S A x anyway, perhaps that first plan would have worked better. You know, take dummy's !CQ, then play a low !S to get to your hand. 
It depends on East. If he ducked the low !S then you could get TWO discards and make an overtrick.
The method given here gives up the possibility of an overtrick for an improved chance of making the contract. You choose.

Feel free to use Blackwood. But if partner shows 3 Aces you only have enough points to bid 6, and if he shows 2 Aces you would still bid 6. So Blackwood will keep you out of slam if he has only 1 Ace. Or, you could just take a chance and bid 6!H.

[PLAY N:SQ,N:ST,N:S9,N:S4,N:HA,N:HQ,N:H8,N:H6,N:DA,N:DK,N:CA,N:CJ,N:C4,S:SA,S:S7,S:S5,S:S3,S:HK,S:HJ,S:HT,S:H9,S:H4,S:DQ,S:D6,S:D5,S:C7]
South plays 6!H. West leads the !S8. To play the !SA or not to play the !SA, that is the question.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
At first thought it seems the !S lead has saved you a guess in the suit. By playing low in dummy you will force East to put on the King, (if he has it), winning the trick but leaving you with a pretty good position in !Ss. [NEXT]
That's why it's good to have second thoughts at the Bridge table. Think about the meaning of the !S8 lead. If it is fourth down, then the Rule of 11 tells you that there will be 3 cards higher than the 8 spread among North, East, and South. BUT YOU CAN SEE 4 HIGHER CARDS. So your conclusion is that West has NOT made a fourth-down lead, but rather has led top-of-nothing, top-of-a-doubleton, or perhaps a singleton.
You don't know which of the above, but you do know that East holds both the !S K J. The danger is if the !S8 is a singleton and you play low from dummy they could get a !S trick and a !S ruff. So don't play low from dummy. Win the !SA at trick 1, pull trumps and then play !Ss from dummy toward your !S Q T 9, giving East the !SK but finessing him out of his known !SJ.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
If East led the !S8 from !S 8 6 or !S 8 2 then it also wouldn't matter whether you played the !SA or not, you would always make the contract.
If East led the singleton !S8 then you had better play the !SA or you will be down before you start.
It is unlikely that East would lead the !S8 from any holding containing one or both of the honors.

Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]

However, holding up once is a good idea because West may have a singleton !H and have to switch to something which helps you. West holds the first trick and plays another !H, which you win. [NEXT]
You must find 4 winners. The bad news is that you must finesse both the !DK and the !SQ. The good news is that with East opening the bidding there is a good chance he has both of them. So, how will you manage those two finesses? [NEXT]

Finesse the !D again. If East ducks a second time you must now take the !S finesse while you are still in dummy. If East covers the second !D you win with your !DA, return to dummy with the !D9, and then finesse the !S.

You need 4 additional winners and can only establish 3 of them in !Ds. So you will have to manufacture another one from the !C suit as well. If you assume the !C finesse will fail, (and you have probably noticed that most finesses DO fail on these pages), that means you will lose the lead twice.

You hold up, of course, to cut defensive communications when West has 5 !Hs and East has 3. West will probably play another !H to dummy's !HK. [NEXT]

If the !DA is with West and the !CK is with East then it doesn't matter in which order you play the suits since you will not lose the lead in !Cs. But if the !CK is with West and the !DA is with East then it is vital that you play !Cs first.

Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
You count 3 !D tricks but will need to be careful to get all 3. And obviously your three extra winners will have to be from the !C suit.
Most important for now, how do you read the !H suit? Do you hold up? [NEXT]
West has 4 !Hs because he led the !H3 and you can see the !H2. Therefore you should NOT hold up because they can only win 3 !Hs and the !CK right now. But if you hold up, East might pocket his !H trick and switch to !Ss, where you are just as bad off. [NEXT]
So win the !HA and unblock the !D A Q. then play !CJ, expecting to lose the trick. In fact, West takes his !CK.
West cashes his 3 !H tricks, then plays a !S. Pounce with dummy's !SA, cash the !DK, then take your 4 !C tricks and the game.
Click for the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
Not all finesses should be taken - certainly not this one.
Another possibility, playing !CA first, should also be rejected. On the rare day where the !CK fell singleton you might be happy, but on the more frequent days where a defender held !C K x x and took the third !C trick you'd feel like a complete fool. Rightly so.

Auction: 1S 1NT | pass 2NT pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 1NT]
A takeout double would not be a terrible bid. But if you don't overcall 1NT right now it will be hard to later convince partner that you have 17 points balanced. So you bite the bullet and say 1NT. Partner now bids 2NT. What do you say? [BID 3NT]
A takeout double would not be a terrible bid. But if you don't overcall 1NT right now it will be hard to later convince partner that you have 17 points balanced. So you bite the bullet and say 1NT. Partner now bids 2NT. What do you say?
There is no point bidding !Hs; you are absolutely sure that partner does not have four of them. He has told you to bid 3NT with a maximum so you bid 3NT.
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
Of course West leads his partner's suit.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
When the going gets tough, the tough better figure out a good plan!Although you MIGHT manage to get an extra trick in !Hs or !Cs, you can see that your only real chance is to find a distribution that will give you 4 !D tricks. With that in mind, where do you win the first trick? [NEXT]
Without thinking it through you might decide to save that entry to dummy and win the first trick in your hand. But to get the 4 !D tricks you need you are going to have to make them play their !DA WITHOUT using one of your two honors. That means the !DA must be doubleton, AND you must lead through it. And EAST is the one most likely to hold !D A x. [NEXT]
You win dummy's !SK and play a low !D. When East follows with the !D3 you play your !DQ which wins.
Then play a low !D from your hand, and DUCK IN DUMMY. East plays the !DA on this trick and you are now home-free!
Click NEXT to see all four hands. [NEXT]
Sometimes you must try to visualize some possible distribution of the defender's cards which will allow you to make your bid and then just go ahead and play for that distribution.

Auction: 1NT pass 2H | pass 2S pass 3H | pass 4H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 2!H]
With two 5-card Major suits you can transfer to either one first. A good system is to use the "weaker" transfer to show an invitational hand, the "stronger" to show a forcing to game hand.
So you bid 2!H and partner replies 2!S. What next? [BID 3!H]
With two 5-card Major suits you can transfer to either one first. A good system is to use the "weaker" transfer to show an invitational hand, the "stronger" to show a forcing to game hand.
So you bid 2!H and partner replies 2!S. What next?
Partner now knows you have 5 !Ss, so you now bid 3!H which lets him know you have 5 of that suit also. Partner chooses the !H game. [NEXT]
East wins the first trick with the !HA and returns the !H4.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
You are surely going to lose the two red Aces, so you must keep the !S losers to 1. A possible Plan is to pull the last trump and trust the !Ss to split 3-3. Good Plan?  [NEXT]
Stinking Plan. The chance of a 3-3 !S split is 36%, just a little over 1 in 3. A much better idea is to leave that trump out for a while longer, take your !S A K, and ruff one !S with dummy's last !H. Then what? [NEXT]
Be careful, you are still in danger. You need to pull that last trump but playing !CA and a ruff at this point could result in you losing trump control. First you need to establish a !D trick, so play the !DK. [NEXT]
East wins the !DA but he can't hurt you. Suppose he plays another !D. You win in dummy, ruff a !D back to your hand, and pull West's last trump. Then play a !S to East's !SQ. Your fifth !S is now established and you still have a trump to get to your hand with.
Click NEXT to see all four hands. [NEXT]
You must then pull West's last trump, leaving you with only one trump. 
When you give up the !S to East he could play a !C, forcing you to use your last trump, and although you could take your !S winner you wouldn't have the !D trick established. Not an easy hand.

Auction: 1NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID pass]
Here is the question. Is 2!S a better contract than 1NT? If so, you should transfer partner, then pass. If not, you should just pass now. With just a 5-card suit, and with no singleton, pass is probably better.
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
The contract would be 1NT played by North.
To make South the declarer click ROTATE. [ROTATE]

South plays 1NT. West leads the !HJ and East plays the !HQ.
Do you hold up or not?
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Outside !Ss you have 6 combined cards in each suit, so you must assume that you aren't any worse off in !Hs than in one of the minors. And, in !Hs you have 2 stops. So don't hold up.
You need 2 additional !S winners, but dummy has but one entry. So? [NEXT]
So you must duck twice. Win the !HK and play a low !S from each hand. A defender will win and probably continue !Hs.
Win the !HA and play another low !S from each hand. West wins and cashes 3 !Hs. He then plays the !CQ. [NEXT]
You win the !CA and take the !DA and the 3 good !Ss in dummy. The 4 high cards from your hand plus the 3 !S tricks from dummy add up to 7. Hallelujah.
Click for the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
But since they may be right you need to be on the lookout for ducking plays because one entry in dummy may be all you are going to have.

Auction: 1S pass pass 1NT | pass 2NT pass 3NT | pass pass pass |
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID pass]
It is good to be a little bold with your overcalls. But with a suit this tattered and only two outside Queens this is not good enough for a 2-level overcall. So you pass. Then you hear partner say 1NT. What do you bid now? [BID 2NT]
It is good to be a little bold with your overcalls. But with a suit this tattered and only two outside Queens this is not good enough for a 2-level overcall. So you pass. Then you hear partner say 1NT. What do you bid now?
A 1NT overcall shows 15-18 points and a stopper(s) in their suit. With 9 points you invite with 2NT and partner bids the game.
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
The contract would be 3NT played by North.
To make South the declarer click ROTATE. [ROTATE]
[PLAY N:SA,N:ST,N:S2,N:HA,N:H8,N:H3,N:DA,N:D7,N:D5,N:CK,N:CQ,N:CJ,N:C4,S:S8,S:S5,S:HQ,S:H6,S:H5,S:DQ,S:D8,S:D2,S:CA,S:C9,S:C8,S:C6,S:C3]
South plays 3NT. West leads the !SK. Do you hold up twice? Or just once? Or not at all?
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
You need to find one winner and it seems that it must come from one of dummy's red Queens. You are certain that West has both red Kings for his opening bid, (you and dummy have 26 HCP between you so that only leaves 14). But you also know that West has at least 5 !Ss, so if you lead toward a red Queen West will grab his red King plus 4 !S tricks.
Does that resolve the holdup question for you? [NEXT]
Yes. You hold up ONCE, and take the !SA at trick 2. Next you play !C K Q J to strip West of that suit. Then play the !ST to throw West into the lead.
He can take his other 3 !S winners, but after that he must lead a red card. Of course you confidently put up dummy's Queen which will be your ninth trick.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
Here you couldn't afford to hold up twice because then you would not have a throw in card left to put West on lead. 
But you had to hold up on the first trick to make sure East couldn't gain entry in the suit.
By the way, if West had a 6-card suit this plan wouldn't work. But then, no other plan would either.

Auction: 2NT | pass 3C pass 3H | pass 3NT pass 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 3!H]
When you have 4 cards in both Majors you respond 2!H to a Stayman request. Partner now bids 3NT.  What do you bid? [BID 4!S]
When you have 4 cards in both Majors you respond 2!H to a Stayman request. Partner now bids 3NT.  What do you bid? 
Partner denies having 4 !Hs so he must have 4 !Ss (or he would not have used Stayman). You correct the contract to4!S.
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
East grabs the opening lead with the !HA and plays the !DT.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
The !S, !H and !C losers are inevitable so you'd better not lose a !D. Even though East has returned a !D it is still possible that he holds the !DK so the finesse has a chance of working. Let's say a 50% chance. Do you take it? [NEXT]
No, of course not. Not when you have a play that offers almost a T0% chance. Win the !DA, play !SK, !SA, then !H K Q, discarding dummy's 2 !D losers.  [NEXT]
With one master trump still out you start on the !Cs, playing first the !CK, then overtake the !CJ with dummy's !CQ. The defense is welcome to take their !CA whenever they want, and they are also welcome to their trump trick. You are so gracious because you have your ten tricks!
Click NEXT to see the complete Deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
But the other 50% of the time West will have the !DK. On those Deals you get your just reward.

Auction: 1NT | pass 2C pass 2S | pass 4S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 2!C]
It is tempting to just bid 3NT and hope the !Ds come in. But not when you have a 4-card Major suit. Instead you bid a Stayman 2!C. Partner says 2!S; what do you bid next? [BID 4!S]
It is tempting to just bid 3NT and hope the !Ds come in. But not when you have a 4-card Major suit. Instead you bid a Stayman 2!C. Partner says 2!S; what do you bid next?
Well, he has 4 !Ss. That's why you used Stayman so you bid 4!S.
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
The contract would be 4!S played by North.
To make South the declarer click ROTATE. [ROTATE]
[PLAY N:S8,N:S7,N:S5,N:S2,N:HA,N:HK,N:DA,N:DJ,N:D3,N:CA,N:C6,N:C4,N:C2,S:SA,S:ST,S:S4,S:S3,S:H7,S:H3,S:DK,S:DQ,S:D8,S:D7,S:D4,S:D2,S:C7]
South plays 4!S. West leads the !CK. Seeing T top tricks sort of makes you wish you had just bid 3NT.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Missing 5 !Ss, the most likely split is 3-2, (68% of the time). You win the !CA and play a small !S toward dummy. West puts on the !SQ which you take with dummy's !SA, East following with the !S6.
Do you play !Ss again? or not? [NEXT]
Not. With both defenders following suit, the possibility of 4 !S losers is gone so you can lose at most 3. But that !SQ from West is ominous. If you play another !S and they do split 3-2 you will make 11 tricks, losing only 2 trumps. But if East has 3 !Ss left he will win the trick, pull all the rest of the trumps, and lead a !C to West.
The guaranteed way to make the contract is to play no more !Ss, but to start playing !D winners. The defenders can make their 3 trump tricks but you maintain control of the hand.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
But with a different distribution, (3-2), playing the second trump would have been great. 
Considering probabilities it looks like this. If you play the second trump you will make 2 overtricks about 70% of the time, but you will go down 4 about 30% of the time.
If you stop with the !Ss and start running !Ds you will make your contract T0% of the time but will never make an overtrick.

Auction: 1NT pass 2C | pass 2D pass 4H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 2!C]
Yes, you have a 6-card !H suit. But you also have 4 !Ss, so you start with a Stayman 2!C.
Partner says 2!D; what do you bid? [BID 4!H]
Yes, you have a 6-card !H suit. But you also have 4 !Ss, so you start with a Stayman 2!C.
Partner says 2!D; what do you bid?
OK, no 4-4 !S fit. But partner has at least 2!H so you know you have an 8-card (or better) fit there. With 10 points you have to decide whether to invite or insist, and you like the looks of this hand so you bid 4!H.
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
You play low from dummy and West continues with !CT, then !C9 which you ruff.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
You don't expect a trump loser, and obviously you cannot afford to have one.
So after ruffing the third !C you play !HA, then !HQ. Aargh! West discards a !D on the second trump. [NEXT]
East has left the !H J 9 while you have the !H Q T 8. If only dummy had another !H you could finesse East's !HJ, but, alas, dummy has none. Can you see another way to accomplish the finesse? [NEXT]
If you could manage to be in dummy after trick 11, and have nothing in your hand but the !H Q T, while East had nothing in his hand but the !H J 9 you would have him. But to accomplish this you must use up your !H8 beforehand.
You enter dummy with a !D, then play a small !D and ruff with your !H8. Then play your !SK. West wins this and assume he plays another !S.  [NEXT]
Win the !S in dummy, then play !DK, and the other !S winner. If East has to follow to all these then you will have accomplished your objective; East will be down to !H J 9 and will have to ruff trick 12 with one of them - which you will over-ruff.
Click for the full layout. [NEXT]
When you played a third !D to ruff with your !H8, East COULD have ruffed this. If he had, it would have handed you your contract since you could over-ruff and take care of your trump problem immediately.
By the way, ruffing a card to purposely shorten your trump holding is called a Trump Coup.

Auction: 1NT | 2S 3S pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 3NT]
Partner's cue-bid is the lebensohl version of Stayman, in this case promising 4 !Hs. Since it is an immediate cue-bid it denies a !S stopper.
You are forced to bid and you don't have 4 !Hs. 
But you DO have a !S stopper so you decide bid 3NT.
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
You hold up your !SA until the third round; West started with 6 !Ss.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
You need just one more winner. It cannot come from either !Cs or !Ss. Unless a defender foolishly discards a !H it can't come from that suit. Which means you have to win a !D trick.
So after winning the !SA, you play a !C to dummy's !CK, then lead a small !D toward your hand and play . . . what? [NEXT]
At first this looks like the classic King / Jack guess situation where you try to figure out if West is more likely to have the Ace or the Queen.
But it isn't like that at all. If West has the !DA then he will take it no matter which !D you play, and will defeat you with 1 !D and 5 !S tricks. Your ONLY chance to make this contract is for East to hold the !DA. So you play the !DK, then you . . .
. . . click NEXT to see if you make the contract or not. [NEXT]
Smart you, if you had played the !DJ you'd be down 2.

You have an invitational strength hand with a 6-card Major suit. It's a no-brainer; you transfer with a 2!H bid. Partner says 2!S; what do you bid next?
Repeat: You have an invitational strength hand with a 6-card Major suit. So you invite with 3!Ss. Partner accepts with 4!S.

To make South the declarer click ROTATE. [ROTATE]
[PLAY N:SK,N:S5,N:HA,N:H6,N:H4,N:D9,N:D6,N:D2,N:CA,N:CK,N:CQ,N:C6,N:C3,S:SA,S:S8,S:S7,S:S6,S:S3,S:S2,S:H8,S:DK,S:DT,S:D5,S:C9,S:C8,S:C2]
South plays 4!S. West leads the !HQ. Of course you take the !HA.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Missing 5 !Ss, the most likely split is 3-2, (68% of the time). You win the !HA then play !SK and !SA, both defenders following to both leads but the !SQ is still out there.
Do you play !Ss again or not? [NEXT]
Usually it is a good idea to leave a master trump un-pulled and go about your business winning tricks in other suits. The idea is to force them to ruff without using any more of your trumps. But that is only "usually". Here your big source of winners is going to be the !C suit - and there are zero outside entries to it. Suppose you do not force out the !SQ, but start playing !C winners. A defender might ruff the third !C and you would be doomed.
So play one more !S and they are doomed.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
Almost always the answer is "not to pull". 
The big exception is when you have a running suit in one hand but with no outside entries to it. A hand exactly like this one.

You know you may be in slam territory, but first you need to establish trumps. So you bid 3!D as a transfer and almost faint when partner jumps to 4!H, showing a super-accept. Now what do you bid?
Check for Aces with Blackwood, partner replies 5!S. What next?
Partner shows three Aces. You can't consider a Grand Slam, so bid 6!H.
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
The contract would be 6!H played by North.
To make South the declarer click ROTATE. [ROTATE]
[PLAY N:SK,N:SQ,N:HA,N:HJ,N:HT,N:DA,N:DK,N:D5,N:D3,N:CA,N:C8,N:C7,N:C3,S:SA,S:SJ,S:S3,S:HK,S:HQ,S:H9,S:H7,S:H4,S:D7,S:D6,S:D4,S:D2,S:CT]
South plays 6!H. West leads the !D8, on which East plays the !D9. You win the !DK.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
If you look just at the North and South hands you would think this was a pretty easy slam to make. Pull trumps and play three rounds of !Ds, and as long as the !Ds split 3-2 you make twelve tricks. But when you consider the !D8 opening lead you realize that it won't happen. The missing !Ds are Q J T 9 and 8. The ONLY combination from which West would lead the !D8 is when he has a singleton. So the !Ds won't be splitting and you need a different plan. [NEXT]
You need to get a !D discard somewhere, and dummy's third !S will take care of one of YOUR !D losers. But then to establish YOUR hand you are going to have to ruff all 3 !C losers. [NEXT]
Play the !CA and ruff a !C. Enter your hand with the !HT and ruff another !C high. Back to your hand with the !HJ and ruff another !C high. Dummy is out of trumps but there is still one more in a defender's hand. So come to your hand with the !SQ and pull the last trump, discarding a !D from dummy.
With all the trumps pulled cash dummy's 2 !Ss and your !DA, then give up a !D at the last trick.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
However it's a "role reversal", you pulled trumps with the short-trump hand and took three ruffs in the long-trump hand.
But call it whatever you like, that's the way to make this Deal.

Auction: 2NT | pass 4C pass 4S | pass 7NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 4!C]
You have 16 points and partner has 20-21. If you bid 7NT right now just because it is something you always wanted to do, then I don't blame you. But if you're cautious you'll use Gerber 4!C. Partner bids 4!S;  what do you bid next? [BID 7NT]
You have 16 points and partner has 20-21. If you bid 7NT right now just because it is something you always wanted to do, then I don't blame you. But if you're cautious you'll use Gerber 4!C. Partner bids 4!S;  what do you bid next?
OK, you have all the Aces. You are missing 4 points at most, possibly a King and a Jack, or two Queens. You could continue with Gerber and find out about the Kings, or you could pick between 6NT and 7NT right now. You go for the gusto with 7NT!
Click NEXT to continue. [NEXT]
The contract would be 7NT played by North.
To make South the declarer click ROTATE. [ROTATE]
[PLAY N:SQ,N:SJ,N:S7,N:HK,N:HQ,N:HJ,N:HT,N:DA,N:DQ,N:D5,N:CA,N:CJ,N:C4,S:SA,S:S6,S:HA,S:H6,S:H5,S:DK,S:D7,S:D6,S:D2,S:CK,S:CQ,S:CT,S:C3]
South plays 7NT. West leads the !ST. Do you play the !SA or a low card?.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
If West has led from !S K T 9 x, then all you have to do to make this contract is play a low card from dummy. But a decent defender would not make such a risky lead against a 7NT contract, so it is probable that East has the !SK. You rise with the !SA.
You hope the !Ds will split 3-3, but if they don't you still have the possibility of squeezing East if he holds 4 !Ds along with the !SK you have assigned to him. [NEXT]
If it comes to a squeeze it is important to take your tricks in the correct order. First take 4 !C tricks, discarding the !SJ from your hand. You note that East discards a small !S on the fourth !C.
Next take 4 !H winners, discarding dummy's useless !S6 and keeping all 4 !Ds. On the fourth !H East must come down to a 4-card holding; he must either throw his !SK, (you are happy) or he can throw one of his !Ds, (you are happy). 
Click NEXT to see what a great squeezer you are. [NEXT]
That means you didn't have to do anything special, just play your winners in the right order and keep your eyes open to see if the !SK gets discarded. 
Of course if the !Ds were breaking 3-3 all the time you haven't lost anything by playing for the squeeze.

It would have done you no good at all.

[PLAY N:SK,N:S5,N:HA,N:H9,N:H4,N:H3,N:DA,N:D6,N:D4,N:CA,N:C9,N:C8,N:C2,S:SA,S:S9,S:S6,S:S4,S:H8,S:H7,S:H6,S:H2,S:DK,S:D7,S:D5,S:CK,S:C6]
South plays 4!H. West leads the !DQ. Win the !DQ in either hand. Lets say you win with your !DA.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
*Don't get overconfident with this loser list. It assumes that trumps break 3-2, (if they don't you cannot make it), and also assumes you will be able to cross-ruff 4 small black cards.
Cross-ruffing those 4 losers could be a problem. You can't afford to get over-ruffed so it would be nice if you could pull some trumps before you start the cross-ruff. But you must make sure that only two rounds of trumps get pulled, otherwise you won't have the trumps for the cross-ruff. [NEXT]
It is actually simple to make sure exactly two rounds of trumps are drawn. At trick 2 just duck a !H in each hand. An opponent will win this, but you can take the next trick, (probably a !D), and then pull a second round of trumps with your !HA. Then leave the trumps alone and play your two black A K's, then start cross-ruffing with your 4 tiny trumps. The defender with the master trump can over-ruff when he can, and can even cash a !D. But that's all he can do so you will make your game. 
Click for the complete Deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
East would have won the second one, and if he had then continued !Ds you would have made the contract.  
But if he was a good enough defender to pull a THIRD round of trumps, getting 2 for the price of 1 value, you would have been defeated.

The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would bid, then click on BID above. [BID 2!D]

With only 2 points you make a Negative 2!D response to partner's 2!C opener. He now bids 2NT. What is your bid? [BID pass]

This isn't as clear-cut a decision as you might think at first. Partner is showing 22-24 points, and even though you only have 2 points it is possible that the partnership total could be 26. The thing that should convince you to pass is that a 24-2 point split doesn't play nearly as well as say a 13-13 split would. Lack of transportation would likely kill any chance of 3NT (or 4!S). So you pass.

Of course you bid your 8-card suit. But no jumping, just bid 2!H. Partner now says 2NT. What do you bid next? [BID 4!H]

Partner has between 3 and 7 points. Somewhere in those points might be the one trick you need, but you don't have any scientific way of finding out. So just bid 4!H and hope.(There it is, the !CT.)

Partner is not introducing a new suit here, you have already agreed on !Hs. He is making a control-showing bid of the !CA. He expects you to do the same if you can. Since you can show your Ace very conveniently below game level you bid 4!D. That was what he was hoping for, he bids 6!H.

Auction: 1H pass 2D | pass 2NT pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
After North's 1!H opening South counts 12 HCP plus one length point for the fifth !D. That is enough for a 2/1 response so South says 2!D.
The partnership is now forced to reach game so North bids 2NT. This describes a balanced hand with exactly 5 !Hs and no 4-card !S suit.
South is happy to play in Notrump, and with no extra strength above the 13 points already promised, uses Quick Arrival and bids 3NT. North passes and a reasonable game contract is reached.
Notice that you would bid this hand the same way whether or not you play 2/1.

Auction: 1H pass 2D | pass 2H pass 3H | pass 4H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
North opens 1!H and South, with 16 points,  responds 2!D, forcing the partnership to game.
North has a minimum strength hand, but with a 6-card suit he rebids 2!H.
Opposite North's 6-card suit, South's doubleton is adequate support. If South had a minimum for her 2/1 response she might just jump to 4!H to show no interest in slam. With a little extra she bids 3!H since she knows the bidding cannot stop until game is reached. From South's perspective North might have a big hand; his 2-level rebid shows suit length but does not say anything about strength. This is one of the beauties of 2/1, the bidding can be kept low while you look for the best place to play. However, this time North merely bids the game and South passes.
The hand would have been bid the same with or without 2/1.

Auction: 1H pass 2D | pass 2H pass 3H | pass 4C pass 4D | pass 4NT pass 5H | pass 6H pass pass
Analysis: With 16+ points and 3 !Hs, South will insist on a !H game at a minimum. But there is no need to start making jump bids, she starts with a simple 2!D bid. North also refrains from a jump, and rebids 2!H to show the 6-card suit.\nSouth now says 3!H to set the trump suit. At this point North reveals some slam interest, making a control-showing bid of 4!C. South continues the process, and bids 4!D, showing the !DA.\nNorth has heard enough. He bids 4NT, and when South admits to two Aces he bids the slam.

Auction: 1S 2D 2H | pass 2S pass pass | pass
Analysis: North has a minimum 1!S opening bid. After East's 2!D overcall both North and South know that the 2/1 Game Force in no longer on. South can therefore bid 2!H, showing at least 11 points. This bid is forcing on North for 1 round, but not forcing to game.\nNorth next rebids his !Ss, promising a 6-card suit, but also indicating a minimum strength hand! Since the Game Force is not on, North would have to make a jump bid to show extra strength.\nSouth has nothing further to say so the partnership arrives in a safe contract.

Auction: 1S pass 2C | pass 2H pass 2NT | pass 3H pass 4H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
North opens 1!S, the higher ranking of the two 5-card suits.
South, with 14 points, responds 2!C, forcing the partnership to game.
North now bids his !H suit.
At this point South figures North for 5 !Ss and 4 !Hs. South cannot support either of North's Majors, but with a good stopper in the fourth suit bids 2NT. The game force is still on and North may not pass this bid.
North bids 3!H, indicating that this is also a 5-card suit. Now South can bid the !H game, knowing there is an 8-card fit.

Auction: pass 1S | pass 2H pass 3H | pass 4H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
South opens 1!S and North, with 14 points, responds 2!H. Note that North is not permitted to make this bid without a 5-card or longer !H suit.
South, knowing that North has 5, bids 3!H to confirm the trump suit.
North has a minimum strength hand with no slam aspirations, so he uses Fast Arrival and bids 4!H. South is also satisfied to just play at game.
2/1 is a good bidding method, and here, 4!H is a good contract. But you can see that it is not a laydown - there is no bidding system that will always reach T0% contracts. In this hand a 3-3 !D split will provide the Tth trick, or if that fails, taking 2 !S finesses provides a 75% chance of success.

Auction: 1S pass 2C | pass 2H pass 3H | pass 4H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
North has 13 points and naturally opens 1!S.
South, with 15 points, would bid 2!H in standard bidding, but with 2/1 this promises a 5-card suit. So instead, South responds 2!C, forcing the partnership to game. Note that holding two 4-card minors South bids them up-the-line, just as in standard bidding.
North has a nice 6-card !S suit, so you might think he would rebid them. But Opener's first responsibility with his second bid is to show a 4-card Major if he has one. This isn't much of a suit, but North still bids 2!H.
You can see why it is important for Opener to show a 4-card Major. Since South couldn't bid !Hs in her first response the fit would have been lost if North had not mentioned the suit. South now confirms the trump suit with a 3!H bid, and North shows his minimum by just bidding the game.

Auction: 1H pass 2D | pass 2S pass 2NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
North opens 1!H, his 5-card Major. South, with 14 points, naturally responds 2!D, forcing the partnership to game.
North next bids 2!S, showing the other Major suit. In standard bidding North would not be able to bid the !Ss since that would be a Reverse and North is far too weak to Reverse. But after a 2/1 Response the concept of a Reverse does not apply, and the priority of showing a 4-card Major certainly does apply.
South assumes North to be 4-5 in the Majors, so she cannot support either. She bids 2NT. If North actually has 6 !Hs (or 5 !Ss) he will rebid the suit. South's 2NT bid guarantees a stopper in the fourth suit.
North does not have either 6 !Hs or 5 !Ss so he just bids 3NT. Notice that North never once considered the possibility of passing what might be a misfit - the initial 2/1 response unconditionally forced the partnership to reach a game somewhere.

Auction: 1S pass 2C | pass 2H pass 3D | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
North opens 1!S, his 5-card Major. South, with 14 points, responds 2!C, a 2/1 force to game.
North next bids 2!H, showing the other Major suit.
South assumes North to be 5-4 in the Majors, so she cannot support either. She cannot bid 2NT without a stopper in !Ds. So South bids the fourth suit, 3!D, telling North she knows she must make a bid, but can't find anything appropriate.
North now must find a bid. His choices include rebidding the 5-card !Ss, supporting South's !Cs with a doubleton Queen, or bidding 3NT with the !D K 6 as a stopper. He chooses this last option. It appears that 3NT is the best game for these two hands.

Auction: 1S | pass 2H pass 3H | pass 3S pass 4C | pass 4NT pass 5H | pass 6H all pass
Analysis:
South opens 1!S, her 5-card Major and North responds 2!H. South knows this is a 5-card suit, and bids 3!H, confirming the 8+card trump fit.
Once the trump fit is known, North revalues his hand to about 19 points. He makes a slam try with  a control-showing bid of 3!S. He knows South won't take this as !S support since the partnership has agreed that !Hs are going to be trumps.
South now shows her control by bidding 4!C.
That was what North needed to hear; when Blackwood uncovers two Aces he bids 6!H.
The slam is a good one. If either the !SQ or !CK is right there are 12 tricks by way of a finesse. But the best way to play the hand would be to try to establish a !S in the South hand, and if that fails try the !C finesse.

Auction: pass 1H pass 2C | pass 2NT pass 3NT | pass 4NT pass 6NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
North opens 1!H and South responds 2!C. Using standard bidding North would now jump to 3NT to show his 19 points, but in 2/1 this is not necessary since the partnership must not stop bidding until game is reached. So North just bids 2NT. South shows her minimum by bidding 3NT.
North will now disclose his extra strength. He bids 4NT. This is not Blackwood, but rather a quantitative raise in Notrump, and an invitation to slam.
South has 15 points, and they are good ones. She accepts the invitation and bids 6NT.
There are 11 top tricks. A 3-3 !H split would provide the 12th winner, but this is against the odds. Better to try two !S finesses, a 75% chance.

Auction: pass 1S pass 2D | pass 2S pass 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
North opens 1!S and South responds 2!D. North has a pretty good hand, 17 points, but no stopping power in the minor suits. Also, North's !S suit is pretty ragged. Taking these points into consideration, North should just rebid his 6-card suit.
South should now jump to 4!S. This is Fast Arrival, indicating a minimum hand with no particular interest in slam.
North is happy to rest in the game contract.
Even with a combined 30 points, T tricks are certainly not a sure thing. North must hope that West holds the trump King.

Auction: pass 1S pass 2H | pass 3H pass 4NT | pass 5H pass 5NT | pass 6C pass 6H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
North opens 1!S. South has a powerhouse, plenty strong enough to jump-shift. But playing 2/1 it's usually simpler when you make the 2/1 response, and save your jumping for later - if at all. So South bids just 2!H, knowing North must keep the bidding open.
North knows South has at least 5 !Hs, so his first priority is to agree on the trump suit. He bids 3!H.
South now makes the slam try. She knows North has at least three trumps, and all she wants to find out is how many Aces/Kings North holds. So she bids Blackwood and North confesses to two Aces.
Still hoping for the Grand, South bids 5NT. Oops, North doesn't have any kings so South settles for a small slam.
This is a good slam, cold if West makes any opening lead other than a !C. With a !C lead, South will have to pull trumps and play to discard a loser on the !ST.

Auction: 1H | pass 2D pass 2H | pass 4H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
South opens 1!H and North responds 2!D.
South has a good-looking hand, but needs to find a trump suit before she starts showing her extra strength, so she bids just 2!H.
Knowing that South holds 6 !Hs, North can support with the honor doubleton so he agrees the trump suit with a Fast Arrival bid of 4!H.
South has some extra strength, but not enough to push on after North's weak bid. Notice that if South DID try a 4!S Control bid North would just bid 5!H and the pair might be one trick too high.

Auction: 1S pass 1NT | pass 2C pass 2H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
North opens 1!S. South has 11 points, enough to respond 2!H in standard bidding, but not when using 2/1. So she bids 1NT.
North would love to pass 1NT but is not permitted to do so. He has no good bid, so he must bid a 3-card suit. When holding two 3-card minors, usually bid !Cs. South now shows the !H suit that she could not bid first round.
North was forced to reply to 1NT, but he is not forced to bid again. With his minimum hand and a tolerance for partner's suit he just passes and the partnership ends up in a reasonable contract.
This hand demonstrates one of the benefits of Forcing 1NT. In standard bidding South's first response would be 2!H, and North would have to bid again, probably 2NT. The partnership might go even higher but in any case would probably not reach a good contract.

Auction: 1S pass 1NT | pass 2C pass 2NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
North opens 1!S. South has 11 points, enough to respond 2!C, (or 2!D), in standard bidding, but not when using 2/1. So she bids 1NT.
North is forced to bid again, but unlike the previous hand, here he wants to keep bidding. He bids 2!C. South knows North doesn't have !Hs, so she shows her above-minimum hand by bidding 2NT.
North is happy to play Notrump. He assumes South must have something useful in !Ds and bids 3NT.
3NT seems to be a good contract. There are 8 top tricks and possibilities for a ninth winner in either !Ss, !Ds, or, (the best chance), !Cs.

Auction: 1H pass 1NT | pass 2H pass pass | pass
Analysis: North opens 1!H. South responds 1NT, just as in standard bidding. The difference is that in this case the 1NT response is forcing on North.\nNorth has an easy second bid, he rebids his 6-card suit. South has nothing to say over 2!H except pass.\nNotice that this is the same bidding and same final contract that would have been reached with standard bidding. Using 2/1 is often like that.

Auction: 1S | pass 2D pass 3D | pass 4S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
South opens 1!S. North responds 2!D, a 2/1 force to game. 
South cannot rebid her !Ss, but has decent support for partner's !Ds. So she bids 3!D.
North always intended to play a !S contract. He now bids 4!S, using Fast Arrival to indicate he has no slam aspirations.
4!S is cold, and if the defenders don't take their !H tricks immediately South will make an overtrick.

Auction: 1H X 2C | pass pass pass
Analysis: North opens 1!H and East Doubles.\nAfter the intervening Takeout Double 2/1 is OFF. If South had T or more points she would Redouble. So even with only 9 points South can bid 2!C without fear that North will think she has a strong hand.\nNorth also knows everything mentioned above so he passes.

Auction: 1S | pass 2D pass 2S | pass 3S pass 4C | pass 4S all pass
Analysis:
South opens 1!S. North responds 2!D, a 2/1 force to game. 
South has a big hand, perhaps in the slam range, but first priority is to set a trump suit. So she contents herself with a rebid of 2!S.  North agrees on trumps by bidding 3!S (not Fast Arrival).
South now makes her slam try by using a Control-showing cue-bid. She bids 4!C, showing first round control of the suit (Ace or Void).
North's next bid would be a control-showing bid of her own - IF SHE HAD ONE. Since she cannot win the first round of either red suit she just returns to 4!S. South realizes that they are off two red Aces and passes.
Notice that South did not fall into the Blackwood trap. If she HAD asked for Aces, North would have shown one Ace and South wouldn't know what to do next. She might have figured the odds favored that one Ace being a red one and tried the slam. Moral: Don't use Blackwood when you have a void.

Auction: 1S pass 2D | pass 2H pass 2NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis: North opens 1!S. South responds 2!D, a 2/1 force to game. \nNorth's priority is to now show the 4-card !H suit. Remember that South might also have 4 !Hs.\nSouth doesn't have 4 !Hs, nor does she have 3 !Ss. She does, however, have stoppers in !Cs so she bids 2NT. North happily says 3NT.

Auction: 1S pass 2D | pass 2H pass 3C | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
North opens 1!S. South responds 2!D, a 2/1 force to game. 
North's priority is to now show the 4-card !H suit. Remember that South might also have 4 !Hs.
South doesn't have 4 !Hs, nor does she have 3 !Ss. Furthermore,  she does not have stoppers in !Cs so she cannot bid NT. Since she has to keep bidding, but has no reasonable bid she can make, she bids the fourth suit, 3!C. Compare this Deal with Deal 21.
North understands that South's !C bid is Fourth-Suit-Forcing, and does not actually show !Cs. However since North does have a !C stopper he bids 3NT. In this case this turns out to be the best game contract.

Auction: pass pass 1S | pass 2D pass 2H | pass 2S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
North passes and South opens 1!S. 
North now bids 2!D. Since North originally passed this is NOT 2/1 Game Force. Instead, it is forcing for one round and shows 11 or more points. 
South next shows her 4-card !H suit. North gives a preference to 2!S.
Knowing that North does not have opening strength South passes 2!S.

Auction: 1S pass 1NT | pass 2C pass 2S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
North opens 1!S. With 9 points and a doubleton !S South must respond 1NT. 
In standard bidding North would happily pass a 1NT response. But in 2/1 the 1NT response is forcing for 1 round. North is forced to bid a 3-card minor so he says 2!C. 
South prefers !C over !S but must allow for the possibility that North has bid a 3-card suit. So South gives a preference to 2!S. This is called a "false preference", but it assures the team of being in at least a 7-card fit. 
North happily passes and the pair lands in a reasonable contract, probably better than 1NT.

Auction: 1S | pass 2H pass 3H | pass 4C pass 4D | pass 4NT pass 5H | pass 5NT pass 6D | pass 6H all pass
Analysis:
South opens 1!S. North has a mountain, but there is seldom a need to jump-shift when using 2/1. He bids 2!H. 
South's priority on her first rebid is to agree trumps if possible. Knowing North has at least a 5-card suit, she bids 3!H.
North naturally feels slammish, and shows it with a control-showing cue-bid, 4!C. Do not even THINK this might be Gerber.
South doesn't have any extra strength, but that doesn't matter. With South making a slam try she should cooperate by showing her !D control. It is important to realize that South isn't showing any extra strength, she is merely going along with North. 
North asks for Aces and gets two. He decides to find out about Kings, if South happens to have three he will bid 7NT. When South shows just one North settles for 6!H. This should be a good slam, needing only a decent !S break.

Auction: 1S pass 1NT | pass 2S pass 3S | pass 4S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
North opens 1!S. With 11 points South cannot respond 2!C. So she bids 1NT, which is forcing for 1 round. 
North's first priority is to show a 4-card !H suit. Since he doesn't have one his next priority is to rebid the 6-card !Ss.
South is strong enough to invite, and with the known 8-card fit she says 3!S.
North has a little extra so he bids 4!S, which is a pretty good contract.

Auction: 1S pass 2C | pass 2H pass 2NT | pass 3S pass 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis: North opens 1!S. Perhaps a little marginal, but you don't pass 13 point hands. South has a good 2/1 response of 2!C. \nNorth's first priority is to show a 4-card !H suit, so he does. South wouldn't dare support !Hs with only three cards, but has a good 2NT bid.\nNorth is not happy in notrump so rebids the 6-card major, 3!S. South's two !Ss are enough support so she bids the !S game.

Auction: 1S | pass 1NT pass 2C | pass 3S pass pass | pass
Analysis: South opens 1!S. North cannot say 2!H because he only has 11 points, and also because he only has 4 !Hs. So he bids 1NT (forcing for 1 round).\nSouth rebids 2!C, a 3-card suit. North now jumps to 3!S, showing limit-raise strength. This sequence is the way to show a limit-raise with only 3 trumps; an immediate jump-raise to the 3-level shows a limit-raise with 4 trumps.\nIn any case South has a bare minimum and passes the invitation.

Auction: pass 1NT pass pass | pass
Analysis: NORTH has a perfect 1NT opener; a balanced hand with 16 points.\nSOUTH has 7 points; he knows that the most points the partnership could hold is 24 (7 + 17).\nSince this is below the 26 point game requirement he passes.

Auction: 1NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
SOUTH has an ideal 1NT opening -
16 points and balanced distribution.
With 12 points, NORTH knows the partnership total is between 27 and 29, enough for game
but not enough to think about slam. Since NORTH also has a balanced hand she bids 3NT.

Auction: pass 1NT pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
NORTH has 16 points and balanced distribution.
She naturally opens 1NT.
SOUTH has 14 points and balanced distribution so he does the math.
The partnership has at least 29 points (14 + 15).
The partnership has at most 31 points (14 + 17).
Since this is more than the 26 needed for game, but fewer than the 33 needed for slam
SOUTH just bids 3NT, knowing NORTH will respect his decision and pass.

Auction: 1NT | pass pass pass
Analysis: When SOUTH opens 1NT, NORTH knows that he cannot have more\nthan 17 points. So with her 7 points, she knows there is no reason to respond.

Auction: pass 1NT pass 2NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
NORTH has a maximum 17 point 1NT opener.
SOUTH has 9 points:
- if NORTH has 15 the total is 24, not enough for game.
- if NORTH has 17 the total is 26, enough for game.
Since SOUTH doesn't know what to do he passes the buck back to NORTH
by bidding 2NT; this is an invitation for NORTH to bid game.
NORTH has a maximum 17 point hand so she accepts the invitation.

Auction: 1NT | pass 2NT pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
With 9 points NORTH is unable to decide the final contract. If SOUTH has 17 points then the partnership
should be playing 3NT. If SOUTH opened with just 15 points then 3NT will be too high..
So NORTH makes the temporizing bid of 2NT. This tells SOUTH that he must make the final call - go on to
game if he has maximum, pass if he has minimum. On this Deal SOUTH has 17 points so he bids 3NT.

Auction: pass 1NT pass 2NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
This time NORTH has a minimum 1NT opener; a balanced hand with 15 points.
SOUTH has 9 points; he knows that the partnership is somewhere between
24 (9 + 15) and 26 (9 + 17). So he invites with a 2NT bid.
NORTH, with a minimum, declines the invitation by passing.

Auction: 2NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
SOUTH has a strong hand, 20 points and balanced distribution.
It is just right to open 2NT (20-21 points).
NORTH adds her 2 points to SOUTH's promised number of 20 or 21. Since she doesn't reach the
magic game number of 26 points she just passes.

Auction: pass 1NT pass 2NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
NORTH has an mid-range 1NT opener; a balanced hand with 16 points.
SOUTH has 9 points. He bids 2NT, asking NORTH to pass if she has 15 or bid 3NT if she has 17.
But NORTH has 16 points, which leaves her with no clear choice.
In this case she must decide whether her hand is a "good" 16 points or a "poor" 16 points.
Since her supporting cards are mostly 10's, 9's and 8's she figures it as "good"
and bids 3NT.

Auction: 2NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis: SOUTH has 20 points and 4-4-3-2 distribution, so he opens 2NT.\nNORTH has 8 points. She adds SOUTH's 20 or 21 for a total of 28 or 29, enough for game but\nnowhere close to the slam requirement. So she bids 3NT and SOUTH passes.

Auction: pass 1NT pass 4NT | pass
1NT | pass 2NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
SOUTH has a minimum 1NT opening hand - balanced distribution with 15 points.
NORTH has 9 points, which is not enough to bid game, but is worth making an invitational bid.
So she says 2NT.
Since SOUTH is minimum he declines the invitation by passing.

Auction: pass 1NT pass 6NT | pass
2NT | pass 6NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The partner who is first sure what the final contract should be should just go ahead and bid it.
This is called "She who knows, goes."
In this deal, for example, it is NORTH who knows. She has a balanced 14 points, so when SOUTH indicates
20/21 points with his opening 2NT bid she
KNOWS
the partnership holds about 34/35 points.
Therefore she
GOES
to 6NT.

Auction: pass 2NT pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis: NORTH has a balanced 20 point hand - ideal to open 2NT.\nSOUTH has 7 points; he knows the partnership has either 27 or 28 points so he bids 3NT.

Auction: 1NT | pass 6NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
This is another example of "She who knows, goes."
NORTH has a solid 18 points, (1 extra for the fifth Club), so when SOUTH opens 1NT
she
KNOWS
that together they must hold at least 33 points. The may even have 35 points.
In any case they should be in slam, so NORTH
GOES
to 6NT.

Auction: pass 2NT pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis: NORTH has 20 points, counting one extra for the fifth Diamond. Just right to open 2NT.\nSOUTH has 6 points, just enough to bid 3NT.\n(20 + 6 = 26) (21 + 6 = 27)

Auction: pass | pass 1NT pass 2NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass

Auction: pass 1NT pass 4NT | pass 6NT pass pass | pass

Auction: pass 2NT pass pass | pass

Auction: 1NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass

This is an easy one to bid.
SOUTH has a balanced 16 points so he opens 1NT.
NORTH has a balanced 12 points so she responds 3NT.
BUT - just look at how this would play. You might only be able to take 8 tricks.
Sometimes correct bidding gets you to unmakeable contracts. But it's only a game.

Auction: pass 2NT pass 6NT | pass pass pass

Notrump bidding really is easy, you just add your points to partner's points and then
bid according to that answer.
Here SOUTH has 14 points. So when NORTH opens 2NT, showing 20 or 21 points SOUTH knows the
total will come to 34 or 35 so he bids 6NT.

s as trumps.

opening is passed around to SOUTH. He is

Analysis: The bidding has gone as shown. Your 3!H bid showed 11-12 points. Decide how you would answer partner's Blackwood 4NT, then click on BID above. [BID 5!D]\n\nThe Blackwood response for 1 Ace is 5!D. Partner evidently was hoping for 2, and he signs off at 5!H. He is the Captain so you pass.

Analysis: The bidding has gone as shown. Your 1NT bid showed 15-17 points and a balanced hand. Decide how you would answer partner's Gerber 4!C, then click on BID above. [BID 4!S]\n\nThe Gerber response to show 2 Aces is 4!S. So you bid 4!S and partner jumps to 6NT, which you pass.

Auction: 1NT pass 4C | pass 4H pass 4NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 4!C]

Very interesting! If partner's 1NT bid happens to include 3 Aces and one King you can count 13 tricks!So you bid 4!C, definitely Gerber following the 1NT opening. Partner answers 4!H. What do you say next? [BID 4NT]

You almost refuse to believe it! How can partner have a 1NT opener with only 1 Ace? But you trust your partner so you bid 4NT. Everybody passes and you stare in amazement at partner's 16 points.
Wouldn't it have been funny if partner had thought your 4!C bid was Stayman? And so his 4!H bid would have been showing a suit. And then your 4NT bid would have been Blackwood. And then he would have answered 5!D and you would have passed and made it!

Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 2NT]

With a 20 point balanced hand you open 2NT. What do you rebid after partner jumps to 4!C? [BID 4!S]

The 4!C bid is Gerber and your correct response with 2 Aces is 4!S. Partner now bids 6NT and since he is the Captain you pass.

Auction: 2H pass 4NT | pass 5H pass 6H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 4NT]

Partner opens a Weak 2-bid and catches you with a blockbuster. The only thing you want to know about his hand now is how many Aces he has. So you bid 4NT. Partner answers 5!H. What do you bid? [BID 6!H]

That makes it simple, with 2 Aces you bid a confident 6!H. If he had 1 Ace you would have bid an also confident 5!H. If he had zero Aces you would have been in a spot of trouble. And if he had 3 Aces you would have asked him how he could open a Weak-2 with that many points.

You MIGHT say that with 13 points and partner controlling the !Cs you could jump to 2NT, "To show you my points, partner."You might say it but you won't because your first priority is to look for a Major suit fit. You bid 1!H (skipping !Ds with the two Majors). Partner now jumps to 4!H. What do you say? [BID 4NT]

Partner says you can make game even if you have a minimum 6 points. So he must have about 20. So you think you can make slam and you bid 4NT. Partner answers 5!H. What do you bid? [BID 6!H]

Partner shows 2 Aces so you bid 6!H.

Auction: 1D | pass 2NT pass 4C | pass 4S pass 6NT
Analysis:
You dealt this hand. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 1!D]

You have 20 points and it would not be terrible to open 2NT. However, strictly speaking you shouldn't open 2NT with two doubletons. So you open 1!D. Partner responds with a jump to 2NT. What do you bid? [BID 4!C]

With partner's 13-15 added onto your 20, bidding 6NT would be a reasonable bid. However, it costs nothing to check for Aces first, so you bid 4!C. (Everybody agrees this is Gerber, right?)Partner answers 4!S. What do you bid? [BID 6NT]

Easy, missing one Ace you bid 6NT.

Auction: 1S | pass 3H pass 3S | pass 4NT pass 5H | pass 5NT pass 6C | pass 6NT all pass
Analysis:
You dealt this hand. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 1!S]

With 13 points and a good Major suit you naturally open 1!S. Partner responds 3!H. What do you bid next? [BID 3!S]

We are playing strong jump-shifts by Responder so partner is showing 17+ points. However, you are still stuck with your minimum opening so you just rebid 3!S. Partner bids 4NT. What is your reply? [BID 5!H]

He asks for Aces so you bid 5!H showing 2. He now bids 5NT. What do you say? [BID 6!C]

You have no King. So you reply 6!C and partner bids 6NT (safer than 6!S).

Auction: 2H pass 4NT | pass 6D pass 6H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 4NT]

You need to find out about Aces so you bid 4NT. Partner says 6!D. What do you bid? [BID 6!H]

Partner has shown one Ace and a !D void. As to what you bid, that's easy. You have no choice now but to say 6!H. This is a pretty good slam, but it is not cold. Maybe East will not lead a !C. Or maybe West will have the !DA.

Auction: 2C pass 2NT | pass 4C pass 4S | pass 6NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 2NT]

Not everybody responds to 2!C openers the same way. But with 9 balanced points 2NT is reasonable. Partner jumps to 4!C. What do you bid? [BID 4!S]

With 2 Aces your response is 4!S. Partner bids 6NT and you pass.

Auction: 2C pass 2S | pass 2NT pass 4C | pass 4D pass 7NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 2!S]

Interesting hand. Too bad these only come up in lessons and never at the table! You could jump right into Ace-asking but there is no rush so you say 2!S. Partner now rebids 2NT. What do you say? [BID 4!C]

Now you know all about partner's hand. 22-24 points, balanced. Now ask for Aces. If you agree that 4!C is Gerber here then that's what you should bid. If not, then you would have to use Blackwood. Partner answers 4!D. What do you say? [BID 7NT]

The 4!D reply says either zero or all four. Put your money on all four and bid 7NT.

Auction: 1C pass 1S | pass 4S pass 4NT | pass 5D pass 6S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 1!S]

With 15 points and a nice 5-card suit you respond 1!S. Partner jumps to 4!S. What do you say? [BID 4NT]

Do NOT say "Partner bid a close-out bid so I'll pass." Partner's bid means he thinks you can make 4!S even though he is only counting you for 6 points. Since you have 15+ now you want to go for more. You bid 4NT and partner answers 5!D. What do you say next? [BID 6!S]

Partner has 1 Ace so you can go no higher than 6. Although you can't tell for sure that slam will make, remember you used Blackwood just to be sure you weren't missing two Aces. You are not and you have enough points so you bid it. Although you can see that 6NT would have been a great contract you had to take the safer 6!S.

Auction: 1S | pass 3S pass 4C | pass 4H pass 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis:

Partner's limit-raise shows 11-12 points and you revalue your hand up to 22. So you are definitely in slam territory. You hope partner has 2 Aces but you cannot use Blackwood with that worthless doubleton in !Ds. Instead you make a control-showing bid of 4!C. Partner then bids 4!H. What do you bid next? [BID 4!S]

The good news is that partner's control-showing bid says he has the !HA. The bad news is that he bypassed !Ds so he does not have the !DA. Since you may have 2 quick losers in !Ds you sign off at 4!S.

THIS IS NOT BLACKWOOD. Partner's bid is the Quantitative 4NT. He has 16 points and is inviting you to bid slam if you have a maximum opener, but to pass with a minimum. Since your 17 point hand is at the top of the 1NT range you accept the invitation and bid 6NT.

Missing one Ace you bid 6!H.

Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 3!S]
You would have bid 2!S if East had not overcalled. 
Instead, with 4 trumps you can jump to 3!S as a preemptive measure. Partner will not mistake this for a limit raise since you would have cue-bid with 11+ points and support.
The jump to 3 is based on the Law of Total Tricks - bidding to a trick level equal to the number of your side's trumps.

4!S. Partner's jump shows a good overcall, but not enough strength to insist on game when you might have only 11 points. You have plenty extra so you bid the game.

Partner responds 2!S. What do you bid now? [BID pass]

Partner prefers !Ss to !Hs. Since you were bare minimum you pass.

Partner has two suits, !Ds and one of the Majors. If his other suit is !Hs then a 2!H bid by you would work great. But if his other suit is !Ss anything you say would not be good.

You bid your suit, 2!H, and everybody passes. Notice that partner had a decent hand, but could not bid over 1NT in the immediate seat.

Partner makes a DONT double in the balancing seat. What do you bid now? [BID 2!C]

Right now you probably have a premonition about what is going to happen next. But there really is nothing you can say other than 2!C.
Your premonition came true. Partner passes and you are left playing 2!C with a singleton. Nobody promised that DONT would always get you to a good contract.

Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
With one certain !H loser you cannot afford to lose a !D also. You could guess which way to finesse and be correct half of the time. But an elimination play will work ALL of the time.
Win the first trick and play !SA, !SK. Trumps split 2-1.
Click NEXT to see the result of these plays. [NEXT]

[PLAY N:CK,N:C8,N:C2,S:CA,S:CQ,S:C5]

The defender who won the last trick cannot lead a trump because he has none. If he leads a !H or a !C you will get a ruff-sluff, ruffing in one hand while discarding a !D loser from the other. If he leads a !D you will get the free finesse you were hoping for all along.
Click NEXT to see all the hands. [NEXT]

The eliminations are complete and it is time for the throw-in. Play the small !H from whichever hand you are in. This will be taken by one of the defenders.
Click NEXT. [NEXT]
[PLAY N:H6,S:H3]
No matter which defender wins the !H he is end-played. A !H or a !C will give you a ruff-sluff, but if he leads a !D you cannot be prevented from establishing either your !DQ or !DJ as a winner.
Click to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
[PLAY S:D6]
Only by forcing them to start the !Ds can you take a trick in the suit.

Auction: 1S | pass 3S pass 6S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
South is to play 6!S. West leads the !HQ.

This is another follow-up to Deal 1. But this time you are missing both the !DQ and !DJ. In this case an Elimination play doesn't give you a guarantee, it just improves your odds.
Win the first trick and play !SA, !SK. Trumps split 2-1.
Click NEXT. [NEXT]
[PLAY N:SK,N:S4,N:H4,N:CK,N:C2,S:SA,S:S3,S:HA,S:CQ]

Now execute the throw-in by leading a !H from either hand.
Click NEXT. [NEXT]
[PLAY N:H6,S:H3]
The defender who gets thrown in cannot play a !H or a !C without handing you the contract by way of a ruff-and-sluff. So he must lead a !D. Suppose it is West who leads the !D. You play low in dummy and East must play either the !DQ or !DJ to keep you from getting a cheap trick with your !D9. So you take East's honor with your !DA and then finesse West for the other honor. As long as the !DQ and !DJ are in different hands the elimination play will succeed.
Click NEXT to see the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
By forcing them to start the !Ds you make three tricks when the two outstanding honors are divided.

Auction: 1C pass 1S | pass 2S pass 4S | pass pass pass

Auction: 1S | pass 3S pass 6S | pass pass pass

Auction: 1NT | pass 2D pass 2H | pass 3NT pass 4H | pass pass pass

Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
[PLAY N:S8,N:S3,S:ST,S:S5]

Whichever defender wins the !DQ is end-played. If he plays a !D or a !S you will ruff in one hand and discard a !C loser from the other. But if he leads a !C instead you no longer have a !C loser.
Clickfor the complete deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
However, it also guarantees that you will not make an overtrick.
If you try the two finesses instead you MIGHT make an overtrick, but you also might go down 1.
Decide for yourself!

If West puts on either the !CT or !CJ you play dummy's !CQ. If East can win with the !CK he will once again be end-played, forced to either play a !C back to dummy's !CA 9, or give you a ruff-sluff.

In this case though, West's overcall means all things are not equal, so your chances are lower than 75%.

Auction: 1NT pass 3C | pass 4C pass 6C | pass pass pass
Analysis:
South considered Blackwood, then realized if North showed either 2 or 3 Aces he was going to bid slam. But if North showed just one Ace he would have to maneuver to play 5NT which might be worse than 6!C. So he just bid the slam. South plays 6!C. West leads the !SJ.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Perhaps an elimination play will improve your chances. Don't lead a trump yet though, you're going to need several entries to dummy to eliminate the !Hs. 
Win the !S, play to the !HA and ruff a !H.
Click NEXT. [NEXT]
[PLAY N:SQ,N:HA,N:H2,S:SA,S:H5,S:C9]

Now execute the throw-in by leading a !S. If West wins the trick he will have to play !Ds for you or give you a ruff-sluff. So if these are competent defenders they will make sure that it is EAST who wins the !S trick. So he does, and he plays a small !D.
Click NEXT. [NEXT]
[PLAY N:S5,S:S4]
DO NOT PLAY THE JACK! If the finesse is going to work now it will still work one trick later. By playing low you take advantage of the possibility that East held the !DT and West will have to put on the !DQ to prevent you taking a trick with dummy's !D9.
Click to see the Deal. [NEXT]
Here you had two chances. First, West might have HAD to win the throw-in, either because he had all of the high !Ss, or more likely because he messed up. The second chance paid off when East took the throw-in but you found a fortunate position with the !Ds.

Click NEXT. [NEXT]
[PLAY N:S9,N:D8,S:SK,S:S2]
Too bad, the !DA did not fall so dummy's !DK is not a winner. But it will still prove to be useful. 
Play the !HA, then ruff a !H in dummy. Play a trump to your !SA and ruff your last !H.
Click NEXT. [NEXT]
[PLAY N:ST,N:S7,N:S5,N:H7,S:SA,S:HA,S:H6,S:H3]
You are in dummy, just where you want to be. Play the !DK, and when East plays the !DA don't ruff but instead discard a !C from your hand. You knew all along that he held the !DA.
Click NEXT. [NEXT]
[PLAY N:DK,S:C4]
East is end-played, forced to either break the !Cs and give you a !C trick, or give you a ruff-sluff.
Click for the full deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
It also depended upon the defenders not switching to !Cs at the second trick. If West had decided to switch to the !CQ you would have had no chance at all.

Auction: 1H | pass 3H pass 6H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
After hearing a limit raise, South's leap to 6!H is, well, bold let's say. South plays 6!H. West leads the !S5, East plays the !SK.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Win the !SA, play the !DJ to dummy's !DK and discard the !SJ on dummy's !DA.
Click NEXT. [NEXT]
[PLAY N:S6,N:DA,N:DK,S:SA,S:SJ,S:DJ]
You are in dummy, so ruff the !S7 with a high trump. Next play the !H9 to dummy's !HJ. Both defenders follow, whew!
Click NEXT. [NEXT]
[PLAY N:S7,N:HJ,S:HA,S:H9]
Back in dummy, ruff a !D with the !HQ, then lead the !HT to dummy's !HK, pulling the last trump as you enter dummy.
Click NEXT. [NEXT]
[PLAY N:HK,N:D4,S:HQ,S:HT]
It would be great if you could ruff dummy's last !D, then get back to dummy with a trump so you could lead a !C from dummy and finesse. But check your trumps. If you do that you will have no more trumps in your hand and West won't be endplayed because you have no ruff-sluff. The only thing you can do is to go ahead and play !Cs now, finessing into West and HOPING he has no more !Ds!
Click to see if you made the slam. [NEXT]
But if it had turned out that West DID have another !D, and led it, all would not be lost. You would ruff in your hand, play a trump to dummy, then take a second !C finesse. If it turned out the !CK and !CQ were in different hands you would make the slam.

Auction: 2NT | 3S 6NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
Some bidding, huh? Well, what would you have bid in the North seat? South plays 6NT. West leads the !DJ.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
That means you will have to make two !S tricks. And since the odds are 5000 to 1 that West has the !SK, leading toward your !SQ is NOT your play.
Win the !D and play 4 rounds of !Cs. West follows to the first, then discards 3 !Ss.
Click NEXT. [NEXT]
[PLAY N:D2,N:CK,N:CJ,N:C6,N:C2,S:DK,S:CA,S:CQ,S:C5,S:C4]
Next play 3 !H winners. West follows twice, then discards a !S.
Click NEXT. [NEXT]
[PLAY N:HK,N:HQ,N:HJ,S:HA,S:H9,S:H6]
Now play your 2 !D winners. East and West both follow.
Click NEXT. [NEXT]
[PLAY N:D7,N:D5,S:DA,S:DQ]
Keeping your fingers crossed that West must win the next trick you play the !S9. West puts on the !ST, you play low in dummy, and East (thankfully) discards a !H. 
Click NEXT. [NEXT]
[PLAY N:S2,S:S9]
West has been thrown in and he has nothing left but the !S K J. Whichever one he plays you will take the last two tricks.
Clickfor the complete Deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
In fact, it just kept you from making a losing play, (leading toward the !SQ), and allowed you to find the end-play to make the slam.

Auction: 1NT | pass 2C 2S 3H | pass 4H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
South is to play 4!H. West leads the !S6, taken by East with the !SA. East returns the !SQ, you play the !SK and West ruffs. West next leads the !DJ.   
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
[PLAY N:S3,N:S2,S:SK,S:S5]
After that unfortunate start you seem to be in a bit of trouble. Two tricks are already in the defender's pockets and you still have a !S loser and a !D loser. So you win with your !DK and play two rounds of trumps.
Click NEXT. [NEXT]
[PLAY N:HJ,N:H6,N:D3,S:HA,S:H5,S:DK]
The good news is that West started with three trumps, and since he already used one it only takes two pulls to pick up the remaining trumps.
Eliminate !Cs by playing !CA, !CK, and ruffing a !C. Both defenders follow to all three !Cs.
Click NEXT. [NEXT]
[PLAY N:H8,N:CA,N:C9,S:CK,S:C7,S:C4]
So far East has followed suit to every trick, meaning he has not discarded a single !S. Since you know he started with 6 !Ss, his final 5 cards consist of 4 !Ss and one other. You play to the !DA and East follows suit again.
Click NEXT. [NEXT]
[PLAY N:DA,S:D2]
Play dummy's !S7. East will win, but he has nothing left but !Ss. When he plays another !S you discard your !D loser and ruff in dummy.
Clickfor the complete deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
However, the key is that you could tell they were eliminated from the East hand, and East was going to be the throw-in target because of his long !Ss. 
In many hands an opponent who opens with a preemptive bid gives you the information you need to plan and execute the throw-in.

Auction: 1NT | pass 2H pass 2S | pass 4S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
North first transfers you to !Ss, then closes the auction with 4!S. 
South is to play 4!S. West leads the !C2. East takes the !CA and returns the !C9 to West's !CK. West plays another !C to your !CQ. 
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
[PLAY N:C8,N:C7,N:C6,S:CQ,S:CJ,S:C4]
With two tricks lost already you have a sure !D loser (unless the defenders goof) and a !H loser that might be taken care of if East holds the !HK. But what if West holds the !HK? Maybe an elimination play.
First pull trumps - they split 2-1.
Click NEXT. [NEXT]
[PLAY N:SA,N:S3,S:SK,S:S2]
Next eliminate !Ds by playing !DA then another !D. This does the elimination and throw-in at the same time.
Click NEXT. [NEXT]
[PLAY N:DA,N:D2,S:DQ,S:D7]
If the defender who won the !DK plays a !D or a !C you will ruff in your hand and discard dummy's !H loser. So that defender is going to have to lead a !H.
If it is West who won the !DK you are home free. His !H play will give you two !H tricks.
If it is East who won the !DK you still have a chance. He will lead a !H and you will finesse the !HQ.
In other words, played this way you make the contract whenever West holds the !DK OR East holds the !HK.
Click to see all the hands.. [NEXT]
But if the !DK is with East and the !HK with West it wouldn't.
Of course it is POSSIBLE that if you played a low !D from dummy some Easts would duck and let you win a trick with your !DQ. 
This trickery would fail if West held the !DK, or if East held it and went up right away.

Auction: 2S 3C | pass 4NT pass 5H | pass 6C pass pass | pass
Analysis:
South plays 6!C. West leads the !S8.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
You have one !S loser and one !D loser. A successful finesse will take care of either one of them. Chance of the !S finesse working? Zero. Chance of the !D finesse working? Maybe 50%. Chance of an elimination play? Priceless.
Win the !SA and pull trumps with the !CA and !CQ. They split 2-1.
Click NEXT. [NEXT]
[PLAY N:SA,N:C8,N:C7,S:S3,S:CA,S:CQ]
Play the !DA, just in case there is a singleton !DQ somewhere. There isn't. Then eliminate !Hs by playing !HA and ruff a !H.
Click NEXT. [NEXT]
[PLAY N:H6,N:DA,N:CT,S:HA,S:H7,S:D3]
Now play a low !S from both hands. West doesn't follow suit as East wins with a small card.
Click NEXT. [NEXT]
[PLAY N:S2,S:S4]
East is end-played. He has no !Cs. If he plays a !D it will be into dummy's !D K J. If he plays a !H you will discard a !D from your hand and ruff in dummy. If he plays the !SK you will ruff, and dummy's !SQ will be promoted. If he plays a small !S you will let it ride to dummy's !SQ.
Click to see the complete Deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
I hope you enjoyed them.

Auction: 1H pass 1S | pass 3D pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
South is to play 3NT. West leads the !C3.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Winners:   !S = 0    !H = 5  !D = 1    !C = 2 Total = 8
You only need one more winner and your !S K Q will provide it. So, is there anything that could go wrong? - - Like could you mess up your entry?
Click [NEXT]
Suppose you play the !CJ from dummy on the first trick. And then suppose West puts the !CQ on. If you take your !CA you have used your entry to the !S K Q before you established one of them. But if you don't take the trick East will play another !C to remove dummy's !CK with the same effect. So what should you do?
Click [NEXT]
It's easy once you think about it. Just win the opening lead with dummy's !CK. Then, while it's fresh in your mind play to your !S K Q to establish the one extra winner you need. Then it's just a question of taking your winners.
Clickfor the complete Deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
Making a plan before they play to the first trick is one of the strengths of winning bridge players.

Auction: pass pass 2NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
South is to play 3NT. West leads the !D5. You play the !D9 from dummy and East plays the !D4.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Winners:   !S = 1    !H = 2  !D = 2    !C = 0 Total = 5
The bad news is that you must come up with 4 more winners!The good news is dummy's !C suit.
You can drive out the !CA, then get over to dummy for those !C winners. You will be able to get over to dummy, won't you?
Click [NEXT]
Not if you let the !D9 hold the first trick. The defender with the !CA will hold it up until the third round, then West will be able to play his !DK so as to prevent you from entering dummy.
But take first trick with the !DA and the !D Q J will be there guaranteeing you an entry to those two good !Cs.
Click NEXT to see the full Deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]
But look carefully at the !D situation. You are going to get exactly two !D tricks no matter when you play your !DA. So you don't lose a trick, but you do gain an entry.

Auction: 1H pass 1NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
South is to play 3NT. West leads the !C4.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Winners:   !S = 2    !H = 0  !D = 1    !C = 1 Total = 4
Looks like you're going to need some !D tricks. Lots of them. And it also looks like you are going to have to be very careful with entries, which shouldn't surprise you at this time. So what is your first key move?
Click NEXT. [NEXT]
The !C situation is exactly the same as the !Ds in Deal 2, but flipped North to South. And you must handle it exactly the same way - jump up with the !CA right away to preserve the !C Q J combination as a sure entry to your hand.
Having done that, are your problems (and thinking) over?
Click NEXT. [NEXT]
Not quite, there is one more hurdle to hurdle. You must put all thought of a !D finesse far out of your mind. Play !DA, then !DT, overtaking with !DJ and continuing the suit until the King appears. Now you should be able to come to 9 tricks unless there is a very unfortunate distribution which lets the defenders score 3 !H tricks along with their 1 !C and 1 !D.
Clickfor the complete Deal. [NEXT]
[RESET]

Auction: 1H | pass 2H pass 4H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
South is to play 4!H. West leads the !CA, !C K, !CQ.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
Losers:   !S = 1    !H = 0  !D = 1    !C = 2 Total = 4
