Analysis: [BID 1!S]\nYou open 1!S and partner responds 2!H. What do you bid next? [BID 4!H]\nPartner has shown 11+ points and at least 4 !Hs. Your hand revalues to 16 points in support of !Hs, where you know you have an 8-card fit or better. You bid 4!H confidently.

Auction: 1S | pass 1NT pass 3S | pass 4S pass pass | pass |
Analysis: [BID 1!S]\nWe all know you will open 1!S with this hand. And after partner responds 1NT what is your next bid? [BID 3!S]\nWith 6 of them you can rebid !Ss but you are too strong to say just 2!S. Your 17 points puts you in the Medium range where you make a jump. So you bid 3!S and partner bids 4!S.

Auction: 1H | pass 3H pass 4NT | pass 5H pass 6H | pass pass pass |
Analysis:
[BID 1!H]
This is a big hand. But not quite enough to open 2!C. So you open 1!H and partner responds 3!H. Now what? [BID 4NT]
You might bid 4!D as a slam try, but it is probably just as well to go ahead and ask for Aces. So you bid 4NT and partner owns up to holding 2 Aces. What is your next bid? [BID 6!H]
You have all the Aces but don't go crazy. Partner only has 11-12 points so don't think too Grand! Bid 6!H.

Auction: 1H pass 2H | pass 4H pass pass | pass | |
Analysis: [BID 2!H]\nWith 6 points you must respond and you should let partner know you have support for his suit. So you bid 2!H and he promptly raises to 4!H. It's a good thing he had 20 points isn't it.

Auction: 1H pass 4H | pass pass pass | | |
Analysis: [BID 4!H]\nWhen you have a weak, distributional hand with 5 of partner's suit an immediate jump to game is usually the best approach. If he has a good hand you will probably make the contract. If he is minimum then you might get a preemptive effect and stop your LHO from entering the bidding.\nThis is a good example. Partner may be lucky and make 4!H. But if they had had an opportunity to compete the opponents might well be able to make 4!S.

Auction: 1H pass 1S | pass 3H pass 4H | pass pass pass | |
Analysis: [BID 1!S]\nYou can't support partner's !Hs with only 2 of them so you bid your nice !S suit. Partner then jumps to 3!H. Now what do you bid? [BID 4!H]\nHere's where a lot of players go wrong. Since they only promised 4 !Ss with their first response they think they should now rebid them to show partner they had 5. And this MIGHT work if it turns out partner has 3 !Ss. Not only is this a risky bid, it is unnecessary. When partner jump rebid !Hs he showed 16-18 points and 6 !Hs. So you know of an 8-card fit and you know you should be in game. Bid 4!H.

Auction: 1S pass 2C | pass 2D pass 4S | pass 4NT pass 5D | pass 6S all pass |
Analysis:
[BID 2!C]
As soon as partner opens 1!S you know you will settle for nothing less than the !S game. The problem with bidding 4!S right now is that partner will take you for the "weak-distributional-with-five-trumps" hand. So you temporize by first bidding 2!C. Partner rebids 2!D. What do you say now? [BID 4!S]
You now jump to 4!S, completing the picture of an opening hand with good !S support. Partner bids 4NT. What say you? [BID 5!D]
This is Blackwood so you answer 5!D for one Ace. Partner says 6!S.

Auction: 1H pass 3H | pass 4H pass pass | pass | |
Analysis:
[BID 3!H]
You could bid 1!S. Many would do so, thinking "I have to show partner my !S suit."
In fact, you don't have to show partner your !S suit. You already know of a partnership 9-card fit in !Hs, so there is no reason to search for a possible 8-card fit in !Ss.
With 11 points and 4 trumps you bid 3!H, a limit raise. Partner raises to game.

Auction: 1H pass 1S | pass 2S pass 4S | pass pass pass | |
Analysis: [BID 1!S]\nYou MIGHT jump to 2NT to "show your points". However, a notrump bid now would deny a 4-card !S suit. Instead, your priority is to show that Major, so you respond 1!S. Partner bids 2!S. What do you say next? [BID 4!S]\nPartner would not support a response which might be 4 cards unless he had 4 himself. Knowing that you have two opening hands facing each other, each containing 4 !Ss, you bid the !S game.

Auction: 1S pass 2S | pass 3S pass 4S | pass pass pass | |
Analysis: [BID 2!S]\nWith 4-card support you respond 2!S. Partner raises to 3!S. What do you say next? [BID 4!S]\nPartner's bid is an invitation. You have told him you have 6-10 points and he probably has about 17-18. If you are at the high end of your 6-T he wants you to bid game, at the low end he wants you to pass. You actually have T, definitely high end, so you bid 4!S.

Auction: 1S pass 2S | pass 3C pass 3S | pass pass pass | |
Analysis:
[BID 2!S]
With 7 points and good trumps you respond 2!S. Partner now bids 3!C. What do you bid next? [BID 3!S]
Again partner is inviting you to bid game. He wants you to bid it if you are at the top of your 6-T range, and he wants you to particularly promote any Help you can give him in !Cs.
You are at the bottom of your range and you have no help in !Cs, so you just return to !Ss. Partner passes.

Auction: 1H pass 2H | pass 3D pass 4H | pass pass pass | |
Analysis: [BID 2!H]\nYour only reasonable response is 2!H. Partner now bids 3!D. What do you say? [BID 4!H]\nWith 8 points you are right in the middle of the 6-10 points you promised. So you could either accept partner's invitation or decline it. BUT, he said you should particularly look at any Help you could provide in !Ds. Since you have lots of good stuff in that suit you upgrade your 8 points and bid 4!H.

Auction: 1D 2D | pass 2S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 2!D]

A perfect Michaels example; 5-5 in the Majors and 9 points. You bid 2!D and partner says 2!S. What do you bid next? [BID pass]

You have a rather minimum Michaels type hand and you asked partner to choose a Major suit. He chose !Ss. But don't start thinking about what great support you have for his !S suit, he doesn't HAVE a !S suit, he is just supporting yours. In other words, you pass.

Auction: 1C 2C pass 2H | pass pass pass
Analysis: The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 2!H]\n\nYou have a fair hand with a guaranteed 8-card fit in either Major. You are not, however, strong enough to jump the bidding. So you bid 2!H, which is passed out.

Auction: 1H 2NT | pass 3C pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 2NT]

You have a pretty good hand for an Unusual Notrump, but not so good that you wouldn't use the convention. You bid 2NT and partner says 3!C. What do you say next? [BID pass]

As mentioned, you have a pretty good hand, but partner only bid because you forced him to and he showed nothing more than minimum. So you pass.

Auction: 1S 2NT pass 3D | pass pass pass
Analysis: The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 3!D]\n\nYour best suit is !Hs. But partner didn't ask you to bid !Hs, he asked you to pick a Minor. You know you will have an 8-card fit in !Ds so you take the safe approach and bid 3!D. Everybody passes.

Auction: 1S 2S | pass 4H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 2!S]

Of course you bid a Michaels Cue-Bid of 2!S. Partner says 4!H. What do you bid now? [BID pass]

Partner's jump might indicate he has a really good hand, or he might just have a really good fit. You certainly don't have the strength to make another move so you pass. A good thing, too. Partner might get lucky and make this but it looks like the other guys are cold for 4!S. Even if partner loses 2 !H tricks and goes down 1 it will turn out to be a good sacrifice.

Auction: 1H 2NT pass 3NT | pass pass pass | |
Analysis: The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 3NT]\n\nYou have no idea what you can make with this hand. Slam in one of the minors may be possible, but maybe not. You decide to try 3NT.

Auction: 1C 2NT | pass 4D pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 2NT]

With the two lowest unbid suits you bid 2NT. Partner jumps to 4!D. What do you bid? [BID pass]

Partner probably has a good hand, but he might just be preempting. Assuming he is inviting you to bid game you have a tough decision. You are not very strong but you might have been a couple of points weaker. It is strictly a judgement call and we decide to pass.
As you can see, IF they open the lead with a !C, and IF the !H finesse then works, you can make 5!D.

Auction: 1D 2D pass 3S | pass 4S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 3!S]

As you have figured out by now, using Michaels Cue-Bids / Unusual Notrump is sometimes hard to tie down. Here you have 13/14 points and if you figure partner for 9 that won't be enough for game. But, those two Minor Aces are worth a lot when you figure partner has only 3 Minor suit cards.
So let's say you decide to just invite with 3!S. Partner takes you to game.
You will surely make this game if trumps split 2-2. If they don't then you will have to hope for a defensive mistake.

Auction: 1S 2S | pass 2NT pass 3D | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 2!S]

With 5 cards in the "other" Major and a 5-card Minor you bid 2!S, Michaels of course. Partner bids 2NT. What do you say next? [BID 3!D]

Is it possible that partner wants to play Notrump? Not at all. He hates !Hs and wants you to bid your Minor suit. So you say 3!D and he passes.

Auction: 1C 2NT pass 3D | pass 4D pass 5D | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 3!D]

Partner asked you to choose between !Hs and !Ds so you bid 3!D. He then raises you to 4!D. What do you bid? [BID 5!D]

If you say to yourself "I only have 7 HCP" then you might pass. But if you say "Partner invited me to bid game, even though I might have no points and only 3 trumps. I'm a lot better than that.", then you will accept the invitation. So you bid 5!D and everybody passes.

Auction: 1H 1S | pass 2H pass 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 1!S]

With 5 cards in the "other" Major and a 5-card Minor suit this looks like an ideal Michaels Cue-Bid, right? No, not really. While it would not be a capital offense to bid 2!H here, it generally works out better with 13-16 point hands to just overcall in your higher-ranking suit. You bid 1!S. Partner responds 2!H. What do you bid? [BID 4!S]

Partner's cue-bid shows a limit-raise or better in !Ss. So you bid 4!S without the blink of an eye.

Auction: 1H 2H pass 2NT | pass 3C pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 2NT]

Partner is 5-5 in !Ss and one of the Minor suits. Forget !Ss, you want him to bid the Minor. So you bid 2NT. Partner says 3!C. What do you bid now? [BID pass]

Partner only made a minimum bid, so you have no choice but to pass.

Auction: 1D 2D | pass 2H pass 3H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 2!D]

With 18 points and 5-5 Major suits you are up in the high-level Michaels category. You bid 2!D and partner responds 2!H. What do you bid next? [BID 3!H]

Yes, you have a high-level Michaels hand but don't get carried away. Remember that you forced partner to bid. Any bid at all by you at this point will show 17+ points, so you just raise to 3!H. Partner has a weak hand and passes.

Auction: 1C 2NT pass 3S | pass pass pass
Analysis: The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 3!S]\n\nPartner wants you to bid !Hs or !Ds. You figure that in either of the red suits you will have a 7-card fit. You hope to do better than that in !Ss. So you bid 3!S and everybody passes.

Auction: 1C 2C | pass 2S pass 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 2!C]

You have 20 points and two good 5-card Majors so you bid a Michaels 2!C. Partner responds 2!S. What do you say next? [BID 4!S]

Partner may have as few as zero points and as many as 13 or so. You COULD bid an invitational 3!S, but if he has only 5 or 6 points he will pass. Looking at your hand you only need to find partner with !S J x x to have a good shot at game. So go ahead and bid 4!S.
Will you look at that. Partner has only 2 points, but what great ones to have!

Auction: 1D 2D pass 4H | pass pass pass
Analysis: The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 4!H]\n\nPartner has 5 of each Major suit so you know of a good 9-card !H fit. You have a nice hand and must decide between inviting with 3!H or bidding the game on your own. You decide to bid the game so you say 4!H and everybody passes.

Auction: 1S 2NT | pass 3S pass 4C | pass 5C pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 2NT]

This is a really good hand for Unusual Notrump. You bid 2NT and partner says 3!S. What do you say now? [BID 4!C]

Partner apparently has a big hand. His cue-bid is forcing, and probably means he wants to be in game. But for now you can just show your minimum strength and give a suit preference. You bid 4!C and partner raises to 5!C.

Auction: 1C 2C 3C pass | pass pass
Analysis: The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID pass]\n\nMany times at Bridge you want to fight for the contract. This isn't one of them. With 6 HCP and only four cards total in partner's two suits just let the opponents have it. You pass.

Auction: 1D 2D | pass 3C pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 2!D]

With two 5-card Majors of course you bid 2!D. Partner responds 3!C. What do you say now? [BID pass]

This wasn't according to your script. Partner was supposed to choose a Major. The reason he didn't, of course, is that he didn't like either one and figured you would be better in !Cs. So you pass.

Auction: 1D 2D 3D 3S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 3!S]

You don't have a great hand but you DO have 4 !Ss. So don't let the opponents have a 3-level contract when your side has 9 !Ss. Bid 3!S.
Note: See the Law of Total Tricks Lesson on this topic.

Auction: 1D | pass 1H pass 2H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You dealt this hand. Decide what you would say, then click BID above. [BID 1!D]

With 13 points you will open. You cannot bid 1!H with only 4 of them, so you say 1!D. Partner responds 1!H and it is your bid again. [BID 2!H]

Partner's response is forcing. He might have anywhere from 6 points to about 17. With a minimum opener and 4-card support for his Major suit you bid 2!H. Partner passes.

Auction: 1D | pass 1NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You dealt this hand. What do you bid? [BID 1!D]

You are not strong enough to open 1NT, but too strong to pass. You bid 1!D. Partner responds 1NT. What do you say next? [BID pass]

You are not strong enough to open 1NT, but too strong to pass. You bid 1!D. Partner responds 1NT. What do you say next?
With that small doubleton in !Cs it is very tempting to rescue partner from 1NT by bidding 2!S. There are three good reasons why you don't. First, bidding 1!D followed by 2!S is a REVERSE, which shows a strong hand, perhaps 16-17 points or more. Second, and even more important, partner's 1NT bid DENIES a 4-card Major suit. And third, partner probably has something in !Cs since he has no 4-card Major and also didn't feel like supporting your !Ds.
So you pass and hope for the best.

Auction: 1C | pass 1H pass 4H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You dealt this hand. What do you bid? [BID 1!C]

The !H and !S suits look really good, but neither of them are 5 cards, so you open 1!C. Partner responds 1!H. What is your next bid? [BID 4!H]

Partner's bid shows 6-10 points and at least 4 !Hs. Since you now know there is an 8-card Major suit fit you revalue your hand, adding 2 more points for the singleton !D.
That gives you 20 points; add partner's 6-T and you have enough for game. She who knows, goes, so you bid 4!H.

Auction: 1C | pass 1S pass 3S | pass 4S all pass
Analysis:
You dealt this hand. What do you bid? [BID 1!C]

You have the right strength but the wrong distribution to open 1NT. So you bid 1!C. Partner responds 1!S. What do you say next? [BID 3!S]

With partner's !S bid giving you a fit, your hand revalues to 18 points. If partner has only 6 or 7 points there is not enough for game, but if he has more than that then you should bid game.
When you are in-between like this you just invite. So you jump to 3!S. This tells partner to bid game if he has more than the minimum for his bid. He has 9 revalued points, so he bids 4!S.

Auction: 1D | pass 2NT pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You dealt this hand. What do you bid? [BID 1!D]

This is the one situation when you open a 3-card !D suit; two 4-card Majors, three !Ds and two !Cs, but not enough strength to open 1NT.
Partner responds 2NT. What do you bid? [BID 3NT]

Partner's bid shows 13-16 points, balanced. And most importantly, it denies holding a 4-card Major suit. So you do not consider bidding either your !Hs or !Ss, but just bid 3NT.

Auction: 1D | pass 1NT pass 2C | pass 3C pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You dealt this hand. What do you bid? [BID 1!D]

With a 5-card and a 4-card Minor you open the 5-card. Partner responds 1NT. What do you say now? [BID 2!C]

With only 14 points a pass might be the best bid. But with doubletons in both Majors, knowing partner does not have 4 of either, you elect to bid 2!C. Partner now surprises you and bids 3!C. It's your bid. [BID pass]

Partner evidently found some hidden treasure when he revalued! But you still have only 16 points at the most so you pass.

Auction: 1C | pass 3C pass 4NT | pass 5D pass 6C | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You dealt this hand. What do you bid? [BID 1!C]

Nice hand! But not strong enough to open with anything other than 1!C. Partner jumps to 3!C! What do you bid? [BID 4NT]

You might be tempted to mention one of your Majors at this point, but resist the temptation. Trust that your partner also knows the bidding priorities and that he would have bid a 4-card Major if he had held one. The problem with you now saying 3!H for example, is that partner would probably think you had a 5-card !H suit and support you with only 3 of them. You know that !Cs is your suit so stick to it.
With partner showing 13-16 points, and your hand revaluing to 21 you are definitely thinking slam. It would not be terrible to just bid 6!C right now, but Blackwood was invented just for these situations, to make sure you are not missing 2 Aces when you bid a slam. So you bid 4NT. Partner answers with 5!D. What say you? [BID 6!C]

Blackwood did its job. You are missing one Ace so all thoughts of a Grand are put aside. Bid 6!C.

Auction: 1D | pass 3D pass 3NT | pass pass pass |
Analysis:
You dealt this hand. What do you bid? [BID 1!D]

This would be a perfect hand to open 1NT - well, it would be if it held one more point. But with only 14 you open your 4-card Minor, 1!D. Partner responds 3!D.
What do you say now? [BID 3NT]

Partner suggests that !Ds is your suit, and he may be right. But you would much rather play the less demanding Notrump game if he is willing. So you bid 3NT, knowing that if partner is really distributional he will take you back to !Ds. He doesn't, so you play 3NT.

Auction: 1C | pass 1S pass 2NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You dealt this hand. What do you bid? [BID 1!C]

This would be an ideal hand to open 1NT - well, it would be with one less point. But with 18 you are too strong to open 1NT so you open 1!C. Partner responds 1!S. What do you bid next? [BID 2NT]

DO NOT fall into the trap of supporting partner's !Ss just because you have such nice help for him. He might have a 4-card suit. Instead, just describe your hand by jumping to 2NT, showing a balanced hand with 18-19 points. Partner now bids 3NT and you play it there.

Auction: 1D | pass 1S pass 2NT | pass 3S pass 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You dealt this hand. What do you bid? [BID 1!D]

You open 1!D and partner responds 1!S. What is your next bid? [BID 2NT]

Do not support what may be a 4-card suit with only 3 cards. Instead, jump to 2NT, showing 18-19, balanced. Partner rebids the !Ss. What do you say next? [BID 4!S]

Partner shows a minimum hand, but with 6 !Ss. 3NT is very tempting, and might work out fine, but with 9 !Ss it is probably better to play the suit game. So you bid 4!S and everybody passes.
Bidding 4!S was a good choice. It makes easily, yet 3NT might have gone down.

Auction: 1C pass 1S | pass 2S pass pass | |
Analysis:
The bidding is shown. Decide what you would say, then click BID. [BID 1!S]

You have plenty good support to raise partner's !C suit. But your first priority is to show a 4-card Major suit if you have one. You do, so you respond 1!S. Partner raises you to 2!S. What do you bid now? [BID pass]

Are you tempted to take partner back to !Cs since you have such good support? Don't be. Partner has 4 !Ss, but he might have only 3 !Cs.
Are you tempted to bid 3!S since partner raised you? Don't be. He showed a minimum hand with his single raise and you only have 9 points. Just pass.

Auction: 1D pass 1H | pass 2H pass 4H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding is shown. Decide what you would say, then click BID. [BID 1!H]

Some might jump to 2NT, "to show partner my point count". Some might jump to 3!D, "to force partner to game and show my !D support". The wise ones will just bid 1!H, striving to find an 8-card Major fit, the first priority of bidding.
You choose the 1!H route, and partner obligingly says 2!H. What do you bid next? [BID 4!H]

Remember "She who knows, goes"? You know of the 8-card Major fit. You know of at least 26 combined points. You know you should bid 4!H, so you do.

Auction: 1C pass 1H | pass 1S pass 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding is shown. Decide what you would say, then click BID. [BID 1!H]

When you have two 4-card suits to show you bid them "up-the-line". In this case it means you say 1!H. Partner replies 1!S. What do you bid? [BID 4!S]

There are enough points for game and a known 8-card Major fit. So you bid 4!S.
Perfect bidding isn't always rewarded. They can win three !D tricks and the Ace of trumps. If the opening lead is a !H or a !C you might make it, so it just depends on luck.

Auction: 1D pass 2NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding is shown. Decide what you would say, then click BID. [BID 2NT]

You have two very good choices, neither of which is really wrong. You could bid 2NT, showing 13-16 points, balanced, or you could bid 3!D, showing 13-16 points, good trump support.
What should decide you is the bidding priorities. You'd much rather try to play a 9-trick game than an 11-trick game. And at the same time you must trust your partner not to leave you hung out in Notrump with an unsuitable hand. (Can you believe I wrote Notrump and unsuitable in the same sentence?)
Anyway, you bid 2NT and partner raises to 3NT.

Auction: 1C pass 1H | pass 1S pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding is shown. Decide what you would say, then click BID. [BID 1!H]

With 14 points and a 4-3-3-3 distribution this could be the perfect hand for a jump to 2NT. But not when the 4-card suit is a Major - you should not skip bidding a Major when you have the opportunity.
So you respond 1!H. Partner says 1!S. What do you bid? [BID 3NT]

Partner doesn't have 4 !Hs so you go back to thinking this is an ideal notrump hand. So ideal that you apply the "She who knows, goes" principle and bid 3NT. Partner smiles and passes.

Auction: 1D pass 3D | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding is shown. Decide what you would say, then click BID. [BID 3!D]

You have great !D support and perhaps 15 points. The "perhaps" is because partner may have only 3 !Ds, and if you are the long-trump hand any ruffs you take will probably not increase the number of trump tricks your side makes. But still, you have a great hand.
So you bid 3!D. Partner now says 3NT. What do you bid? [BID pass]

You described your hand very well with your first bid. Partner heard the description and chose 3NT. Since you trust your partner you pass.

Auction: 1C pass 1S | pass 3S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding is shown. Decide what you would say, then click BID. [BID 1!S]

You must make a weak response, and in theory there are 3 weak responses you could make with this hand. You could bid 2!C, 1!S or 1NT. And while none of them would be actually incorrect the best choice is to show your 4-card Major.
You bid 1!S. Partner jumps to 3!S. What do you say now? [BID pass]

You started with just 6 points, and after discovering the !S fit you revalue all the way up to 7 points. Partner has shown 16-18 and that's still not enough for game. You pass.

Auction: 1D pass 1H | pass 3H pass 4H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding is shown. Decide what you would say, then click BID. [BID 1!H]

Your top priority as responder is to show a Major suit if you have one, so you say 1!H. Partner jumps to 3!H. What do you say? [BID 4!H]

Partner knows you may have only 6 points and went to the 3-level anyway. He is inviting you to bid game if you have a bit more than the 6 you promised. You revalue up to T so you have quite a bit more. You accept his invitation and bid 4!H.

Auction: 1C pass 1S | pass 3S pass 4NT | pass 5C pass 5S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding is shown. Decide what you would say, then click BID. [BID 1!S]

You have a very big hand. But there is no need to start jumping before you know whether you have a fit. So just bid 1!S, partner cannot pass this bid.
Partner now surprises you with a jump to 3!S!. What do you bid next? [BID 4NT]

Wow! Partner has 16 and you have more than that. Slam appears certain, by why not check for Aces? So you bid 4NT and partner answers 5!C. What do you say next? [BID 5!S]

You probably say "Oh Darn!" or perhaps something less printable. But then you just sign of at 5!S.

Auction: 1D pass 2D | pass 4D pass 5D | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding is shown. Decide what you would say, then click BID. [BID 2!D]

That is great support, but always remember when supporting a Minor that partner might have only 3 of them. So you bid 2!D. Partner jumps to 4!D. What do you bid? [BID 5!D]

You were cautious with your first bid, but that is over now. Partner didn't open with a 3-card suit, he really has !Ds. He bypassed 3NT in a flash, so he has no interest in playing anywhere but a !D contract. He invites you to bid game if you have something extra above the 6 points you already promised. You have a lot more than that, so you bid 5!D.

Auction: 1C pass 1S | pass 1NT pass 2D | pass 2S pass 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 1!S]
With 14 points you will insist on game, but you aren't strong enough to jump shift. So you bid 1!S. Partner rebids 1NT. What do you bid now? [BID 2!D]

Partner has a minimum hand, balanced. You know you want to be in game, but you aren't sure which game. If partner has only 2 !Ss then 3NT should be best. But if he has 3 !Ss then you would prefer to play the 8-card Major fit. The way to find out is with New Minor Forcing. So you bid 2!D. Partner answers with 2!S. What do you bid now? [BID 4!S]

Partner tells you he has 3 !Ss. You already know he has a minimum strength hand. You bid the !S game.

Auction: 1D | pass 1S pass 1NT | pass 2C pass 2NT | pass 3NT all pass
Analysis:
You are the dealer. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 1!D]
With 13 points and 4 cards in each minor suit you should open 1!D. Partner responds 1!S. What do you bid now? [BID 1NT]

You have a minimum, balanced hand. It would not be wrong to say 2!C, but 1NT is probably better. Partner says 2!C. What do you bid now? [BID 2NT]

Do not support the !Cs if you have another decent bid. This is New Minor Forcing and partner may or may not have a !C suit. You do not have 3 !Ss. You do not have a 4-card !H suit. You do have a !H stopper, so bid 2NT. Partner then bids 3NT.

Auction: 1D pass 1H | pass 1NT pass 2C | pass 2H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 1!H]
With 12 points you know game is likely, but for now you bid 1!H. Partner rebids 1NT. What do you say next? [BID 2!C]

Partner has 12-14 points, balanced. If he is at the top, game could still be there, but you aren't sure where to play. If partner has only 2 !Hs then NT is probably best, but if he has 3 !Hs then you would prefer to play the 8-card Major fit. New Minor Forcing will allow partner to answer both questions for you. So you bid 2!C. Partner answers with 2!H. What do you bid now? [BID pass]

Partner tells you he has 3 !Hs. But he also tells you he has minimum strength - in other words not 14 points. So you pass and accept the partscore.

Auction: 1D | pass 1S pass 1NT | pass 2C pass 2H | pass 4H all pass
Analysis:
You are the dealer. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 1!D]
With 13 points you open your 4-card minor, 1!D. Partner responds 1!S. What do you bid now? [BID 1NT]

You have a great !H suit, but can't bid it. A 2!H bid here would be a Reverse and you are nowhere near strong enough. So instead you say 1NT.
Partner says 2!C. What do you bid? [BID 2!H]

This is New Minor Forcing and your first priority is to show a 4-card !H suit. You bid 2!H and partner raises to 4!H.

Auction: 1D pass 1H | pass 1NT pass 2C | pass 2NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 1!H]
With 12 points you know game is likely, but for now you bid 1!H. Partner rebids 1NT. What do you say next? [BID 2!C]

Partner has 12-14 points, balanced. If he is at the top, game could still be there, but you aren't sure where to play. If partner has only 2 !Hs then NT is probably best, but if he has 3 !Hs then you would prefer to play the 8-card Major fit. New Minor Forcing will allow partner to answer both questions for you. So you bid 2!C. Partner answers with 2NT. What do you bid now? [BID pass]

Partner tells you he has only 2 !Hs. He also tells you he only has 12-13 points. So you pass 2NT.

Auction: 1C | pass 1H pass 1NT | pass 2D pass 3H | pass 4H all pass
Analysis:
You are the dealer. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 1!C]
With 14 points you open your 4-card minor, 1!C. Partner responds 1!H. What do you bid now? [BID 1NT]

This is easy. You cannot support !Hs at this point with only 3 cards. So you rebid 1NT.
Partner says 2!D. What do you bid? [BID 3!H]

This is New Minor Forcing. Partner wants to know if you have 3 !Hs. Not only do you have 3 good !Hs, but you also have a maximum hand. So you jump to 3!H and partner bids the game.

Auction: 1C pass 1S | pass 1NT pass 2D | pass 2H pass 4H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 1!S]
You have 12 points and you respond 1!S. Partner rebids 1NT. What do you say next? [BID 2!D]

Partner has 12-14 points, balanced. You have an excellent 4-card !H suit, but if you bid 2!H right now it is not forcing on partner and he will almost surely pass. And you definitely don't have the points to jump to 3!H. New Minor Forcing gives you a way out.
So you say 2!D and your wonderful partner bids 2!H. What now? [BID 4!H]

Your 12 points just got upgraded! Bid 4!H.

Auction: 1D | pass 1H pass 1NT | pass 2C pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You are the dealer. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 1!D]
This 14 point hand is almost good enough to open 1NT, but you bid 1!D. Partner responds 1!H. What do you bid next? [BID 1NT]

You could bid either 1NT or 2!C. You decide on 1NT.
Partner says 2!C. What do you bid? [BID 3NT]

This is NMF, asking if you have 3 !Hs. You only have 2, but you have a great notrump hand now. Since partner must have at least invitational strength you jump right to 3NT.

Auction: 1D pass 1H | pass 1NT pass 2C | pass 2NT pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 1!H]
With 15 points you are going to insist on game. First you respond 1!H. Partner rebids 1NT. What do you say next? [BID 2!C]

Partner has 12-14 points, balanced. You are happy with notrump, but would prefer to play in !Hs if partner has three cards in the suit. To find out if he does, use New Minor Forcing.
So you say 2!C and partner replies 2NT. It is your bid again. [BID 3NT]

Partner doesn't have 3 !Hs. That's what you wanted to know, you bid 3NT.

Auction: 1D | pass 1S pass 1NT | pass 2C pass 3H | pass 4H all pass
Analysis:
You are the dealer. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 1!D]
You have 14 points and you open 1!D. Partner responds 1!S. What do you bid now? [BID 1NT]

You cannot bid 2!H because a Reverse shows at least 16 points. So you bid 1NT. Partner says 2!C. What do you bid now? [BID 3!H]

This is NMF, asking you to further describe your hand. You do not have 3 !Ss. You do have a 4-card !H suit. You have a maximum hand for your previous bidding, so you jump to 3!H. Partner raises to 4!H.

Auction: 1C pass 1S | pass 1NT pass 2D | pass 2H pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 1!S]
You have 14 points and you respond 1!S. Partner rebids 1NT. What is your next bid? [BID 2!D]

Partner has 12-14 points, balanced. You will insist on reaching game, but don't know whether 3NT or 4!S is going to be the best spot. It depends on whether partner has 3 !Ss. So of course you use NMF.
You bid 2!D and partner then says 2!H. Where do you go from here? [BID 3NT]

OK, partner has a 4-card !H suit - may or may not have 3 !Ss. Since you don't have 4 !Hs you bid 3NT, leaving it up to partner to correct to 4!S if he has 3 of them.

Auction: 1C | pass 1S pass 2NT | pass 3D pass 3S | pass 4S all pass
Analysis:
You are the dealer. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 1!C]
You are too strong for 1NT so you open 1!C. Partner responds 1!S. What do you bid now? [BID 2NT]

You don't support !Ss with only 3 cards since partner might well have just a 4-card suit. With 18 points, balanced, all suits stopped, you jump to 2NT.
Partner says 3!D. What do you bid? [BID 3!S]

This is New Minor Forcing. Partner wants to know if you have 3 !Ss. Since you do have 3 you bid 3!S and partner raises to 4!S.

Auction: 1H pass 1S | pass 2NT pass 3C | pass 3NT pass 6NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 1!S]
You have 16 points and you respond 1!S. Partner rebids 2NT. What is your next bid? [BID 3!C]

Partner has 18-19 points, balanced, with 5 !Hs. You are going to bid a slam, either 6NT or 6!S, depending on whether partner has 3 !Ss. Time for New Minor Forcing. 
You bid 3!C rather than 3!D just because your !Cs are stronger. Partner now says 3NT. What do you bid? [BID 6NT]

Partner does not have 3 !Ss. That was the information you needed, so you bid 6NT.

Auction: 1D | pass 1S pass 1NT | pass 2C pass 2D | pass 3NT all pass
Analysis:
You are the dealer. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 1!D]
You have 13 points and you open 1!D. Partner responds 1!S. What do you bid now? [BID 1NT]

With a minimum opener you now bid 1NT. Partner says 2!C. What do you say next? [BID 2!D]

This is NMF, asking you to further describe your hand - and you are stuck for a bid. You do not have 4 !Hs. You do not have 3 !Ss. You do not have a stopper in either !Hs or !Cs so you cannot bid 2NT. Reluctantly you rebid your 5-card !D suit.
Then you breathe a sigh of relief when partner says 3NT.

Auction: 1H 1S 2S | pass 4H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 2!S]

I admit it, I tried to trap you. Just because this is a lesson about Negative Doubles doesn't mean you should abandon your normal good bidding practices. You have a known 8-card !H fit so you don't need to bother telling partner about your two 4-card Minors. With 12 points and support you make a cue-bid in the opponent's suit which tells partner you have limit-raise or better.
Partner now bids 4!H which you pass.

Auction: 1D 1S X | pass 2H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID double]

With 8 points and 4 !Hs you have enough to make a negative double. Partner bids 2!H. What do you say now? [BID pass]

Partner also has 4 !Hs. Unfortunately his strength is only in the 13-15 point range. So you pass.

Auction: 1C | 1S X pass 2H | pass pass pass
Analysis: The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 2!H]\n\nPartner is showing you a !H suit with at least 6 points. With 4 !Hs in a minimum strength hand your rebid is 2!H. Everyone passes.

Auction: 1D 1H X | pass 2S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID double]

You just scrape 7 points together. With your 4-card Major that's enough for a Negative Double. So you double and partner jumps to 2!S. What is your bid? [BID pass]

Partner's jump is inviting but it takes more than just a simple jump to get you excited with this junk. Even though partner has 16-18 points you pass.

Auction: 1D | 1H X pass 2S | pass 4S pass pass | pass
Analysis: The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 2!S]\n\nPartner has indicated a 4-card !S suit. Since you also have 4 you will naturally bid them. However, with the !S fit your hand revalues to 17 points. So you jump to 2!S. Partner bids the game.

Auction: 1C 1S X | pass 2H pass 4H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID double]

With 13 points and 4 of the "other" Major you make a Negative Double. Partner's rebid is 2!H. What is your next bid? [BID 4!H]

Partner has 4 !Hs and an opening hand. You have 4 !Hs and an opening hand. That adds up to a game bid and an 8-card !H fit. You bid 4!H.

Auction: 1C | 1D X pass 2NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis: The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 2NT]\n\nPartner's Negative Double in this situation shows both Majors. You can't support either Major but with 18 points and good !D stoppers you jump to 2NT. Partner bids 3NT and everybody passes.

Auction: 1D 1H X | pass 2S pass 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID double]

If you bid 1!S now it would be showing a 5-card !S suit. So instead you make a Negative Double. Partner jumps to 2!S. What do you bid? [BID 4!S]

Partner's jump shows a Medium hand, 16 - 18 points. Add your 11 and you have enough for game so you bid it.

Auction: 1D | 1S X pass 2S | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis: The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 2!S]\n\nYou have a very good hand but only 2 of partner's !H suit. You are actually too strong to just jump in !Ds so you cue-bid the opponent's suit. Partner now bids 3NT which you pass.

Auction: 1H 1S X | pass 2H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID double]

Ahhh, a perfect Negative Double. Both Majors have been bid and you have 4 cards in each Minor. So you double. Partner bids 2!H. What do you say next? [BID pass]

Well let's see. Partner shows no interest in your two Minors or notrump. And he has 6 !Hs and a minimum hand. He wants to play it at 2!H so you pass and let him.

Auction: 1H | 1S X pass 3H | pass 4H pass pass | pass
Analysis: The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 3!H]\n\nPartner is showing both Minors but you are not interested in either one. Bidding notrump is a possibility but with just a single !S stopper is not advisable. With 18 points and a 6-card suit you jump in the suit. You bid 3!H and partner raises to 4!H.

Auction: 1S 2H X | pass 3D pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID double]

When the two Majors have been bid, a Negative Double shows both Minors. So you double. Partner now bids 3!D. What do you say next? [BID pass]

This is difficult. You forced partner to bid and he supported your known !Ds. But he didn't jump so you figure him for 13-15 points. Revaluing your hand you get up to 13 points so it is just possible you have a 28 point total. That's not enough for game in !Ds so you pass.
As you can see you will lose 2 !Ss and 1 !C so you made the right decision.

Auction: 1D | 2C X pass 2H | pass 3H pass 4H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 2!H]

Partner's double promises 4 cards in at least one of the Majors. You certainly hope it is !Hs. You bid 2!H and partner raises to 3!H. What do you bid next? [BID 4!H]

Once partner confirms he has the !Hs you can revalue your hand to 17 points. This gives you enough extra to accept partner's invitation. You bid 4!H.

Auction: 1C 1D X | pass 1S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID double]

You have the special hand, 4-4 in the Majors, so you make a Negative Double. Partner replies 1!S. What do you say? [BID pass]

Partner has a minimum opener with 4 !Ss. You have a minimum response with 4 !Ss. Pass and be grateful the opponents aren't bidding.

Auction: 1H | 2D X pass 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis: The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 4!S]\n\nSometimes using Negative Doubles seems like you can read minds. You know for sure that partner has 4 !Ss since that is the only unbid Major. You know for sure that partner has T+ points because he made a Negative Double of a 2-level overcall. So you conclude that your side has 8 !Ss and 27+ points . . .. . . and you bid 4!S.

Auction: 1C 1D 1S | pass 1NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 1!S]

The general guideline for a Negative Double when both Majors are unbid is that you must have 4+ cards in at least ONE of the Majors. But for this specific sequence, 1!C - 1!D, you do not double unless you have BOTH Majors. When you have only one of them you just bid it. Like this hand. You bid 1!S. Partner rebids 1NT. What do you say? [BID pass]

Partner has a minimum hand and fewer than 4 !Ss. A good time for you to pass.

Auction: 1H | 2D X pass pass | pass
Analysis: The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID pass]\n\nPartner has T+ points, a !S suit and fewer than 3 !Hs. Doesn't this look like the perfect hand to pass for penalties? Yes.

Auction: 1C 1D X | pass 1NT pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID double]

This is one of the nicer parts of Negative Doubles. When the bidding is 1!C - 1!D, a double by you promises both Majors. It's like you are allowed to bid both suits at once, 1!S!H. So you double and partner says 1NT. It is your bid. [BID 3NT]

Partner doesn't have 4 of either Major. But he does have 13 points and !Ds stopped. You also have 13 points so you bid 3NT.

Auction: 1D | 1H 1S pass 2S | pass 4S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 2!S]

It is the sign of a novice to support responder's 1-level response with only 3 of the suit. Very often he will have responded in a 4-card suit and you end up playing in a 7-card fit.
But that is not the case here. If partner had only 4 !Ss he would not have bid the suit, he would have made a Negative Double. Since his !S bid promises 5 it is quite correct for you to support with only 3. So you raise to 2!S and partner bids the game.

Auction: 1D 2C pass | pass X pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID pass]

First let's agree on what you DON'T say. You don't say "double" because that would a Negative Double showing at least one 4-card Major. You don't support partner's !Ds with just two of them. You probably don't bid 1NT with no honor in either Major. So you pass. This is called a "Trap Pass". Partner re-opens with a double. What do you say? [BID pass]

Now you see why it's called a "Trap Pass". When an overcall is followed by two passes Opener should try to find another bid. In particular he should try to double for takeout if he can. That's what North did here, but you converted it to a Penalty Double by passing.

Auction: 1NT | pass 2NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You dealt so it is your bid. What do you say? [BID 1NT]

With 4-3-3-3 distribution and 15 points this hand qualifies for a 1NT opening. You bid 1NT andpartner raises to 2NT. What do you bid now? [BID pass]

Partner's 2NT bid invites you to bid 3NT if you are at the top of your 15-17 point range. Since you have only 15 points you decline the invitation.

Auction: 1NT | pass 2NT pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You dealt so it is your bid. What do you say? [BID 1NT]

This hand has 17 points and one of the balanced distributions. When you have a hand that meets the requirements you should open 1NT. Do not worry about the lack of a !D stopper, you don't have to have all the suits stopped to open 1NT. You bid 1NT and partner raises to 2NT. What do you bid next? [BID 3NT]

You should count on partner for 9 points for his invitation. Your 17 brings the total to 26 so you bid 3NT.

Auction: 1NT | pass 2NT pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You dealt so it is your bid. What do you say? [BID 1NT]

Of course you open 1NT. Partner responds 2NT. What do you say? [BID 3NT]

With 15 points you decline invitations, and with 17 points you accept. But with 16 you have to use your judgement. Some players will just automatically bid 3NT when they have 16 points, preferring to err on the side of boldness than to possibly miss bidding a makeable game. Others prefer to base their decision on how good the hand looks.
With all the Ts and 9s this hand is stronger than 16 points, so you bid 3NT.

Auction: 1NT | pass 4NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You dealt so it is your bid. What do you say? [BID 1NT]

You open 1NT. Again. This time partner jumps to 4NT. What do you bid? [BID pass]

Partner's bid is not Blackwood. It is called a Quantitative 4NT and he is telling you he has a balanced 16-17 point hand. He is inviting you to bid 6NT.
With 17 you accept invitations, with 15 you decline. You have 15 so you pass.
As you see, there are 9 easy tricks and you can probably set up another. But you have no chance to make slam.

Auction: 1NT | pass 4NT pass 6NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You dealt so it is your bid. What do you say? [BID 1NT]

You open 1NT and partner jumps to 4NT. What do you bid now? [BID 6NT]

This is the sequel to Deal 4. This time you have 17 points so you accept partner's invitation to slam and bid 6NT.
You have 11 top tricks and can easily set up one more in !Cs.

Auction: 1NT | pass 4NT pass 6NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You dealt so it is your bid. What do you say? [BID 1NT]

You open 1NT and partner jumps to 4NT. What do you bid now? [BID 6NT]

This is the threequel to 4 and 5. With a "good 16" points you accept the invitation and bid 6NT.
As you might expect, this time the slam is not so certain, but there is a good chance. If either Minor suit finesse works you can make 12 tricks.

Auction: pass 1NT | pass 2H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 1NT]

Surprise - you open 1NT. Partner responds 2!H. What do you bid next? (no transfers in this lesson) [BID pass]

Pass. Partner has long !Hs (probably 6) and short points (fewer than 9). He has decided that 2!H will be a better spot than 1NT. Trust him.

Auction: pass pass pass 1NT | pass 3H pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 1NT]
[PLAY S:D4]

You open 1NT and partner replies 3!H. What do you say next? [BID 3NT]

With this bidding method, partner's bid shows at least 10 points and exactly 5 !Hs. He expects you to choose between 3NT and 4!H. Since you have just a doubleton in !Hs you choose 3NT.
NOTE: Jacoby Transfers are very useful for this type of hand.

Auction: pass pass pass 1NT | pass 3S pass 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 1NT]

Yes this is exactly the same hand you held in Deal 8. You still open 1NT. This time partner responds 3!S. What do you bid? [BID 4!S]

Partner shows T+ points and exactly 5 !Ss. This time, with 3-card support, you choose game in !Ss, knowing there is an 8-card fit.

Auction: pass 1NT | pass 3D pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 1NT]

You open 1NT and partner says 3!D. It's your bid. [BID 3NT]

Partner has a great hand. A jump to 3 in a Minor suit almost always shows slam interest. But that's partner with interest, not you. You couldn't have a more minimum 1NT opening bid. 
So you just return to 3NT. Partner gives up and passes.

Auction: pass 1NT | pass 3C pass 4C | pass 4NT pass 5D | pass 6C all pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 1NT]

You open 1NT and partner responds 3!C. What is your next bid? [BID 4!C]

Partner's jump to 3!C shows at least 5 !Cs and slam interest. Your hand is good enough to encourage that interest so you bypass 3NT and say 4!C. Partner now bids 4NT. What do you answer? [BID 5!D]

That is Blackwood. You admit to one Ace and partner bids 6!C.

Auction: 1D 1NT | pass 2H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 1NT]

A 1NT overcall is almost the same as a 1NT opening. The range is increased to 15-18, but the main difference is that you must have the opponent's suit adequately stopped. Here you certainly have the stopper so you bid 1NT. Partner responds 2!H. What do you bid next? [BID pass]

And the responses are the same also. Partner's 2!H bid is a signoff bid, often called a "drop dead" bid. So even though you really like the !Hs you pass.

Auction: 2NT | pass 3S pass 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You dealt so it is your bid. What do you say? [BID 2NT]

With a balanced 20 point hand you open 2NT. Partner responds 3!S. What do you bid next? [BID 4!S]

Partner is showing a 5-card !S suit and at least 5 points. This is a forcing bid; you are to choose between 3NT and 4!S, depending on your !S holding. With three of them you bid 4!S.

Auction: pass 1NT pass pass | pass
Analysis: The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID pass]\n\nYou have 8 points. Even if partner has the maximum 17 it would only add to 25, which is probably not enough to make game. You should pass.

Auction: 1NT pass 2NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis: The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 2NT]\n\nWith 9 points you have just enough strength for an invitation. So you bid 2NT. Partner then says 3NT and everybody passes.

Auction: 1NT pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis: The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 3NT]\n\nA balanced hand with 12 points. Even if partner has just 15 points you want to be in game. So you bid 3NT.

Auction: 1NT pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis: The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 3NT]\n\nYou have just 9 points, only 7 of which are HCP. Still, that !D suit is very likely to provide 5 or 6 tricks. Take a risk and bid 3NT.

Auction: 1NT pass 4NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 4NT]

With partner's 15, 16 or 17 points added to your 16 the total assets are 31, 32 or 33. That's only one chance in 3 of having the points you need for slam. On the other hand you have a pretty good 16. So you bid 4NT, inviting partner to bid the slam. He will pass if he has only 15, so the worst thing that can happen is that he puts you in slam with only 32 points.
So you bid 4NT and guess what? He passes.

Auction: 2NT pass 6NT | pass pass pass
Analysis: The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 6NT]\n\nDo the math. If partner only has 20 points you still come to 34 points, enough for the slam. If you want to use Gerber to check for Aces, go ahead. Or, just bid 6NT.

Auction: 1NT pass 2S | pass pass pass
Analysis: The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 2!S]\n\nYou have a terrible hand and partner is not going to make 1NT. So you bid 2!S, the Drop-dead bid. You don't expect to make this either, but it will probably end up better than 1NT would have.

Auction: 1NT pass 4H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 4!H]

Since partner opened 1NT he has at least 2 !Hs and you are assured of an 8-card fit. The only question is how high. With 10 points you are in the judgement zone.
But unless you play Jacoby Transfers there isn't a method for inviting with this kind of hand. You have to decide for yourself and bid either 2!H or 4!H. Take the optimistic view and bid the game.
As you see, it is going to take some luck.

Auction: 1NT pass 3S | pass 4S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 3!S]

With 13 points you must either bid game or make a bid that forces partner to game. If partner has 3 or more !Ss then the game should be 4!S. If partner has only a doubleton !S then the game should be 3NT. Only partner can decide, and the bid that tells him to make the decision is 3!S.
Partner has 3 of them so he bids 4!S.

Auction: 1NT pass 3C | pass 4C pass 4D | pass 6C pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 3!C]

With 16 points you may be in slam range. You should alert partner of your big hand by jumping to 3!C. Partner says 4!C and it is your bid again. [BID 4!D]

Don't make the mistake of bidding Blackwood when you have a doubleton-nothing in a suit. If partner has only one Ace you will be left not knowing what to do. Instead make a control-bid showing your !DA. Now partner bids 6!C which ends the auction.

Auction: 2NT pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 3NT]

You have 5 points, all in !Ds. That will take the partnership total to either 25 or 26, so you have a judgement call. If partner is unable to establish your !Ds then even 2NT will probably be too high, so you might as well assume that he will be able to use them and bid 3NT.
You hit the jackpot.

Auction: 2NT pass 4C | pass 4S pass 6S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 4!C]
[PLAY S:SJ]

You and partner better have a good agreement on which Ace-asking convention you use because you're going to use it now. Let's say it is Gerber. 
You bid 4!C and partner replies 4!S. What do you bid next? [BID 6!S]

Missing one Ace you settle for the small slam.

Auction: pass pass 1NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. The contract is 3NT and it is your lead.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
Leading an honor sequence is always good strategy against a notrump contract. It is attacking, threatening to set up several winners for you, and there is little risk that you will give away a trick.
South will probably hold up, at least once. If he does, you should continue the suit by next playing the !HJ. This is standard technique; if your first card holds the trick and you want to continue the suit, play the lowest card in the sequence and partner will know that you have all the ones in between.
South only has 7 winners unless he can establish the !C suit, and when you win your !CK you will also be able to win enough !Hs to set the contract.

Auction: 1C pass 1S | pass 4S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. The contract is 4!S and it is your lead.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
Against confident bidding an attacking lead is probably called for and having the Ace of trumps makes a singleton lead a particularly good choice.
If declarer plays low in dummy partner will win the !HK and give you an immediate ruff. You play a !C back to partner and get another ruff for down 2.
Declarer would be better off to go up with the !HA at the first trick and try to pull trumps. This would still not be good enough. You win your !SA, and lead a !C to partner's hand. He can then win his !HK and lead a third !H for you to ruff. Down 1.

Auction: 1NT | 3NT pass pass |
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. The contract is 3NT and it is your lead.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
The only suit you have worth attacking with is your !Ss. Leading fourth down is standard with this type of holding, but it does have some risk. You are hoping to find partner with the !SQ or, even better, the !SA.
This time he comes through with the !SA and your side wins the first 5 tricks for a 1-trick set.
If you had led any card other than a low !S declarer would take T tricks.

Auction: 1H | pass 2C pass 2H | pass 4H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. The contract is 4!H and it is your lead.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
Against a suit contract you want to try to set up a quick winner in the suit.
Notice that with any other lead declarer would have been able to discard a !S loser  (maybe both of them) on dummy's !Cs.

Auction: 1NT | pass 3NT pass pass |
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. The contract is 3NT and it is your lead.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
The top of a solid 3-card honor sequence is best, but as you can see, a broken 3-card sequence may work out just as good.
South will likely try the !C finesse, and when East wins the !CK he will return a !S through South's !ST.

Auction: 1D | pass 1H pass 1S | pass 4S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. The contract is 4!S and it is your lead.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
You have !D winners, but dummy will surely be short since he has at least 8 cards in the Major suits.
Partner has whatever !H strength your side possesses.
It is very likely that declarer will want to do some cross-trumping. To try to cut that down your best lead is a trump.
Just imagine that declarer wins the first !S in his hand and plays a !H to dummy's honors. East will win and play another trump. Whenever you win your first !D you will play your last trump.
As you can imagine, declarer will be in a whole lot of trouble.

Auction: 2NT | pass 6NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. The contract is 6NT and it is your lead.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
You held this identical hand in Deal 3. The declarer was playing 3NT and the best lead was the !S4, fourth down.
It's different when the conract is 6NT. Against 6NT you should make a passive lead, which means don't underlead any honors. Against 6NT you have little chance of establishing a suit to win four or five tricks. Instead, you just want to try to not give declarer an undeserved trick.
So any passive lead would be OK, you pick the !H just because they are less likely to have an unbid 4-card Major in either hand.
Declarer has 11 winners sitting there; if you had led a low !S you would have handed him his 12 trick on a platter.

Auction: 1D | pass 2C pass 3D | pass 4NT pass 5D | pass 6D pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. The contract is 6!D and it is your lead.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
Against a notrump slam it is best to make a passive lead so you don't give declarer an undeserved winner.
Against a suit slam the situation is very different. Against strong dummy bidding like this you are pretty sure that if you don't establish a winner early declarer will find something in dummy to discard losers on. In this hand it is dummy's !C suit.
Your most promising suit is !Ss. Obviously partner has a very weak hand, but if he has the !SQ you can set up your !SK before your King of trumps is dislodged.
Without a !S lead declarer will have smooth sailing.

Auction: 1NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. The contract is 3NT and it is your lead.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
This is a close call. The top of your !S honor sequence is very tempting, but even when you find partner with the !SK you can still only establish three !S winners to go with your !CA. Unfortunately, that's not enough to defeat the contract.
Leading a !H from your 5-card suit is riskier, but it has the potential of setting up an additional winner. In this hand, as you see, the !H lead gets you 4 !H winners to go with your !CA.

Auction: 1H | pass 1S pass 2C | pass 4H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. The contract is 4!H and it is your lead.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
A careful look at this hand shows just how bad it can turn out.
And leading from a doubleton in a suit the opponents have bid is almost as bad.
So by process of elimination you lead a trump, probably the !H9.
And when South plays !Cs, (preparing to ruff in dummy), you will win and play another trump. Even if South guesses the !Ss correctly he will not be able to make the contract.

Auction: 1C 1S 2NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. The contract is 3NT and it is your lead.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
If partner had not overcalled, the !HQ would be the perfect lead against 3NT. But partner DID overcall, perhaps to give you a hint on what to lead if South became declarer.
As you see, a !S lead will defeat the contract this time while the !HQ would let declarer make 11 tricks.
Consider this: even if partner has a high !H to help you establish the suit it is not very likely that you would be able to get the lead with your entryless hand.
There is another, more subtle, reason for leading partner's suit. If the lead turns out wrong, and the !HQ lead would have beaten the conract, partner will not blame you in the least. But if you lead the !HQ and it turns out that a !S lead would have let you set the contract, well, that would not be too good for partnership harmony.

Auction: 1C | X pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. The contract is 1!C doubled and it is your lead.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
There is only one reason partner would pass your takeout double - he has a great !C suit and he expects to inflict a large penalty.
What he wants do do is pull South's trumps so your high card winners don't get ruffed by South. The way you can help him do that is to start with a trump lead.
With the trump lead South might not make more than three tricks.

Auction: 1D pass 2NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. The contract is 3NT and it is your lead.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
Your !Cs are so good that all your instincts tell you to lead the !C8, and perhaps set up 3 winners.
If you had one more small !Cs your instincts would be right, but with only a 4-card suit you should think a little longer. Three tricks won't set this contract, so you must depend on partner winning something. And if partner is going to win something perhaps he will lead a !C and you might make FOUR tricks in the suit.
So lead the !H9. You lead a high card so partner won't be tempted to return the suit when he gets the lead. Note that although this lead finesses partner's !HQ, it didn't do anything that declarer wouldn't have done on his own.
Declarer must play !Ds to get some winners, and when East takes the !DA he will surely switch to the !CJ. Down goes declarer.

Auction: 1H 2S | 3D 3S 4C pass | 4H pass pass 4S | X pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. The contract is 4!S doubled and it is your lead.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
South's 2!S bid is a Weak-jump Overcall, based on a 6-card !S suit and a weak hand.
Either the !DQ or !HJ would normally be good leads.
But on this deal North/South have clearly sacrificed against your almost certain !H game. Since they don't have enough high-card strength to make this contract declarer is hoping to get some ruffs.
The way to cut down the number of ruffs he can make is to lead a trump at every opportunity.
So take the !SA and then play another !S. Declarer will still be able to ruff one !H in dummy, but will be left with two losing !Hs and will be down 2. Without the two trump plays he could have ruffed all three of his !H losers and actually made the conract.

Auction: 1NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. The contract is 3NT and it is your lead.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
Sometimes it comes down to just this kind of choice. Do you lead fourth down from !S K 8 7 3 or from !H Q T 7 3.
The presence of the !HT bolsters the !H suit enough to give it the edge.
The suits could be arranged something like shown at left. With a !S lead the presence of the !ST in dummy allows declarer to make a second !S trick, which happens to be declarer's ninth trick.
But when you lead the !H3 it does not promote a !H winner for declarer, and left to his own devices, he cannot establish the !S winner.

Auction: 1D pass 1S | pass 3D pass 3S | pass 4S pass 4NT | pass 5D pass 6S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. The contract is 6!S and it is your lead.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
The !CT would probably be a very safe lead. But you don't want "safe", you want "attack".
Dummy has advertised a long, strong !D suit which declarer will no doubt establish for discards.
It is important for your side to create a winner before your !DA is forced out. The most likely looking winner is your !HK. So lead the small !H and hope partner has the Queen.

Auction: 1S pass 2NT | pass 3NT X pass | pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. The contract is 3NT and it is your lead.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
If partner had not doubled the contract you would probably have started with the !HT, or possibly the !C2.
But partner DID double, and most good players play that doubling 3NT is lead-directing as follows:If you have bid a suit, lead it. If doubler has bid a suit, lead it. If neither of you has bid, lead dummy's first bid suit.
 So lead a !S, certainly not a lead you would have made without the double. Partner immediately establishes 4 !S winners and he has the !DA for an entry.
With any other lead declarer will make the contract.

Auction: 1NT | pass 2C X 2H | pass 4H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. The contract is 4!H and it is your lead.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
If partner had not doubled North's Stayman 2!C bid you would probably have started with one of your Jacks.
But partner DID double, and the double of a conventional bid clearly means that the doubler would like you to lead that suit.
 So lead a !C, and partner will take three !C tricks. With any other lead declarer would quickly discard a !C from dummy on a high !D, easily making the contract.
Declarer may still make the contract if he guesses the !HQ correctly, but maybe not.

Auction: 1H pass 2NT | pass 6NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. The contract is 6NT and it is your lead.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
Admittedly the !HQ looks very tempting, but resist the temptation.
Since dummy bid !Hs, don't help declarer by leading the suit. Declarer has 11 tricks, and will hope to pick up one more in !Cs, but that won't happen.
But if you start with the !HQ, he will win with his !HK and can then establish an extra !H winner by leading through your !H J T into dummy's !H A 9.
With any lead other than a !H honor he cannot come to 12 tricks.

Auction: 1S | pass 2C pass 3C | pass 4S pass pass | X pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. The contract is 4!S and it is your lead.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
Did you choose the !HQ? I was afraid you would. That is wrong, but because this is the last Deal I'm going to give you another chance.
Look at the bidding carefully, then ask yourself why you doubled.
Now pick the opening lead that will set the contract, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
North/South apparently have 8 or more !Cs between them, which leaves partner with a singleton at most.
Partner will ruff the second !C, and when you get into the lead with the Ace of trumps you will play a third !C which he will again ruff.
That's why you doubled.

Auction: 2H | pass 2NT pass 3C | pass 3H pass pass | pass
Analysis: The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 3!C]\nAt favorable vulnerability you decided to open 2!H.\nIn reply to partner's Ogust 2NT you say 3!C, showing a minimum hand along with a poor suit. Partner says 3!H and you gratefully pass.

Auction: pass 2H pass 2NT | pass 3C pass 3H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 2NT]
With four top tricks it is tempting to go straight to 4!H.
But you use discretion and bid an Ogust 2NT instead. Partner responds 3!C. What do you bid next? [BID 3!H]

Partner's 3!C bid shows a weak hand and a poor suit. So you reluctantly settle for 3!H.

Auction: 2S | pass 2NT pass 3D | pass 3S pass pass | pass
Analysis: The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 3!D]\nAt favorable vulnerability you decided to open 2!S.\nIn reply to partner's Ogust 2NT you say 3!D, showing a minimum hand along with a good suit. Partner says 3!S and you pass.

Auction: pass 2S pass 2NT | pass 3H pass 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 2NT]
With three top tricks it is tempting to go straight to 4!S.
But you use discretion and bid an Ogust 2NT instead. Partner responds 3!H. What do you bid next? [BID 4!S]

Partner's 3!H bid shows a maximum hand and a poor suit. Your !SK should be enough help for the suit, and with three outside Aces you bid 4!S.

Auction: 2S | pass 2NT pass 3H | pass 4S pass pass | pass
Analysis: The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 3!H]\nHaving opened 2!S, you reply to partner's Ogust 2NT bid with 3!H, showing a maximum hand but with a poor suit. Partner says 4!S and you pass.

Auction: pass 2D pass 2NT | pass 3D pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 2NT]
You could just guess between pass, 3NT, or 5!D.
But you use Ogust instead. Partner responds 3!D. What do you bid next? [BID 3NT]

Partner's 3!D bid shows a minimum hand but a good suit, which should mean two of the top three honors. Your !DK tells you that partner has a 6-card !D  suit headed by the A Q. With three outside Aces you can count 9 tricks - you bid 3NT.

Auction: 2D | pass 2NT pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis: The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 3NT]\nHaving opened 2!D, you reply to partner's Ogust 2NT bid with 3NT, showing a !D suit headed by A K Q. Partner passes.

Auction: pass 2H pass 2NT | pass 3NT pass 4H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 2NT]
This is a perfect hand for Ogust - when you're not sure what to do! So you bid 2NT. Partner responds 3NT. What do you bid next? [BID 4!H]

Partner's 3NT bid describes his hand exactly; !H A K Q x x x and nothing else. You MIGHT have a !S stopper, but they might be arranged so the defenders could take the first 5 !S tricks. So you bid the "safe" 4!H game which depends only on a 3-2 trump split.

Auction: 2H | pass 2NT pass 3S | pass 4H pass pass | pass
Analysis: The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 3!S]\nAfter opening 2!H you reply to partner's Ogust 2NT with 3!S, showing a maximum hand along with a good suit. Partner bids 4!H and you pass.

Auction: pass 2S pass 2NT | pass 3S pass 6S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 2NT]
Before you read this lesson you might have just jumped to a Blackwood 4NT. But now you bid an Ogust 2NT. Partner rebids 3!S. What do you bid next? [BID 6!S]

Wow! Partner has a maximum Weak 2-bid and a good trump suit, no doubt headed by the A Q.  If he also has the !HA you might be cold for 7!S. Bid Blackwood if you must, but you don't really need to since partner could not possibly have The !HA AND !S A Q x x x x. Too many points for a Weak 2-bid. So you bid 6!S.

Auction: 1D pass | pass pass
Analysis: The bidding has been as shown. It is your turn. Decide what you would say, then click on "" above. [BID pass]\n\nYou have 14 points but so what. You have no 5-card suit to Overcall. You cannot make a Takeout Double with 4 of their suit. So you pass. It is important to realize that there are hands you would open but cannot overcall with.

Auction: 1C 1H pass 3H | pass pass pass
Analysis: The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 3!H]\n\nWith four trumps and 12 points you have a text-book raise to 3!H. Partner had a minimum overcall though, so he passed.

Auction: 1C 1H | pass 2H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. [BID 1!H]

With 12 points and a good suit you have a very solid overcall so you bid 1!H. Partner responds 2!H. What do you say? [BID pass]

Partner is showing 6-10 points and three trumps. Your hand revalues to 14 at most so you pass.

Auction: 1D 1S pass pass | pass
Analysis: The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID pass]\n\nYou really don't like partner's !Ss, and you do have 8 points. But 8 points is not enough to be considering game, and you would have to bid your !Hs at the 2-level. All things considered it is better to pass while you still aren't doubled.

Auction: 1S 2H | pass 3H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. [BID 2!H]

You overcall 2!H and hear partner raise you to 3!H. What do you say now? [BID pass]

No matter how many times you check this hand you cannot revalue it any more than 13 points. Since partner has T at the most you reluctantly pass.

Auction: 1D 1S 2D 2S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 2!S]

With only 7 points you might not think you have enough to make a "free bid". But in competitive bidding situations like these, where both sides have a fit, bidding is usually better than passing. So you bid 2!S.
You might look at the Law of Total Tricks lesson for more on this subject.

Auction: 1D 1S | pass 3S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. [BID 1!S]

You have enough for a 1-level Overcall so you bid 1!S. Partner says 3!S. What do you say now? [BID pass]

The jump raise tells you partner has 11-14 points.
With your minimum it's going to have to be better than that to get you excited. So you pass.

Auction: 1H 1S 3H 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 4!S]

You have 10 points, but in cases like this points don't matter that much. They MIGHT be able to make 4!H. Partner MIGHT be able to make 4!S. This preemptive jump takes the decision away from them.
Looking at the hands you can see that partner is going to go down 1 at 4!S. However, that is an excellent result since they appear to be cold for 5!H.

Auction: 1C 1H | pass 3H pass 4H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. [BID 1!H]

Nice hand. But not nice enough to double, then bid your !Hs. So you overcall 1!H. Partner says 3!H. It is your bid. [BID 4!H]

The jump raise promises 11-14 points. Your 17 plus partner's 11 or so takes you right up to game. You bid 4!H.

Auction: 1S 2C pass 2NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis: The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 2NT]\n\nPartner has at least 11 points for his 2-level overcall. He might have as many as 16. You have a perfect invitational hand including two sure stoppers in their suit. So you bid 2NT. Partner raises to 3NT and you get to play it there.

Auction: 1C 1NT | pass 2C pass 2D | pass 2NT pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. [BID 1NT]

This hand would be one point too strong to Open 1NT, but it fits the 15-18 range to Overcall 1NT. Partner responds 2!C. What do you bid? [BID 2!D]

Don't get your systems crossed. Partner did not make a cue-bid, he is using Stayman. Since you have no 4-card Major suit you answer 2!D. Partner now says 2NT and the ball is in your court. [BID 3NT]

This is just a plain old 1NT/Stayman sequence. Partner is inviting, and since you have 18 points you accept.

Auction: 1D 1S pass 2D | pass 2S pass 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 2!D]

Wow! Great !S support and 15 points. You cue-bid 2!D, forcing partner to bid. He says 2!S. Your turn. [BID 4!S]

Partner has not made a strong bid and it is possible that T tricks will be too high. But it is pretty likely that game can be made so you bid it. Be bold!

Auction: 1H 2S | pass pass pass
Analysis: The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. [BID 2!S]\n\nIf you had been the dealer you would have opened 2!S. The situation is no different after they open so you Overcall 2!S. Everybody passes.

Auction: 1D 1H pass 1S | pass 2S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 1!S]

You don't like to take partner out of his overcalled suit without good reason. Here you have good reason. So you bid 1!S. Partner replies 2!S. What do you say next? [BID pass]

You expect partner to have three trumps, but he has made a minimum bid. So you take the conservative route and pass.

Auction: 1C 1H | pass 1S pass 2S | pass 4S all pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. [BID 1!H]

You have a nice easy decision here. You overcall 1!H. Then partner bids 1!S. What do you say next? [BID 2!S]

Whether you play a change of suit as forcing or not, your hand certainly qualifies as one where you should make a bid. Partner doesn't really like your !Hs but you are quite satisfied to play in !Ss. So you bid 2!S. Partner jumps to 4!S and that closes out the auction.

Auction: 1D 1NT pass 2C | pass 2H pass 3H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 2!C]

You treat partner's 1NT Overcall the same as a 1NT Opening. You use Stayman and bid 2!C. Partner replies 2!H. What is your next bid? [BID 3!H]

You have 9 points, an invitational strength hand. You bid 3!H, inviting partner to go to game with a maximum. He declines your invitation.

Auction: 1S 2C | pass 2S pass 2NT | pass 3NT all pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. [BID 2!C]

You have a sound 2-level overcall. You bid 2!C and partner replies 2!S. What is your next bid? [BID 2NT]
