Partner's cue-bid obviously forces you to bid. Partner's hand might be very distributional, but rather than just sticking to !Cs you suggest with 2NT. This guarantees you have !Ss stopped. Partner likes your suggestion and bids 3NT.

Auction: 1C 1S pass 2NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis: The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 2NT]\n\nBalanced hand, poor support for partner's suit, stoppers in their suit and 13 points. You couldn't get a better hand to jump to 2NT. Partner takes you to 3NT.

Auction: 1C 2D | pass 2NT pass 3H | pass 3NT all pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. [BID 2!D]

With a good 6-card suit and 10 points you make a Weak Jump Overcall to 2!D. Partner says 2NT. What do you bid now? [BID 3!H]

The 2NT bid is a standard response to a Weak 2-bid. It asks for the identification of any outside high-card if the Weak 2-bidder has more than a minimum. Here you are in the top range for your bid so you show your !HK.
That was apparently the missing link for partner, he now says 3NT.

Auction: 1C 2S pass 2NT | pass 3D pass 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 2NT]

You might just try 4!S. Of course if partner has a minimum Weak Jump Overcall that will get you much too high. A better approach is to ask for more information from partner. The bid that asks is 2NT. Partner replies 3!D. What do you bid now? [BID 4!S]

Partner's 3!D bid tells you two things. One, he is in the top half of his 6-11 point range. Two, he has a high card (Ace or King) in !Ds. When you construct a hand for him which contains 6 pretty good !Ss and the !DA you come up with a hand which will probably make game. Bid 4!S.

Auction: 3D | pass pass pass
Analysis: You dealt this hand. Decide what you would bid, then click on BID above. [BID 3!D]\n\nYou estimate you can win 6 !D tricks so you open 3!D. Everybody passes.

Auction: 3S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. Decide what you would bid, then click on BID above. [BID pass]

You have 13 points and if partner had opened with a 1!S bid you'd be feeling "jumpy". But what a preemptive bidder needs from dummy are immediate winners, not points. So you pass.
Here's a pretty good tip:When partner opens with a 3-bid and you are trying to decide whether to take him to game, visualize him holding this very hand:K Q J T x x x of trumps and nothing in any other suit. Then base your decision on that.

Auction: 3H | pass 4H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You dealt this hand. Decide what you would bid, then click on BID above. [BID 3!H]

You expect your hand to produce 5 !H tricks and the !SA. So you open 3!H. Partner responds 4!H. What do you bid? [BID pass]

When you preempted 3!H you described your hand perfectly. You have nothing more to say except pass.

Auction: 3H pass 4H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. Decide what you would bid, then click on BID above. [BID 4!H]

No matter how much we try to reduce bridge to rules and guidelines we will never get rid of the judgement factor. With this hand you definitely have 3 fast tricks for partner. In theory he can take 6 of his own, so 3!H should be the right contract. BUT, maybe he could ruff a !D in your dummy?
Fortune favors the bold so you bid 4!H . . . and live happily ever after.

Auction: 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You dealt this hand. Decide what you would bid, then click on BID above. [BID 4!S]

With 7 estimated winners and an 8-card suit you preempt 4!S. And you are not going to make it. In fact you are only going to make 8 tricks so you will go down 2.
You may be wishing that you had opened just 3!S, rather than following the guidelines and opening at the 4-level. The problem with that thinking is that the lower your preempt, the less difficult it is for the opponent's to enter the bidding. If you had opened 3!S West might have been able to make a Takeout Double and they could have found their !H fit. Just visualize their combined hands; they have 9 !Hs between them, they have no !S losers, no !C losers and just one !D loser. If they decide to finesse your partner for the !HQ they can make slam.
This is what preempting is all about.

Auction: 3S pass 6S | pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. Decide what you would bid, then click on BID above. [BID 6!S]

If is hard to imagine any hand partner could have where the slam wouldn't be there. Maybe you should use Blackwood, just to be sure? If partner shows 1 Ace you would then bid 6!S. And if he shows no Aces you would then . . . bid 6!S anyway. So you leave out the middle step and bid 6!S.
Did you think about bidding 6NT instead? Ugh, they would have led a !C.

Auction: 3H | X pass 3S pass | pass pass
Analysis:
You dealt this hand. Decide what you would bid, then click on BID above. [BID 3!H]

You make a simple 3!H opening bid and then the fireworks start. West doubles, your partner passes and East bids 3!S. What do you bid now? [BID pass]

Do not preempt the same hand twice. The idea of a preemptive bid is that you bid it's maximum at your first turn. If there is to any further competing on this hand partner will have to do it.

Auction: 3D 3S 4D | pass pass pass
Analysis: The bidding has been as shown. Decide what you would bid, then click on BID above. [BID 4!D]\n\nYou do not have the 4 fast winners you need to raise partner to the 4-level. But you do have 4 of his trumps and 2 and a half winners. And your side doesn't have much defense against a 3!S contract. You should raise partner to 4!D because you think they can make 3!S. With these hands it appears they might have gone to 4!S in which case you would have had to decide whether to continue to 5!D. More judgement would be called for,based on Vulnerability, whether you think they can make the game, etc. The Law of Total Tricks can be a help in these competitive situations; it would lead you to 5!D.

Auction: 3D | X 4D 4H pass | pass pass
Analysis:
You dealt this hand. Decide what you would bid, then click on BID above. [BID 3!D]

You open 3!D. West doubles, partner raises to 4!D, and East bids 4!H. What do you say? [BID pass]

You just pass. Partner's raise was probably just advancing your preempt and they got to 4!H anyway. Sometimes preempts don't do the full job.
It is partner's decision, not yours, whether to continue to 5!D as a sacrifice.

Auction: 3H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. Decide what you would bid, then click on BID above. [BID pass]

The guidelines in the summary would have you bid 4!H. After all you very clearly have four quick winners.
But you also have seven quick losers in the other suits, and a trump void to boot.
Somewhere in some of these lessons there should be a guideline that says:

Auction: 1H 3S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. Decide what you would bid, then click on BID above. [BID 3!S]

The fact that East opened doesn't change your hand at all. You had planned on Opening 3!S, now you make a Weak Jump Overcall of 3!S. If partner has some "stuff" you might get to a makeable contract, and if he doesn't you may keep the opponents out of a !H game.
This time everybody passes.

Auction: 1C 3H pass 4H | pass pass pass
Analysis: The bidding has been as shown. Decide what you would bid, then click on BID above. [BID 4!H]\n\nYou have four quick winners. If partner had opened 3!H you would have bid 4!H in the blink of an eye. His Weak Jump Overcall describes the exact same hand. So blink and bid 4!H.

Auction: 1C | pass 1H pass 1S | pass 4S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 1!S]
If you thought you couldn't bid 1!S because it would have been a Reverse just think again.
A Reverse is when you bid a higher-ranking second suit at the 2-level. This is just normal bidding of suits up the line.
Partner now takes control and bids the !S game.

Auction: 1C | pass 1S pass 1NT | pass 3NT all pass
Analysis: The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 1NT]\nDon't bid 2!H. That would be a Reverse, showing at least 17 points. A 2!H bid would also show longer !Cs than !Hs. Don't bid 2!S. That would be showing 4-card support.\nSo with your minimum hand you bid 1NT which partner raises to 3NT.

Auction: 1C pass 1H | pass 2D pass 2NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. At your first turn you bid your !H suit, up-the-line. Decide what you would say next, then click on BID above. [BID 2NT]
You only have 7 points, but partner Reversed so you cannot pass. You need to make a bid to show your minimum, and you cannot support either of partner's suits, nor can you rebid your !Hs.
However, you also cannot bid your !S suit. That would be fourth-suit-forcing, and would show a game forcing hand of 9 or more points.
Instead you bid 2NT. Partner has a bare 17 so he passes.

Auction: 1C | pass 1S pass 2D | pass 3S pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis: The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 2!D]\nWith 18 points you have enough to make a Reverse. So you bid 2!D. Partner now says 3!S. What do you bid? [BID 3NT]\nPartner's jump bid shows a 6-card suit and enough points to insist on game. You don't have !S support but you do have good !H stoppers so you bid 3NT.

Auction: 1C pass 1S | pass 2H pass 4H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 4!H]
With his Reverse, partner has shown at least 17 points and at least 4 !Hs.
You could fall back on the guidelines and say that with 10 points you need to make a positive bid at this time, but it is simpler to just rely on "SHE WHO KNOWS, GOES."
Since you know of an 8-card !H fit and at least 27 points you bid 4!H.

Auction: 1S | pass 2S pass 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You are the dealer. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 1!S]
It may be tempting to open 1!H, planning on Reversing in !S at your second turn to show your big hand.
Don't. A Reverse should always show an unbalanced hand with the first suit longer. So you open 1!S and partner replies 2!S.
What do you bid? [BID pass]
If you had opened 1!H partner would have replied 1NT. Then when you Reversed with 2!S he would have assumed you had a 4-card !S suit and would probably have put you back in !Hs, your known 5-card suit.
Things would have gotten confusing, to say the least.

Auction: 1C pass 1H | pass 2D pass 3C | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 3!C]
[PLAY S:D7,S:D3,S:C9,S:C8,S:C5]
You would really love to pass. You have a terrible hand and you like the !Ds better than the !Cs.
But you are forced to bid. And since partner has 5 !Cs and only 4 !Ds, you should take him back to his first suit.
Mercifully he passes.

Auction: 1D pass 1S | pass 2H pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis: The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 3NT]\nWhen partner shows 17+ points with his Reverse you are sure you belong in game. Since he did not support your !Ss you know he doesn't have four of them. You also know you have an 8-card fit in !Ds, but surely nine tricks in Notrump will be easier than eleven in !Ds.

Auction: 1C | pass 1H pass 2D | pass 3C pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 2!D]
With 17 points you have a perfect hand for a Reverse. So you bid 2!D. Partner then says 3!C. What do you say? [BID pass]
Partner's return to your !C suit shows he has fewer than 9 points. Although it is possible to devise a hand for him where your side could make 3NT, the risk is too great.
So you pass. It's a good thing, too.

Auction: 1C pass 1H | pass 2D pass 2H | pass pass pass
Analysis: The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 2!H]\nYou have 7 points, and basically nothing but s!H. You must make a minimum bid, and the only reasonable one is 2!H. Despite his 17 points, partner passes.

Auction: 1D | pass 1S pass 2H | pass 3D pass 5D | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 2!H]
You have an ideal hand for a Reverse, so you bid 2!H.
Partner now bids 3!D. What do you say? [BID 5!D]
Partner has a minimum hand, but at least he came up with a preference for !Ds.
There are no guarantees here, but you should probably try 5!D.

Auction: 1C | pass 1S pass 2D | pass 3S pass 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 2!D]
With 18 points you have enough to make a Reverse. So you bid 2!D. Partner now says 3!S. What do you bid? [BID 4!S]
[PLAY S:S5]
Partner's jump bid shows a 6-card suit and enough points to insist on game. With your !H stopper you might be considering 3NT, but since you know of an 8-card !S fit you decide on 4!S.
Be very glad that you did.3NT would go down with a !H opening lead while 4!S is cold.

Auction: 1C pass 1S | pass 2D pass 4D | pass 5D pass pass | pass
Analysis: The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 4!D]\nWith partner showing 17 or more points, your 13 brings you to game level. You want to support partner's !Ds but you must jump to show that you have more than 8 points. So you bid 4!D and partner raises it to game.

Auction: 1D | pass 1S pass 1NT | pass pass pass
Analysis: The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 1NT]\nYou only have 15 points, not enough to Reverse, so you cannot bid the !H suit.\nInstead you content yourself with 1NT. Partner passes.

Auction: 1S pass 2H | pass 4NT pass 5S | pass 6H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 5!S]

Since there has not been a clear agreement on the trump suit you can assume it is !Hs, the last bid suit.
So you have two Key-Cards (!SA and !HK, along with the !HQ). You therefore bid 5!S and partner bids 6!H.

Auction: 1C pass 1S | pass 4S pass 5C | pass 5H pass 5S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
Partner's jump to 4!S indicates he is prepared to play at game even if you have as few as 6 points. So he must have 20 points or so. With your 14 that puts you in slam range. Decide what you would say next, then click on BID above. [BID 5!C]

Despite your conviction that this hand is going to slam you should NOT ask for Key-Cards holding a worthless doubleton. Instead, you make a slam try by bidding your cheapest control, 5!C. Partner says 5!H. What is your next bid? [BID 5!S]

You can only say 5!S. Partner would have control-bid !Ds if he held the Ace since controls are bid up-the-line. His failure to show it means he doesn't have it. Since you might be off the first two !D tricks you stop at 5!S.
Yes, partner should probably have opened 2NT. Sometimes partners don't make the bids you think they oughta.

Auction: 1D | pass 1S pass 3S | pass 4NT pass 5D | pass 6S pass pass | pass
Analysis: The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 5!D]\n\nYou have 3 Key-Cards so you bid 5!D. Partner bids 6!S.

Auction: 1S | pass 2NT pass 3NT | pass 4H pass 4NT | pass 5S pass 6S | pass pass pass
Analysis: Your partnership plays Jacoby 2NT convention, so partner's 2NT shows a game-forcing raise in !Ss. Your 3NT bid indicates a 5-card suit and "extra values". Partner's 4!H is a control-bid showing the !HA. Decide what you would say next, then click on BID above. [BID 4NT] What you need to know now about partner's hand is Key-Cards so you bid 4NT. He answers 5!S. What is your bid? [BID 6!S] Partner's response says 2 Key-Cards and the !SQ. So you are missing either the trump King or the !DA. So you shouldn't bid 7, but you will almost surely make 6. You bid 6!S.

Auction: 1NT | pass 3D pass 4D | pass 4NT pass 5H | pass 6D all pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 4!D]

Partner's 3!D bid shows a very good hand with probable slam interest. It is very tempting to say 3NT now but you don't have !Hs stopped and don't know if partner does. So with good !D support you bid 4!D. Partner bids 4NT. What is your response? [BID 5!H]

You have 2 Key-Cards, the !SA and !DK. But you don't have the !DQ so you answer 5!H. Partner bids 6!D.

Auction: 1H | pass 3H pass 4C | pass 4H pass 4NT | pass 5C pass 6H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
Your partner's 3!H is a limit-raise, 11-12 points with !H support. Decide what you would say next, then click on BID above. [BID pass]

What you want to know is whether partner holds the !SA. If you bid 4NT and he shows two Key-Cards all will be well, you will know they are the two missing Aces. But if he shows just 1 Key-Card you will be in the soup since you can't tell if that Key-Card is the useful !SA or the practically useless !DA. So you don't use RKCB, you use control-showing and bid 4!C. Partner says 4!H. What do you bid next? [BID 4NT]

Partner would have control-bid !Ds if he had the Ace. You may not think that helps but it does since now you can bid RKCB. You bid 4NT and he answers 5!C. What is your next bid? [BID 6!H]

It was a lot of work but you have figured out that partner holds 11-12 points including one Key-Card which must be the !SA. It looks like the slam is a good idea so you say 6!H.

Auction: 1S pass 4D | pass 4NT pass 5NT | pass 6S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Your 4!D bid is a Splinter Bid, showing opening hand strength, at least 4 !Ss, and a singleton or void in !Ds. Partner bids 4NT. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 5NT]

You have 2 Key-Cards, the !SK and the !CA. So do you bid 5!H?
No. You have two Key-Cards AND a void. So you bid 5NT. Partner bids 6!S.

Auction: 2NT pass 3C | pass 3H pass 4NT | pass 5H pass pass | pass pass
Analysis:
Your partner's 2NT opener is 20-21 points and the 3!C bid is Stayman. Decide what you would say next, then click on BID above. [BID 4NT]

You know of 33 points and you know of an 8-card !H fit. The math tells you that 6!H should be a good slam but you might as well check Key-Cards, that's why the convention was invented. So you bid 4NT and partner answers 5!H. What do you say? [BID pass]

You say "Darn!" You are missing just one Key-Card, but you are also missing the trump Queen. And with partner holding only a 4-card suit that Queen might well win a trick. Knowing that at best the slam will depend on a trump finesse you pass 5!H.

Auction: 2C pass 2H | pass 4NT pass 5C | pass 6H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 2!H]

With 11 points and a good suit you should make a positive response. So you bid 2!H. Partner then says 4NT. What is your bid? [BID 5!C]

The 4NT bid agrees !Hs as trump. You have one Key-Card, the !HK, so you bid 5!C. Partner bids the !H slam.

Auction: 1S pass 3H | pass 3S pass 4NT | pass 5S pass 6S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. Decide what you would say next, then click on BID above. [BID 4NT]

Your partner has shown a minimum opening hand, but with 6 !Ss. You are happy with the 8-card trump fit but need to know about Key-Cards. So you bid 4NT. Partner answers 5!S and it is your bid again. [BID 6!S]

Partner has two Aces and the !SQ. That should be all he needs to make slam so you bid 6!S.

Auction: 2C pass 2H | pass 4NT pass 6C | pass 7H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has gone as shown. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 2!H]

With 11 points and a good suit you should make a positive response. So you bid 2!H. Partner then says 4NT. What is your bid? [BID 6!C]

The 4NT bid agrees !Hs as trump. You have one Key-Card, the !HK, but you also have a void in !Cs. You therefore answer 6!C. Partner goes all the way to 7!H.

Auction: 1NT pass 2C | pass 2S pass 4NT | pass 5C pass 5D | pass 5S pass pass | pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. Decide what you would say next, then click on BID above. [BID 4NT]

Partner has 15-17 points and 4 !Ss. You have 18 points and 4 !Ss. You plan to bid the slam, but first you check Key-Cards. So you bid 4NT. Partner says 5!C. What do you bid? [BID 5!D]

You are missing 1 Key-Card. Slam has become less certain. You decide to see if partner has the trump Queen so you bid 5!D. Partner bids 5!S. What do you say next? [BID pass]

Partner denies having the !SQ. Knowing that the best you could hope for would be a finesse to make the slam you give up your quest and pass.

Auction: pass 1D | pass 1S pass 2H | pass 4NT pass 5C | pass 5D pass 5H | pass 6H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
Your 2!H bid is a Reverse, showing 17+ points. Decide what you would say, then click on BID above. [BID 5!C]

There has been no agreement on trumps, so you assume that North has implicitly agreed to !Hs. So you respond 5!C, showing 4 Key-Cards, three Aces and the !HK. Partner next bids 5!D. What do you say? [BID 5!H]

5!D is the Queen Ask. Partner obviously is thinking about a Grand Slam and wants to know whether you hold the trump Queen (!HQ). Since you do not have the card you return to the agreed trump suit at the lowest level - which is 5!H. Partner now bids 6!H.

Auction: 1H pass 2D | pass 3H pass 4NT | pass 5C pass 5NT | pass 6D pass 7NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. Yes, you could have jump-shifted on your first bid. Decide what you would say next, then click on BID above. [BID 4NT]

Slam in !Hs is almost certain, but you should check for Key-Cards. You bid 4NT and partner says 5!C. What do you bid next? [BID 5NT]

Partner shows 1 or 4 Key-cards. Since he jumped on the second round you figure it must be 4. So you have all the Key-Cards. Time to find out about the other Kings, so you bid 5NT. Partner replies 6!D. What do you bid? [BID 7NT]

Partner has 1 King, the only one left, the !DK. You can count about 17 high-card tricks available so you bid 7NT.

Auction: 1H pass 3S | pass 4NT pass 6H | pass pass pass
Analysis: Your 3!S bid is a Splinter, agreeing !Hs as trump, and showing opening hand strength with a singleton or void in !Ss. Decide what you would say next, then click on BID above. [BID 6!H]\n\nYou have one Key-Card, the !HA. You also have a !S void, but since bidding 6!S would take you above the 6!H level you just respond 6!H. Partner will deduce that your void is in !Ss, particularly because you Splintered in that suit. Partner passes your 6!H bid.

Auction: pass 1S | pass 4D pass 4NT | pass 6D pass 7S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
Partner's 4!D bid is a Splinter Bid. It shows opening hand strength, at least 4-card !S support, and a singleton or void in !Ds. Decide what you would say next, then click on BID above. [BID 4NT]

Normally you would not ask for Key-Cards with this !D holding. But since you know partner has at most a singleton, and that it is not the singleton !DA, you are safe to do so. You say 4NT, partner replies 6!D. What next? [BID 7!S]

WOW! Partner has one Key-Card and a !D void. So the Key-Card is the !SA. You don't know what the rest of partner's hand is, but he can surely take care of that small !C. You bid 7!S.

Auction: 2C pass 2NT | pass 3D pass 4D | pass 4NT pass 5C | pass 5H pass 5S | pass 7NT all pass
Analysis:
Your 2NT response shows 8+ points, with no 5-card biddable suit. Decide what you would say next, then click on BID above. [BID 4!D]

You support the !Ds and partner bids 4NT. What is your next bid? [BID 5!C]

With !Ds as trump you have 1 Key-Card, the !HA. You answer 5!C and partner bids 5!H. What is your bid? [BID 5!S]

This is the Queen Ask, wanting to know if you hold the !DQ. Since you do have it you should bid a suit in which you hold a King. So you bid 5!S. That spurred partner on - he was fishing for 7!D but when you told him you had the !DQ, !HA and !SK he was able to bid 7NT.

Auction: pass 2C | pass 2H pass 3H | pass 3S pass 4NT | pass 6H all pass
Analysis:
Partner's 2!H is a positive response, 8+ points with a 5+ card suit. Decide what you would say next, then click on BID above. [BID 3!H]

Even though it is tempting, bidding RKCB now would be a mistake because of your doubleton !S loser. Instead just support the !Hs. Partner cannot pass, you both know you are forced to game. In fact, partner bids 3!S. What do you bid next? [BID 4NT]

Partner promises first round !S control so NOW you can bid RCKB. When you bid 4NT partner answers 6!H. This shows 1 Key-Card and a void in a suit higher than !Hs. Knowing you are missing either the !DA or !HK you pass.

Auction: 2C pass 2H | pass 2S pass 3S | pass 4NT pass 5H | pass 5NT pass 6D | pass 7NT all pass
Analysis:
Your 2!H response shows 8+ points, with at least 5 !Hs. Decide what you would say next, then click on BID above. [BID 3!S]

Your hand is looking better and better. You already gave a positive response so you know you are forced to game. It is better to keep the bidding low to allow more investigating room so you bid 3!S. Partner bids 4NT. What is your response? [BID 5!H]

With !Ss agreed as trumps you have two Key-Cards, the !SK and the !HA. With no trump Queen you respond 5!H. Partner now says 5NT. What do you reply? [BID 6!D]

Partner is asking for Kings and you have just 1, the !HK. Remember, the !SK is not a King, it is a Key-Card which you have already counted. So you bid 6!D. Partner counts 13 tricks and bids 7NT.

Auction: pass 1S | pass 3S pass 4C | pass 4H pass 6S | pass pass pass
Analysis: Partner's 3!S is a limit raise, 11-12 points and good !S support. Decide what you would say next, then click on BID above. [BID 4!C] What you DO NOT say next is 4NT. If partner answered 1 Key-Card you would not know what to do. If he has a red Ace you can make slam, but if his one Key-Card were the !CA you couldn't. Instead you make a control-showing bid of 4!C, promising first round control. Partner obliges you by bidding 4!H. What is your next bid? [BID 6!S] Partner's bidding is like the Sherlock Holmes tale Silver Blaze, about the dog that didn't bark. Partner's !H bid shows that he DOES have the !HA, but equally important it shows that he DOES NOT have the !DA. So you know you don't have a !H loser but do have a !D loser. You bid 6!S.

Auction: 1NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are East. The bidding has been as shown.
Partner led the !SJ, won by dummy's !SQ. The !D5 is now played from dummy. What do you play?

West dutifully plays a !H and you take the next three tricks. Had he switched to a !D instead, South would have been able to discard one of his !H losers on North's !DQ.

Auction: 2NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You are East. The bidding has been as shown. Partner led the !H5, you put on the !HJ, South won with the !HA. The second trick was !DA, !D2, !D3, !D5. The third trick was !DJ, !D6, !D8, !D7. South then put the !CQ on the table.

But don't believe Declarer, believe your partner. On the first !D West played the !D2. On the second !D he played the !D6. He has an odd number of !Ds, obviously 3. And South must also have a third one, so he is up to some trickery with that !CQ.
So grab your !CA and return partner's !H suit.

Auction: 1NT | pass 2H pass 2S | pass 5NT pass 6S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You are East. The bidding has been as shown. The 2!H bid was a transfer. The 5NT bid meant to choose either 6!S or 6NT. South liked the suit. Partner led the !S5, won by South's !SQ. South pulls one more trump with his !SA, then wins three high !Ds. Next comes dummy's !HA on which he plays the !H3 and West plays the !H9. Then he leads dummy's !H6 which you win with the !HQ. On this trick South drops the !HJ and West the !H2. It is your play.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
If you believe South is now out of !Hs then you shoud not play your !HK because it would give him a ruff-sluff.
But you shouldn't believe South when your partner has sent you a clear signal that he holds an EVEN number of !Hs. In this case an even number must be 4 which means that South has one more !H. So you play your !HK. He ruffs in dummy of course, but then has no way to get rid of that !C loser when the finesse fails.
If you had not been paying attention to West's signal you might have decided to risk a !C lead - with a disastrous result.

Auction: 1C pass pass 1H | pass 2C pass 4H | pass pass pass
Analysis:

After the first trick you know the location of every !C except the !CQ and !CJ. If East started with !C J 2 he would have signaled with the !CJ. If East started with !C Q J 2 he would have signaled with the !CQ. Since he did neither he started either with singleton !C 2 or with !C Q 2. In either case you should play a low !C now which he will either win with his !CQ or he will ruff.
It turns out that he wins with the !CQ, then leads a !S back to your !S A Q.

West discards the !SQ and !S9. [NEXT]
[PLAY N:ST,N:D7,S:HJ,S:H9]
He obviously is not going to throw his !SA and make dummy high, so he will instead bare his !DQ.
So you dump dummy's !SK and win the last two tricks with the !DA and then the !DJ.

Auction: 1H 1S | pass 2H pass 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
North's 2!H cue-bid shows !S support and at least a limit-raise or better. South is to play 4!S. West leads the !HA, then a !H to East's !HK. East plays a third round of !Hs.
Make a Plan, then click NEXT. [NEXT]
The reason you are seeing it like this is that you must do some deducing first.
You saw the bidding and you know that West started with the !HA and East started with the !HK.
Before you can make a good Plan you need to figure out where the !SA, !DK and !CK are located. [NEXT]
Now on with the plan. East/West took the first two !H tricks and then played a third !H which you won, discarding the !D2 from dummy.  [NEXT]
[PLAY N:H7,N:H5,N:D2,S:HQ,S:HJ,S:HT]
This pulls all the trumps and also serves to rectify the count for your upcoming squeeze.
**By the way, notice that if East had played any other way he would have handed you the contract. [NEXT]
[PLAY N:S9,N:S5,S:SK,S:SQ]
So dummy's !DQ cannot be one of the Threat cards. Instead you must make the !DJ in YOUR hand a Threat. You do that by playing the !DA immediately, a Vienna Coup. [NEXT]
[PLAY N:DA,S:D3]
Overtake dummy's !ST and run three more !Ss.
Discard all three !Ds from dummy.
East will discard his 2 !Hs, the !D9 and the !C6. [NEXT]
[PLAY N:ST,N:DQ,N:DT,N:D7,S:SJ,S:S8,S:S7,S:S4]
Play your !S2 and discard dummy's !C4.
Poor East will squirm and try to figure out which discard is best because he doesn't actually KNOW what two cards you have left.
But you aren't squirming because you know that whichever card he throws it will give you your contract.

Auction: 1NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
North opens 1NT. What do you respond? [BID pass]

If partner has a 4-card !H suit to match yours you could revalue your hand and add a point for your doubleton !S. That would give you the 9 points you need for an invitational response.
It is far too risky to play for that possibility. So you just pass.

Auction: 1NT pass 2C | pass 2S pass 2NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
North opens 1NT. What do you respond? [BID 2!C]

You have 9 points and a 4-card Major. Just enough for an invitational Stayman sequence. You bid 2!C and partner answers 2!S. What do you bid next? [BID 2NT]

Partner has the wrong Major. Now that you know there is no 8-card Major fit you must go to notrump. And since you don't have the strength to insist on game you say 2NT which is an invitation for partner to bid 3NT if he has a maximum.
He has a maximum and he bids 3NT.

Auction: 1NT pass 2C | pass 2S pass 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
North opens 1NT. What do you respond? [BID 2!C]

Of course you bid 2!C. Partner now bids 2!S. What is your next bid? [BID 4!S]

Partner hit your suit. When you add a point for your doubleton !C you are up to 10 points. This is the situation where you have to use your judgement, either to invite or to bid the game yourself.
There is really no right or wrong here, between 3!S and 4!S. Those extra T's and 9's swing you to 4!S. As you see it will be a close call, but even if you misguess the !D finesse you will still establish a !D winner for a discard.

Auction: 1NT pass 2C | pass 2D pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
North opens 1NT. What do you respond? [BID 2!C]

Both Majors! Lucky you. So you bid a Stayman 2!C. Unfortunately partner comes back with 2!D. What is your next bid? [BID 3NT]

Partner doesn't have a 4-card Major so your side doesn't have an 8-card Major fit. Therefore you will play in notrump. And with your 12 points you MUST play in game. So you bid 3NT.

Auction: 1NT pass 2C | pass 2S pass 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
North opens 1NT. What do you respond? [BID 2!C]

With 11 points and a 4-card Major suit you bid 2!C. Partner answers 2!S. What is your next bid? [BID 4!S]

Stayman bidding can be very straightforward. Partner has 4 !Ss, you have 4 !Ss. That makes 8. Partner has 15-17 points, you have 11-12 points. That makes 26-29.
You bid 4!S.

Auction: 1NT pass 2C | pass 2D pass 6NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
North opens 1NT. What do you respond? [BID 2!C]

You have a very big hand. Enormous. But you also have two 4-card Majors, so the first step is Stayman. You bid 2!C and partner replies 2!D. What do you bid next? [BID 6NT]

You have 18 points and partner has 15, 16 or 17. Your total is between 33 and 35. You have enough POINTS for a small slam, not enough for a grand. You have no Major suit fit, and are happy to play notrump.
There is a lot to be said for bidding 6NT immediately. You could ask for Aces if you like but whether partner shows one or two isn't going to change your decision. Be bold.

Auction: 1NT pass 2C | pass 2H pass 4NT | pass 5H pass 6H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
North opens 1NT. What do you respond? [BID 2!C]

You have another big hand. And with a 4-card Major you start with 2!C. Partner answers 2!H and it's your turn again. [BID 4NT]

What with your singleton !S you certainly have enough points for slam. But since it's possible partner has only one Ace you check with Blackwood. Partner says 5!H and you say . . . What? [BID 6!H]

Missing one Ace you bid 6!H.

Auction: 1NT pass 2C | pass 2H pass 4H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
North opens 1NT. What do you respond? [BID 2!C]

This may go against your instincts, but if you're going to play Stayman then you should follow the rules. Granted that you have a great !S suit, you also have 4 !Hs. And when you have a 4-card Major you use Stayman. You bid 2!C and partner says 2!H. What do you bid now? [BID 4!H]

That is why you used Stayman - to uncover a 4-4 Major suit fit. Having done so you know that you will play in !Hs and you have enough points to bid game. You bid 4!H.

Auction: 1NT pass 2C | pass 2D pass 3S | pass 4S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
North opens 1NT. What do you respond? [BID 2!C]

Yes, this is the same hand as Deal 8. Again you bid 2!CThis time partner says 2!D. What do you bid now? [BID 3!S]

You need to describe your hand clearly to partner with this bid. You want to show a game-forcing hand (11 points or more) with 4 !Hs and 5 !Ss. You do that by now jumping to 3!S.
If partner had just 2 !Ss he would have bid 3NT. Since he has 3 !Ss he bids 4!S.

Auction: 1NT pass 2C | pass 2S pass 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
[BID 2!C]
Even when you hold a 6-card Major, if you have 4 cards in the other Major you use Stayman. Partner answers 2!S. What do you bid? [BID 4!S]
You've found an 8-card Major fit and you know there are enough points for game. So you bid 4!S.
Yes, but you already knew you had an 8-card !H fit since partner's 1NT promised at least 2 !Hs. In fact, you could play game in either Major. However, it is often better to play in a 4-4 fit rather than a 5-3 or 6-2. This hand shows why. Played in !Hs you will make exactly T tricks with any opening lead. Played in !Ss you will again make T tricks when the defenders start with their 3 !C winners. If they start with anything else you are very likely to make 1 or 2 overtricks by discarding dummy losers on your !H suit.

Auction: 1NT pass 2C | pass 2D pass 4H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
This is the follow-up to Deal T. North opens 1NT. What do you respond? [BID 2!C]

Just like the previous deal with a 4-card Major you use Stayman. This time partner says 2!D. Your turn again. [BID 4!H]

With partner showing no 4-card Major the bidding takes a turn. With your 6 !Hs you are sure of an 8-card fit in the suit. With 11 points you must be sure of reaching game. So you bid 4!H.
In this case the strong hand does not become declarer, but the contract is the right one anyway.

Auction: 1NT | pass 2C pass 2S | pass 2NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You open 1NT and partner responds 2!C. What do you bid? [BID 2!S]

Partner has commanded you to bid a 4-card Major if you have one. You have one, so you bid 2!S. Partner now says 2NT. What do you bid? [BID pass]

Partner evidently has 4 !Hs. He also evidently has about 9 points since he is INVITING you to bid 3NT. With your minimum 15 points you decline the invitation by passing.

Auction: 1NT | pass 2C pass 2D | pass 2NT pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You open 1NT and partner responds 2!C. What do you bid? [BID 2!D]

With no 4-card Major you reply 2!D. What do you bid after partner next says 2NT? [BID 3NT]

Partner seems to have about 9 points and is inviting you to say 3NT. Since you have a maximum 17 point hand you accept the invitation.

Auction: 1NT | pass 2C pass 2S | pass 3S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
You open 1NT and partner responds 2!C. What do you bid? [BID 2!S]

You bid 2!S. Partner next says 3!S. What do you say now? [BID pass]

Considering the bidding you have done so far you couldn't have a worse hand. With 4-3-3-3 distribution and a bare 15 points you most certainly don't want to accept any invitation from partner. So you pass. As you see, 9 tricks are not going to come easily.

Auction: 1NT | pass 2C pass 2H | pass 3H pass 4H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You open 1NT and partner responds 2!C. What do you bid? [BID 2!H]

You respond 2!H. Partner now says 3!H. What do you bid? [BID 4!H]

Partner has told you he has 4 !Hs and approximately 9 points. Add that to your 4 !Hs and 17 points and the total equals a game bid in !Hs. So you say 4!H.

Auction: 1NT | pass 2C pass 2H | pass 2NT pass 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You open 1NT and partner responds 2!C. What do you bid? [BID 2!H]

When you have 4 cards in both Majors you respond 2!H. Partner bids 2NT. What is your next bid? [BID 4!S]

Partner would never bid Stayman without a 4-card Major. Since he did not like your !H bid it is clear that his 4-card Major must be !Ss. His 2NT bid was an invitation for you to bid 3NT, which means he has about 9 points. Knowing that partner has 9 points and 4 !Ss, your call is clear : 4!S.

Auction: 1NT | pass 2C pass 2D | pass 2H pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You open 1NT and partner responds 2!C. What do you bid? [BID 2!D]

You do not have a 4-card Major. So your correct response is 2!D. Partner bids 2!H. What do you bid now? [BID 3NT]

Partner has described a hand with 4 !Ss and 5 !Hs. You don't know his strength but it must be at least 9 points. You know that you have just a 7-card fit in both Majors, and since you have a full 17 points you bid 3NT.

Auction: 1NT | pass 2C pass 2D | pass 2H pass 4H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You open 1NT and partner responds 2!C. What do you bid? [BID 2!D]

Your 2!D response tells partner you have no 4-card Major suit. Then he bids 2!H. What do you say next? [BID 4!H]

Partner knows you do not have 4 !Hs, but he bid the suit anyway. He must have 5 of them and he must also have 4 !Ss (since he used Stayman). But it's the !Hs you are interested in. Partner has 5 and you have 3. So you know of an 8-card Major suit fit. And you also know you have a maximum 1NT opening. So you say 4!H.

Auction: 2NT | pass 3C pass 3D | pass 3S pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
With a balanced 20 points you open 2NT and partner responds 3!C. What do you bid? [BID 3!D]

Stayman applies after a 2NT opening, just one level higher. With no 4-card Major you bid 3!D. Partner next bids 3!S. What do you bid? [BID 3NT]

Partner is showing 5 !Ss and 4 !Hs. In neither case would you have the 8-card fit you need. So you bid 3NT.

Auction: 2NT | pass 3C pass 3H | pass 3NT pass 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
You open 2NT and partner responds 3!C. What do you bid? [BID 3!H]

With 4 cards in each Major suit you bid 3!H. Partner puts you in 3NT. What do you do? Pass or bid? [BID 4!S]

You certainly do not pass. Partner's Stayman bid tells you he has a 4-card Major suit. His 3NT bid tells you the suit was not !Hs. Elementary, Watson, the suit must be !Ss. So you convert the 3NT bid to 4!S.
If you want to make yourself happy you use Stayman, just imagine playing 3NT after a !C lead!

Auction: 2NT pass 3C | pass 3S pass 6S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
North opens 2NT. What do you respond? [BID 3!C]
Wow! Start thinking slam, but first things first. Find the suit by starting with Stayman. You bid 3!C and partner replies 3!S. What do you say next? [BID 6!S]

Your hand revalues to 16 points now that you know there's a !S fit. So certainly you want to be in slam as long as there are not two quick !C losers. At this point you might try something like a 4!D cue bid, hoping partner will read that as a slam try in !Ss, but denying the !C control. But that seems awfully easy to be misunderstood. We suggest an immediate 6!S.
Good thing it's being played by North, right?

Auction: 1NT pass 2C | pass 2H pass pass | pass |
Analysis:
North opens 1NT. What do you respond? [BID 2!C]

Your first thought should be that with only 4 points you will pass. But on second thought, what would partner respond if you bid a Stayman 2!C? So you give it a shot and partner says 2!H. What next? [BID pass]

What's next is your PASS. And if he had bid 2!S you also would have passed. And if he had bid 2!D you also would have passed. You figured that with this hand any response partner could make would be a better place than 1NT.

Auction: 1NT pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
North opens 1NT. What do you respond? [BID 3NT]

With 12 points and a 4-card !S suit this fits the model for Stayman.
But thinking a little further, with this 4-3-3-3 distribution you have no ruffing values whatsoever. So even if partner also has 4 !Ss there might not be an advantage in playing the suit contract. So for this specific distribution you ignore your 4-card Major and just bid 3NT.

Auction: pass 1NT | pass 2C 2S pass | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
After you open 1NT partner bids 2!C, then East says 2!S. What do you say next? [BID pass]

Basically you said your say when you opened 1NT. You don't have a 4-card Major and you have a minimum hand. The best way to convey this information to partner is to pass. At which point partner jumps to 3NT. What do you say? [BID pass]

Pass, then "Thank you partner" when dummy comes down. The thing to remember is that partner is in charge. You describe your hand as well as you can and then sit back and let him make the decisions. Perhaps you would have doubled if you held his hand but he didn't.

Auction: 1NT 2D 3D | pass 3H pass 4H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
North opens 1NT and East overcalls 2!D. What do you say? [BID 3!D]

Dad-burned interfering opponents. You were going to bid a Stayman 2!C and now you can't. You also don't want to bid either Major with only 4 of them. And you certainly can't bid notrump with no !D stopper. Fortunately the overcall has opened a window of opportunity for you. So you cue-bid 3!D. Even if you and partner haven't discussed this it is pretty obvious that you don't really want to play in !Ds, so the most likely action for him is to bid a suit, and a Major suit would have priority. So really, the cue-bid achieves the same purpose as Stayman would have.
Partner now bids 3!H. What do you say? [BID 4!H]

Partner showed a 4-card !H suit. With your 4 that makes a fit. You have 12 revalued points so you bid 4!H.

Auction: 1D X | pass 1H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID double]

You have a perfect hand for a Takeout Double. Singleton in their suit, 4-card support for the other three suits and 13 HCP. You Double. Partner responds 1!H. What do you say next? [BID pass]

Yes, you like the !Hs. But remember, you forced partner to bid and his response showed 8 or fewer points. You are not strong enough to consider a game so you pass.

Auction: 1D X | pass 1S pass 2S | pass 4S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID double]

Naturally you make a Takeout Double. Partner responds 1!S. What is your next call? [BID 2!S]

With 17 HCP and the singleton you are not strong enough to insist on game. On the other hand if partner is at the top of his 0-8 point range then game is likely. A raise to 2!S invites partner to bid game with a maximum. Partner accepts the invitation.

Auction: 1C X | pass 1H pass 3H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID double]

With 19 HCP and a doubleton you certainly double. What do you bid after partner replies 1!H? [BID 3!H]

You need to make a strong invitation since partner needs very little for your side to have a game. So you bid 3!H. Partner has almost nothing so he passes. Good thing.

Auction: 1H X | pass 2S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID double]

This is certainly not a great hand, but at least the shape is good. You should strive to get into the bidding whenever possible, and with this hand the only way in is to double. Partner jumps to 2!S and it is your bid again. [BID pass]

Partner shows 9-11 points and a !S suit. However, he didn't force you to game, and you barely scraped up the double to begin with. So you pass.

Auction: 1H X | pass 2S pass 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID double]

This is almost the hand you held in Deal 4 - just 3 points stronger in !Ds. So you double, and again partner jumps to 2!S. What do you bid? [BID 4!S]

That extra 3 points makes all the difference. With that singleton !H your hand is now worth at least 16 points. Add partner's 9, T or 11 and you are at game level. Bid 4!S.

Auction: 1D X | pass 2D 3D 3S | pass 4S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID double]

You'd really like to have 4-card support for both Majors when you double a Minor. But it's not a requirement. So you double and hear partner respond 2!D. East then chips in with 3!D. What now? [BID 3!S]

Don't let East's bid bother you, he's just trying to push the envelope. You have a good hand and partner's bid shows 12+ points and is forcing to game. Now you have to find the right game, and the best way to start is by showing a 4-card Major suit. You bid 3!S.
That was what partner needed to hear, he bids 4!S.

Auction: 1S X | pass 1NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID double]

The minimum requirements for a Takeout Double are 12 points, no more than two of Opener's suit, and at least 3-cards in the other suits. You just squeak by so you double. Partner says 1NT and it is your bid again. [BID pass]

With no suit fit you can't even count a point for your doubleton so you have just 13 HCP. Partner's bid shows 8-T so you waste no time in passing. Don't worry about the !Ss, partner says he has them covered.

Auction: 1S X | pass 1NT pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID double]

Partner is showing you 8-10 points and no 4-card !H suit. What do you bid now? [BID 3NT]

With no Major fit you are happy to play in notrump, knowing partner can stop their suit. Partner's 8-10 points added to your 17 is a probable game so you bid 3NT.

Auction: 1S X | pass 2C pass 2H | pass 4H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID double]

You have 16 HCP and two more points for the fifth and sixth !Hs. That is too strong for a simple overcall. Instead you double. Partner responds 2!C. What do you bid? [BID 2!H]

You bid 2!H, describing your hand as a 1-suited hand, too strong to merely overcall. Partner bids the !H game and you pass.

Auction: 1C pass 1S X | pass 2D pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID double]

You should double. This is a special case of the Takeout Double, where the opponents have already bid two suits before it gets to you. Since they apparently have at least 20 points, you should have a solid hand with at least 4-4 in the two unbid suits. A hand just like this one.
Partner bids 2!D. What do you say next? [BID pass]

Just pass. This is obviously a fight for the partscore and you have the advantage because you have found a fit. However, you suspect partner is quite weak.

Auction: pass 2S X | pass 3H pass 4H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID double]

Pretty good hand you have. Certainly good enough to make a Takeout Double that forces partner to the 3-level. Partner responds 3!H. What do you bid? [BID 4!H]

Some questions don't have a correct answer. If partner has !H Q x x x along with the !CK and !DQ he would bid just as he did and slam would be cold. But if he has four small !Hs and nothing else he would bid just as he did and you probably cannot make ten tricks. On balance it is probably best to just bid the most likely reasonable contract, which is 4!H.

Auction: 1D X | pass 1S pass 1NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID double]

You have a perfect 2NT opening hand. Trouble is, the opponents have already opened. You get around that problem by first making a Takeout Double. Partner replies 1!S. What do you bid now? [BID 1NT]

You could not say 1NT on your first bid because that would show 15-18 points. Doubling first, then bidding the lowest level of notrump shows 19-20 points. Of course in both cases you must have their suit adequately stopped. Partner does the math and bids 3NT.

Auction: 1C X | pass 1D pass 2NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID double]

You double and partner responds 1!D. What do you bid next? [BID 2NT]

The pattern continues. Overcall 1NT with 15-18. Double, then bid notrump with 19-20. Double then jump in notrump with 21-22. So you jump to 2NT. Partner puts it to 3NT.

Auction: 1D X pass 1S | pass 2S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 1!S]

You have no choice. You absolutely may not pass. So you say 1!S. Partner now bids 2!S. What do you say? [BID pass]

Partner obviously has a good hand. Your response showed 0-8 points and he still found enough strength to invite you to bid game. However, with your 4-point square hand you must decline the invitation.

Auction: 1H X pass 1S | pass 2S pass 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 1!S]

With 7 points you must make a minimum response. Even though !Cs is your best suit you should prefer to show a 4-card Major. So you bid 1!S. Partner raises to 2!S and it is your turn to bid. [BID 4!S]

Your first response showed 0-8 points. Knowing that, partner still invited you to go on if you were at the high end of the range. With 7 HCP and a doubleton you are right at the maximum for your bid, so you bid 4!S.

Auction: 1S X pass 3H | pass 4H pass pass | pass
Analysis: The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 3!H]\n\nYour hand falls in the 9-11 point mid-range response where you make a jump bid. With two decent suits you naturally choose the Major and bid 3!H. Partner raises you to game.

Auction: 1C X pass 2C | pass 2H pass 2S | pass 4S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 2!C]

Partner has an opening hand and you have an opening hand. Your first priority is to inform partner that your side must reach game. You do this with a 2!C cuebid. Partner comes back with 2!H. What do you say? [BID 2!S]

With both of you knowing you will reach game, partner has suggested !Hs. You don't care much for that suggestion, but would now consider 3NT. However, you should first mention your 4-card !S suit. Having found the fit, partner bids game.

Auction: 1S X pass 4H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 4!H]

You COULD make a game-forcing cuebid here, but a much better description of your hand is a leap to 4!H, the spot where you know you want to play. If partner has any extra strength he will know to bid again. In this case he has a bare minimum and passes.
Notice that if you had made a cuebid, partner would probably end up playing 4!H and the opening !S lead would be right through your !SK.

Auction: 1D X pass 1H | pass 2S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 1!H]

Don't even think about bidding 1NT. You are way way too weak for that. Don't even think about passing for penalties. Your !D are nowhere near good enough. Partner is forcing you to bid a suit, so you bid your best non-!D suit, !Hs. Partner now jumps to 2!S. What do you say? [BID pass]

You say pass. Despite partner showing you a big hand you just can't help him.

Auction: 1H X pass 2C | 2H 2S pass 3S | pass 4S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 2!C]

Partner told you to bid, so you say 2!C. West repeats his suit and partner then says 2!S. What do you bid now? [BID 3!S]

By doubling and then bidding his own suit, partner is showing a good hand, at least 17 points. Your hand can be revalued to about 7 points so you are good enough to invite partner to game. You bid 3!S and partner says 4!S.

Auction: 1D X 1S pass | 2D X pass 3C | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID pass]

Now that East has stolen your response you aren't strong enough to make a free-bid at the 2-level. You pass, West bids 2!D and partner doubles again. Now what? [BID 3!C]

This is not a penalty double, partner is merely repeating his request for you to name a suit. But now he expects you to choose between !Hs and !Cs.
You bid 3!C and everybody passes.
You may be one too high, but that still might be a good score if they can make 2!D.

Auction: 1D X 1S 2H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 2!H]

After East bids you are no longer forced to respond to partner's Takeout Double. You may pass is you want to.
But if you don't pass you are making what is called a "free bid". You should have 6 or more points and a reason for wanting to bid - like your 5-card !H suit.
You bid 2!H and everybody passes.

Auction: 1D X XX 1H | pass pass 2D pass | pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID 1!H]

The redouble has taken the force from you - you can pass if you want to. But if you pass, the most likely scenario is that West will also pass. So partner will either have to let them play 1!D redoubled (which will be a disaster for your side) or take out his own double by bidding some suit. So he will bid a suit and it will almost surely be 1!S.
You can help your side the most by bidding 1!H immediately. You don't have to worry that partner will believe you have a good hand; both he and West have 13+ points and East's redouble shows T or more. He knows there are no points remaining for you to have.
On this deal your !H bid gets passed around to East who bids 2!D, the final contract.

Auction: 2H X | pass 3H pass 3S | pass 4C pass 5C | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID double]

The problem with making a Takeout Double of a preemptive bid is that the bidding for your side starts out a level or two higher. So you can't risk doubling with a flimsy hand. However, this hand is certainly good enough so you double. Partner responds 3!H. What do you bid? [BID 3!S]

After partner cuebids the next job is to find a suit, so you bid 3!S. Partner now bids 4!C. What do you say? [BID 5!C]

You cannot stop short of game. Partner has apparently rejected your !S suggestion. Since you are happy to play in !Cs you bid 5!C.

Auction: 1C X pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. It is your bid. What do you say? [BID pass]

You could certainly say 1NT if you wanted to. You have 8 HCP and a very good !C stopper. However, you will probably make a lot more points by letting them play 1!C doubled.
This is exactly the kind of hand you need to pass and convert partner's Takeout Double to a Penalty Double. Partner should lead a !C so you can pull declarer's trumps as soon as possible.

Auction: 1NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. Partner led the !S2, dummy played the !S3 and it is your play.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
This is a perfect example of why you should USUALLY play Third-hand-high.
If you do not put your !SQ on this trick declarer will get an undeserved winner with his !SJ. In this Deal it will be his ninth trick. Play Third-hand-high and he will go down, otherwise he will make his contract.

Auction: 1S | pass 3S pass 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. Partner led the !HQ, dummy played the !H4 and it is your play.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
You dare not play low for fear declarer might win a singleton !HK.
And when you win the first trick, (the !HK does NOT fall), you have to decide what to do next. Do not just return the suit like a robot since it is obvious that you have no more !H winners and you surely won't win any !C tricks.
You need to switch to a !D, and the !D4, (low from an honor) is recommended.
Played this way you will defeat the contract by one trick. If you allow declarer to win the first trick he will pull trumps and discard two red losers on dummy's !C and make an overtrick.

Auction: 1NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. Partner led the !C4, dummy played the !C3 and it is your play.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
But that doesn't mean you should blindly play your HIGHEST card, rather you should play the LOWEST of high-equals.
In other words, in this case you should play the !CJ, which is equal to the !CQ.
If instead you play the !CQ, figuring it makes no difference, you'd be right that it makes no difference to you. But partner would then assume that it is declarer with the !CJ, and when he obtains the lead with the !DK he will be unlikely to lead another !C, which would be too bad for your side.

Auction: 1H | pass 2C pass 2H | pass 4H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. Partner led the !S3, dummy played the !S4 and it is your play.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
Partner's low !S lead tells you that he has an honor in the suit. There are only two !S honors you can't see, and you know he wouldn't underlead an Ace at a suit contract. So partner holds the !SQ.
You can see clearly what would happen if you played Third-hand-high and put on your !SK. Declarer would win his !SA and could then set up a second !S trick by leading toward dummy's !SJ.
By playing the !ST you force declarer to win with the !SA if he wants the trick. But however he plays he can only make one !S trick when you play correctly.
For your side, 2 !S tricks and the two minor Aces spell defeat.

Auction: 1NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. Partner led the !S7, dummy played the !S3 and it is your play.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
Partner has led a small card, so it is surely fourth-down. That means you should automatically apply the Rule of Eleven.
11 minus 7 equals 4, so there are just 4 cards higher than the 7 between dummy, you, and declarer. AND YOU CAN SEE ALL FOUR OF THEM.
Declarer has no card that can beat the !S7, and the only way you can beat this contract is to let partner's !S7 hold the trick. He will continue the suit, allowing you to pick up dummy's !SK and four !S winners. Along with the !DA you will defeat the contract.
If you play ANY card except your !S2 on the first trick you will not be able to win four tricks in the suit because you cannot get West back into the lead. And declarer will make the contract easily.

Auction: 1H 1S | pass 2H pass 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. North's 2!H bid shows good !S support with at least 10 points.
Partner led the !H8, dummy played the !H6 and it is your play.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
Partner's !H8 lead is a high spot card, either top-of-nothing, or a singleton or doubleton. He definitely does not have an honor, which means that South holds !H A Q J.
In other words, your !HK is dead in the water. BUT, if you play it to this trick you hand South three !H tricks, while if you play a low !H he can only get 2 winners in the suit.
The extra winner would permit South to discard 2 of dummy's !D losers, and this would give South the contract.

Auction: 1NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. Partner led the !HQ, dummy played the !H4 and it is your play.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
Admittedly you have a terrible hand. But that's no reason to be careless. YOU can beat this contract, but you have to do it right now by unblocking the !HK. If declarer holds up you will continue with your !H7 and partner will establish his suit while he still has the !CA for an entry. If declarer doesn't hold up it will be just as bad for him.
But suppose you say "Well, partner's !HQ is just as good as my !HK so I'll just save the King for later" as you play low. Declarer will love you. He will hold up on the !HQ, then again on trick two when you play the !HK. AND HE WILL STILL HAVE HIS !HA when you switch to another suit. He will have time to drive out the !CA while he still has !Hs stopped.
It was a good thing you held the !HK rather than declarer, but it is a nuisance that you must get out of the way on the very first trick.

Auction: 1S pass 1NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. Partner led the !H2, dummy played the !HA and it is your play.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
You know partner has a 4-card !H suit, (he led the deuce), and you know it is headed by an honor. You hope the honor is the !HJ, but in any case you must get your high !Hs out of the way.
Declarer will probably come to his hand and then take a !S finesse. You win the !SK, take your other high !H, then lead your !H3 toward your partner.
As you see, partner did hold the !H J 9, so your side wins 3 !H tricks.
If declarer played low on the first trick you would win the !HQ, then play the !HK to dummy's !HA.

Auction: 1H pass 2NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. Partner led the !S5, dummy played the !S2 and it is your play.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
Partner's low !S lead tells you he has an honor in the suit, so it must be either the !SQ or the !ST. South's jump to 2NT makes it almost certain that he holds the !SQ, so you can figure partner probably led from !S T x x 5.
Apply the Rule of 11. 11 minus 5 = 6 cards higher than the !S5 held by dummy, you, and declarer. Since you can see 5 of the 6 you conclude that that declarer will have to play his !SQ to beat your !S7.
South will take the !SQ at trick 1, but when West wins a high !H he will play another !S through dummy's !S K 9 to your !S A J. Once you clear dummy's !S away partner will win another !H and be able to cash his last !S.
Note that if dummy's !S9 was played you would cover with your !SJ, leading to the same situation.

Auction: 1NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. Partner led the !H5, dummy played the !H8 and it is your play.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
The Rule of Eleven tells you there are 6 cards in North, East and South that are higher than the !H5. You can see 5 of them, so that leaves just one of them for South.
West cannot have all three of the outstanding honors, because from !H K J T x x his correct lead would be the Jack. So you can deduce that South must hold exactly one of !HK, !HJ, or !HT.
If his honor is not the !HK then it won't matter whether you play !HA or !HQ to the first trick; you will win your two top cards and then play your small one back to West.
So assume South actually holds the !HK x x. If you play the !HA to trick one, then lead !HQ, South will hold up on the second trick, and win the third !H. Then, when you win your !CK you will not have a !H to return to partner and declarer will make the contract.
So what happens if you play the !HQ at trick one? South could still make the contract by holding up, but he will be afraid to do so. After all, from his perspective it looks like West probably holds the !HA and he will be afraid of losing the first 5 !H tricks, perhaps even when the !CK finessing is working!

Auction: 1C pass 1S | 2H 3S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. Partner led the !HQ, dummy played the !H6 and it is your play.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
Your side needs to take 5 tricks to defeat this contract. Two of them will be !Hs, but it doesn't look like you can win any !Cs or !Ss.
That means you need to win 3 !D tricks and the only way that can happen is if you play !Ds from your side.
So win the first !HK (so partner will know you also have the !HA), and play the !DT. Presumably South will play an honor, but West will take the trick and put you back on lead with your !HA. You play the !D9 and your side will collect 3 !D tricks to go with your 2!Hs.

Auction: 1D pass 1H | 1S 4H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. Partner led the !SA, then the !SK. Dummy follows suit and it is your play to the second trick.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
It is obvious that your side can only get 2 !S tricks. And assuming that South has the Ace of trumps you will not make a single trick in the red suits. So you need to make 2 !C tricks.
If partner has the !C A K then he will take them, but if he has the !C A J he cannot win 2 !C tricks from his side. 
To allow for this situation it will be better to play !Cs from your side of the table, and the way to make that happen is for you to ruff partner's !SK with an otherwise useless trump. You still get your two !S winners (sort of) but now you get to play a !C through South's !CK at trick 3.

Auction: 1D 1H 2C | pass 3C pass 3NT | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. Partner led the !H8, dummy played the !HJ and it is your play.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
South played dummy's !HJ to tempt you to cover. Don't fall for it.
Partner's lead of a high spot card shows no honors in the suit. That added to the fact that South bid Notrump after you had mentioned !Hs is pretty good evidence that South holds at least !H Q x x. 
To maintain communication with partner your best hope is to duck the first !H, but to signal encouragement with the !H9.
South wins the first trick easily, but must try to establish !Cs. He will enter dummy with the !SA, then try to run the !CQ.
Not today. Partner takes the !CK and returns his !H2 to your four winners.

Auction: 1NT | pass 2C pass 2S | pass 4S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. Partner led the !C9, dummy played the !CT and it is your play.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
Partner's !C9 is likely from a short suit. If it is a singleton, you should take the !CA immediately and return the suit for a ruff. If it is a doubleton, you should NOT take your !CA now, but should hope partner can get the lead and play his second !C to your Ace so you can give him the ruff.
You can figure out which it is.
If it is a singleton, then South must hold 5 !Cs. But you know South has 4 !Ss, so if he also has 5 !Cs then he only has 4 red cards, and he would not have opened 1NT with either 5-4-2-2 or 5-4-3-1 distribution.
So partner's !C9 is not a singleton, and you should wait. Declarer then runs dummy's !SQ. Partner wins the !SK, returns his OTHER !C to your !CA, and NOW you give him the ruff. He takes the !DA for down 1.

Auction: 1H X | pass 2C pass 2NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. Partner led the !HT, dummy played the !HJ and it is your play.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
Declarer gets two !H winners whether you play one of your honors on this trick or not. So why does it matter what you do?
Suppose you cover with your !HQ. South will win his !HA, then play !Cs until your !CA is forced out on the third round. He can then force an entry to dummy in the !H suit to reach the two !C winners.
Now suppose you duck the !HJ. Again South will push !Cs, and again you hold up until the third round. Ahh, what a difference. Now declarer cannot use the !Hs to enter dummy and he will never get to enjoy those two !C winners.

Auction: 1C 1S 2NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. Partner led the !SQ, a low card was played from dummy, and it is your play.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
It seems that perhaps you should play low and let partner's !SQ force out South's !SA. Then, when you get the lead with a high !C you can force out South's !SJ. Get the lead with your other high !C and set the contract with !Ss.
Suppose you try that. Play low on the first !S. South will also play low and West will be left holding the trick, and also holding the bag!With no more !Ss West will have to play one of the other three suits, and that is just what South wants to have happen. The contract could no longer be beaten.
Now do it the right way. Play your !SK on partner's !SQ. Assume South takes the trick, although it doesn't matter whether he wins the first one or holds up. When you win your first !C drive out South's !SJ. When you win your second !C trick your !Ss will be good. If you overtake the first trick the contract can no longer be made.
Notice that South will always make two !S tricks, so your overtake costs nothing.

Auction: 1C 2S 2NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. Partner led the !S9, dummy played the !S6 and it is your play.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
You could easily win the !SK, then play a small !S to drive out dummy's !SA. But South bid Notrump over your 2!S overcall, so he surely holds !S Q J T. So when you get the lead with your one !CA entry you can establish your !Ss, but you won't get into the lead to cash them.
Look what happens when you duck the first trick. South will win the trick with his !ST, and start on dummy's !C suit.
West (your wonderful partner) will win the first !C and return his final !S to dummy's !SA.
South will have to keep working on !Cs, but now you can win the !CA and play your !SK, dropping South's !SQ, and your other three good !Ss.
Just like the previous deal, South gets two !S tricks either way, but one way he makes an overtrick, the other way he goes down 2.

Auction: 1H | Dbl Rdbl 2C pass | 3C 3H pass 4H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. Partner led the !CK, dummy played low and it is your play.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
You are pretty sure partner would not have supported your !Cs unless he had 4 of them, which means it is very likely that South has a singleton. (he might even be void)
So if you are to set this contract partner is going to have to have some !S winners. It might not matter, but it also might be vital that the first !S lead comes from your side of the table so after you overtake with the !CA you switch to the !S7.
Partner loves it - whatever South does West takes the next two !Ss, then leads a third !S for you to ruff. Down 1.

Auction: 1D pass 1S | pass 2S pass 4S | pass pass pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. Partner led the !CK, dummy played the !C7 and it is your play.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
As soon as you see the opening lead and dummy you should start figuring out just how you can defeat the contract. Hopefully this plan came to your mind.
From his lead, you know partner also holds the !CQ. Overtake the !CK. Play your singleton !H5. When South starts on trumps, win the first one with your !SA. Put partner back on lead with a small !C to his known !CQ.
If you have a partner who pays attention he will now play a !H for you to ruff. Two !Cs, the Ace of trumps, and a !H ruff makes down 1.

Auction: 1C | pass 1H pass 1NT | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
The bidding has been as shown. Partner led the !DK, dummy played low and it is your play.
When you have made your choice click NEXT. [NEXT]
Put yourself in partner's shoes. He almost surely has !D K Q T x (x). When South holds up on his !DA, which he almost surely will, West may think he is holding up with !D A J x, and be afraid to continue the suit.
You can help your partner figure out the true situation by merely playing your !DJ so he can see that South doesn't have it.
With this good play West will be able to continue !Ds and defeat the contract.

Auction: 1NT pass 2D | pass 2H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
North opens 1NT. What do you respond? [BID 2!D]
With 6 !Hs of your own you can be sure that your side has at least an 8-card !H fit. So playing !Hs will be better than playing notrump. You bid 2!D, transferring partner to !Hs. Partner says 2!H. What do you bid now? [BID pass]
Of course you pass. You only have 6 points so there is no chance for game. You just wanted to reach the best partscore and figured 2!H would be safer than 1NT.
As you can see from partner's hand you made the right call. Played in !Hs your hand will produce five tricks. At notrump your hand will win only one trick if the defenders hold up their !HA just one time.

Auction: 1NT pass 2H | pass 2S pass 2NT | pass 3S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
North's 1NT opening shows 15-17 points. What is your bid? [BID 2!H]
With 9 points you have an invitational strength hand. With a 5-card !S suit you should transfer partner to !Ss by bidding 2!H. Partner dutifully responds 2!S. What do you say now? [BID 2NT]
With this next bid you must tell partner you only have invitational strength, and inform him that you have only 5 !Ss (remember, your transfer promised AT LEAST 5). The bid that says both of these facts at once is 2NT. Partner comes back with 3!S. What say you? [BID pass]
You say pass. Partner did not accept your invitation to game so he must have a minimum hand. His correction to 3!S indicates he has three of the suit and wants to play in !Ss rather than notrump.
You might revalue your hand up to 10 points now that an 8-card fit has been discovered, but it is a really poor 10 points. Also, remember the warning about Responder revaluing for short suits.
As you can see, a 4!S contract would have no chance, losing 1 trick in each side suit and at least 1 !S.

Auction: 1NT pass 2H | pass 2S pass 3NT | pass 4S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
North's 1NT opening shows 15-17 points. What is your bid? [BID 2!H]
With 11 points you are strong enough to force to game. With a 5-card !S suit you should transfer partner to !Ss by bidding 2!H. Partner dutifully responds 2!S. What do you say now? [BID 3NT]
You must make a bid that will force partner to game, but at the same time inform him that you have only 5 !Ss (remember, your transfer promised AT LEAST 5). The bid that says both of these facts at once is 3NT. Partner comes back with 4!S. What say you? [BID pass]
You say pass.
You might revalue your hand up to 12 points now that an 8-card fit has been discovered, but with partner's maximum of 17 you are nowhere near slam range.
A 4!S contract is definitely the place to be.

Auction: 1NT pass 2D | pass 2H pass 3H | pass pass pass
Analysis:
North opens 1NT. What do you respond? [BID 2!D]
You have 9 points and 6 !Hs. You transfer partner to !Hs by bidding 2!D. He bids 2!H, as instructed.
What is your next bid? [BID 3!H]
You want to tell partner you have invitational strength. You also want to tell him that you have 6 !Hs, and that the contract must be played in !Hs. The bid that says both is 3!H.
Partner declines your invitation by passing.
A comment is in order about revaluing your hand. Since partner must have at least a doubleton !H it is tempting to claim that with the 8-card fit you should add one point for each of your doubletons, bringing your total to 11. If you did this then you should be bidding game rather than just inviting. The problem with the revaluing is that counting doubleton points in the long-trump hand is deceiving. If you do end up ruffing one or both of those suits it will not add any tricks to your total since you would make your small trumps anyway. So when you have a 6-card suit it is more accurate to not revalue.
As you can see, making even 9 tricks is going to be a challenge.

Auction: 1NT pass 2D | pass 2H pass 4H | pass pass pass
Analysis: North opens 1NT. What do you respond? [BID 2!D]\nYou should bid 2!D to transfer partner to !Hs. He bids 2!H. What do you say now? [BID 4!H]\nYou know you have at least an 8-card !H fit. You know you have at least 26 points (15 + 11). She who knows, goes, so you bid 4!H.

Auction: 1NT pass 2D | pass 2H pass 2S | pass 4S pass pass | pass
Analysis:
North opens 1NT. What do you respond? [BID 2!D]
You transfer of course, but to which Major? It can work either way, but the preferred method is to first transfer partner to !Hs when you have an invitational hand. So you bid 2!D, and partner of course says 2!H. What do you bid next? [BID 2!S]
You now show your second 5-card Major by bidding 2!S.
At this point partner becomes the Captain. You have described an invitational (9 point) hand with 5-5 in the Majors. Partner's next bid should set the contract wherever he chooses. In this case, with a maximum 1NT opener and 3 !Ss he picks 4!S.
Note that you must have at least one Major suit fit since partner cannot have a doubleton in both.

Auction: 1NT pass 2H | pass 2S pass 3H | pass 4H pass pass | pass
Analysis:
North opens 1NT. What do you respond? [BID 2!H]
This is the sequel to Deal 6. You are 5-5 in the Majors again, but this time you have game forcing strength.
The preferred method for this hand is to transfer partner to !Ss, so you bid 2!H.
What do you bid after partner completes the transfer? [BID 3!H]
You show your second 5-card Major by bidding 3!H. Since this shows game-forcing strength (11+ points) partner may not pass, but must bid either 4!H or 4!S. In this Deal he naturally bids 4!H.
If you held an even stronger hand and wished to move toward a slam you would start out the same way but then bid again after partner's game bid.

Auction: 1NT pass 2H | pass 2S pass 3C | pass 3NT pass pass | pass
Analysis:
North opens 1NT. What do you respond? [BID 2!H]
Initiate the transfer by bidding 2!H. After partner responds 2!S what do you bid? [BID 3!C]
